reviewText:
Intuitive controls, clever combat, and polish all work nicely to make Vran stand out. Players will find themselves wall jumping to find secrets and dodge rolling to avoid attacks all with the comfort of smooth directional input (WASD or controller).  Though Vran has loot (graded equipment with random qualities), sprawling dungeons, and grinding like many traditional ARPGs, a fair amount of the game has a tinge of Bastion to it.

For those who have not yet played Bastion, it is a whimsical ARPG that skips loot in favor of loadouts where weapons determine play style, difficulty can be shaped by modifiers, equipment is handled by handful of set items, special abilities are separate from weapons, and character progression involves opening more ways to tinker with these aspects. Victor Vran follows Bastion fairly close in these areas, but with some great added twists in addition to loot.

Every weapon uses a kit of three abilities and powerful special skills use an “overdrive” meter which can be filled a few different ways. The weapons are finely designed: each type feels fun, unique, and balanced, so choosing any of the bunch is satisfying. The kits are engaging and reward players for stringing abilities or timing attacks carefully rather than button mashing. The game also tries to mitigate the burn of carrying favored-but-weaker equipment by letting players break down gear to boost weapons within limit. Despite the drastic visual shift, outfits mainly change how overdrive generates; the more interesting parts to tinker with are destiny cards. These cards, equipped by using “destiny points” from a pool, offer everything from more damage to weapon specialization, and like weapons they act as loot. Once the basic mechanics become second nature, picking the right equipment for the job is a lot of fun.

Victor Vran’s amount of build freedom houses a lot 	of potential for players, but comes at a cost. Character progression suffers a bit in order to allow players to tinker freely. After a few levels, leveling up is underwhelming because it only grants health or destiny points and an item. The lack of hard classes or skill trees means there is no Blessed Hammer moment or satisfaction of a full skill tree. Once you see all the kits and weapon cards, you have seen a large portion of builds. There is little reason to start a new game unless you plan on starting a fresh co-op run. To be fair, the game really tries to push towards an extended endgame experience with lots of challenges, an endless dungeon, and equipment boosting.

Put plainly, Victor Vran is bland outside of gameplay. Other recent ARPGs having some kind of personality: Bastion’s narration, Diablo’s legacy, and The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing’s chatty characters all succeed. Vran’s story could be bottled as a sleep aid, and the characters are as memorable as that one movie with Kevin Costner and a non-white cast that came out last year- oh wait, there were two. What is strange is that Victor talks to the handful of NPCs (also forgettable) in the hub area but rarely talks when adventuring. While The Voice, some mask that tags along with Victor, blabbers on everywhere except the hub area. The Voice is rather unfunny: lazy references, mocking Victor who has no character or comebacks, and hit-or-miss observations. The Incredibly Long Title for a Game Helsing has protagonists that share banter. Bastion has a strong narrator. Vran has broody grumbles with an unamusing companion whom he ignores. Not a deal breaker, but it is certainly a misstep, and it is possible that the real villain of the game just sucked the personality dry.

Victor Vran is polished, fluid, and different. The combat, equipment and movement in the game craft an absorbing experience. At the time of this writing, the devs have released much of their planned post-release content with the notable exceptions of local co-op and a Motörhead expansion (which may be tied to the tragic loss of Lemmy). The base game offers a healthy foundation for continued support and I would gladly buy any content they decide to add. While story and character may fall short, the gameplay is rewarding and dynamic.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Alright, so after putting 10 hours into Victor Vran and completing ALL of the content that this Early Access had to offer, here is my review:

The game takes a bit of a casual approach to the ARPG genre, pretty close to that of Baldur's Gate: Dark Alliance. The enemies in this version of EA have good AI, varied skills, and different means in which you should go about defeating them if you want to be efficient. Rather than having classes, in VV (Victor Vran) there is only one hero, that's why his name is the same as the game. Instead the game's focus is on making every piece of equipment so vastly different that gives the game a very unique feel. Each weapon has a different attacks, effects and skills/abilities associated with them. There are also powerful spells that require you to build up energy through various means to perform for great effect, and potions/elixirs to quickly change the flow of battle in your favor.

The game offers a challenge to the more experienced players pretty early on in the form of Hexes. When activated, they will continiously reward you so long as they are on, but also make the enemies far more dangerous. As a veteran of ARPGs, I felt far more entertained with two of them on the entire time that I played, turning on a couple more every now and then to make the game more difficult when I went back to clear lower level areas. Speaking of which, every area has a set of five challenges that you can complete for immediate rewards. While this is cool and all, I sincerely hope that is not their idea of end-game content."

The graphics in VV are good for an ARPG

reviewText:
I'm in LOVE with Victor Vran! I love the dungeon crawling, rogue, hack & slash ARPG gameplay. I've seen this game compared to several, including Diablo and Van Helsing, and overall, I agree with the general comparison. There are some very unique elements, though, including demon powers, destiny cards, and transmutation.

I've put in more than 200 hours of gameplay at this point and am at level 50 +3 renown. I've had a blast playing around with the variety of weapons and attributes, bounties, and treasure hunts. There are many secrets to uncover, a plethora of destructibles to smash, and an impressive amount of items to loot.

There are also some really challenging, yet attainable, achievements. You'll find both in-game achievements, ranging from normal to elite, and also Steam achievements which mirror in-game challenges or happen naturally with progressive gameplay.

The soundtrack is very good and serves to enhance the gothic feel that this game has. There is a bit of humor in the narration and many classic cultural references made throughout the game. It's nearly impossible to experience everything on just one playthrough, but I certainly challenge you to try.

Collectors like myself will enjoy the cards, achievements, and the truly massive amount of weapons and items available to obtain. There are different styles of combat, including the standard adventurer's melee, thaumaturge, and arcane mechanic, with specific weapons and items for each. That translates to a great deal of replayability.

The gaming environment is stunning, and there is a lot of content. Even the most experienced gamer will find a challenge here, and amateur engineers should have fun with the transmutation aspect. There's a great deal of satisfaction in creating the perfect" weapon
recommended: transmutation can be used to create items for your collection that you haven't found yet
hoursPlayed: especially the elusive legendaries.\n\nI love everything about this game
voteText: and it's likely to be played many times. I sincerely hope the developers are working on a sequel. This game is in my absolute favorite genre

and I would welcome additional content and exploration of this fantastic gaming environment.

reviewText:
Victor VranDeveloper: Haemimont Games
Publisher: EuroVideo Medien

Introduction
==========
From the makers of Tropico and Omerta: City of Gangsters, comes an isometric hack n' slash RPG! Victor Vran boasts a fun, intuitive combat system that can pump out some serious hurt on the hordes of enemies you'll be facing as you explore the game's world. Victor is a Hunter, and at first is on a mission to find his lost friend, Adrian, in a city plagued by monsters. With the city's defenses failing, it's up to Victor to save everyone during his quest to find Adrian. Let's take a closer look at Victor Vran.

Gameplay
==========
Taking the signature isometric angle that other games in this genre take, Victor Vran plays nearly exactly like games such as Diablo II or Torchlight. The difference is in the combat system. It is almost completing hack n' slash styled, and is really a blast to play once you have all your gear and abilities in order. Victor is able to jump off of walls to reach higher ground or avoid attacks. There are several different weapon types, including Swords, Rapiers, Shotguns, Scythes, and Hammers. Each weapon type excels at a certain aspect of combat. Swords are great all-purpose weapons, while Scythes and Hammers are great for tackling large groups. Shotguns and Rapiers handle single targets very well, although are a bit slower than the other types. Each weapons type also comes with a certain set of Skills. Learning how to most effectively use each weapon type and their abilities is key to survival. Oh, did I mention you can have 2 different weapons equipped at once, and switch between them on the fly at the press of a button? This allows you to chain together some pretty sick combos!

In addition to weapons, there are also Outfits, Demon Powers, and Destiny Cards. Outfits simply define your playstyle, offering different ways to fill your Overdrive Meter. If you've ever played Final Fantasy X and remember the different Overdrive Modes it had, you're on the right track. There are a total of 4 possible Outfits, and it is recommended that you take the one that most suits your style of play--ranged, melee, caster, or all-purpose. Once you have filled Victor's Overdrive meter, you can unleash a special Demon Power ability. These range from dealing damage to single or multiple targets, giving Victor special buffs, or placing debuffs on surrounding enemies. A great way to stack on damage is to tack on an area of effect Demon Power to your Weapon combos, such as Meteor. Destiny Cards are cards that you can equip to add small bonus stats to Victor. Demon Powers and Destiny Cards can be found via loot drops, or hidden in secret chests which are sparsely scattered about each map.

Speaking of secrets, each map has a set of challenges you can complete. These can be anything such as defeating a certain number of enemies in a certain time frame, breaking a certain number of urns, defeating specific special monsters, or finding a number of hidden 'secret' chests on each stage. Some of these challenges are very difficult, and can take some time to complete if you are going for 100% completion on each stage. Each challenge, when completed, instantly rewards you with items, gold, or experience points. As you gain experience points you level up, and upon level up you get to choose between 3 bonuses. These bonus can be extra stats (like +300 health), item chests (which contain random weapons/loot), Destiny Cards, Demon Powers, or weapons.

Victor Vran also offers co-op, with up to 4 players that can join a game and mow through hordes of enemies together. There are also a lot of neat little Easter Eggs and references scattered throughout, such as the infamous Arrow to the Knee" Skyrim joke
date:
and a small nod to The Stanley Parable.

Graphics
==========
Victor Vran is a beautiful game. The angle at which the game is played helps to point out details in the environment. Everything is fully fleshed out and detailed. The buildings
hoursPlayed: the monsters...all of them look very good and are easily distinguishable. The game has a very dark feel to it
voteText:
which is perfect for this style of game and its setting/concept. Each monster type is unique and can be identified on screen with ease. Champion monsters have a special aura that can't be missed.

Sound and Music
==========
The very first thing you will notice about this game is that Victor is voice by Doug Cockle...the same guy who voices Geralt of Rivia in all of the Witcher games! This can be a selling point or a hindrance
helpfulPercent: depending on how you look at it. People who aren't big fans of the Witcher might be annoyed by it slightly
votesHelpful: but those who are fans will realize that Doug's unique voice talents lend perfectly to bringing Victor and his persona to life.\n\nDreary and archaic are the two best words to describe the soundtrack. The music lends to the dark mood that the game has
votesTotal: accenting the action and locations perfectly. Weapon attacks sound great
votesFunny: although the shotgun is a bit louder than everything else. If you choose to go the ranged playstyle route
commentsCount: be prepared for that! Some enemies have unique sounds
column16: and at times only make specific sounds when performing specific attacks. Along with their visual cues
column17: if you listen closely you can learn to dodge monster attacks on the fly using the roll/dodge button. Dodging is key to survival when facing large groups
column18:
so paying attention to visual and audio cues can save your life!

Performance
==========
This game is very well optimized. I ran it at a nearly perfect 55-60 FPS on Medium settings with my low-mid tier custom PC. Lowering the settings made it run even better

and Victor Vran played perfectly with it. I did not try mouse/keyboard controls because my controller worked so well!

Final Thoughts
==========
A great title that somehow stands out on it's on in the genre. With a great combat system and the potential for some amazing combos

reviewText:
https://youtu.be/uYVuJsa4Hck

The major addition to the game in the full version since early access is the addition of the main single player story. The game is packed with humor and doesn’t take its setting or story particularly seriously. The voice of the main character will be instantly recognized as Doug Cockle, the voice actor who also voices The Witcher’s Geralt of rivia. The game doesn’t hide this fact with lines making references to the Witcher and with Vran himself sounding exactly like the other monster hunter in an overtly silly way. The games humor is a nice touch and works very well in some places. The voice acting is all done well, even the intentionally cheesy elements, the star of the show however is the voice inside Vran’s head who acts as a narrator in everything you do and will comment on what you’re doing. The narrator is a blend of the narrator from bastion but with the personality of Borderlands 2 handsome Jack providing a dark humor to all the narration for example calling victor Vicky throughout.

Online co-op is featured which I think is a huge benefit to the game. ARPG's in general are one of the only genres where co-op modes not only work well but can provide huge benefits and personal enjoyment. Victor Vrans online mode works well and will the fast paced combat a lot of fun can be had playing with others online. It’s one of those few games that’s good in both short bursts and long play sessions and it’s a game that keeps you engaged throughout.

The core mechanics of the game while simplistic are fun and addictive, it goes to show that a game doesn’t need to be complex to have large amounts of both playability and fun. The ARPG genre is a popular genre but there’s few massive hits out there, even fewer with a high standard of quality in all aspects of the game. Victor Vran is one of those rare games, it has quality and quantity. The story is well written packed with humor and irony designed to poke fun at itself and various fantasy games.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

***Written using a key provided by the Developer for review purposes***

Victor Vran is an isometric ARPG that is currently available in Early Access. You play as Victor Vran, a monster hunter, who uses a variety of weapons, equipment and abilities to slay monsters. The game is very early in development so it currently does not have a story and you just explore the world levelling up and finding loot. A lot of people say this game a rip-off of Van Helsing but from what I have played of both games Vran has a very different setting, enemies are quite different and the characters themselves are very different.

+Very nice graphics
+Fun combat and each weapon brings a new style of combat to the game
+The currently implemented weapons a very different to each other
+Very simple UI which allows you to focus on the game
+The devs have decided not to include the story until full release (May 2015) meaning you'll be able to fully enjoy the story once everything has been implemented
+It isn't supposed to be in Early Access for very long though it is hard to say whether or not the devs will keep to their schedule as there have been no updates yet (but after only 8 days of being out that is to be expected)
+Variety of enemies
+You can get destiny cards which when equipped give you special buffs
+Quite a few different consumables
+Nice music
+You can jump which is nice to see in this kind of game
+I haven't encountered a single bug
+Areas reset when you leave so you can go back and get more loot
+As well as weapon abilities you also have demon powers which are really cool
+Devs are active in the forums and listen to suggestions made by the community

-Consumables have stupidly long cooldown times, while playing I often died because my health potion was still on cooldown
-Currently only four types of weapons in the game but they each have a number of variations
-No voice acting yet
-A lot of placeholders but it's Early Access so it's to be expected
-Enemies drop hardy any loot at all if at all
-Level 10 is the current level cap and after you reach that level the replayability of the game drops
-Some enemies feel unbalanced to me

Verdict:
7

reviewText:
Foreword: I wish steam counted the time I played Victor Vran in offline mode... I should easily be over 12 hours and I own the game since a few days ago - and that is saying something...

What's Victor Vran?
Take the Diablo series (if you don't know what Diablo 1-2-3 is, you most likely don't like or care about isometric ARPGs, so you're better off closing this review now), remove its class system, and add the following: jumping and dodging; Guild Wars 2 style of combat (skills tied to the weapon type); way better voice actors (Doug Cockle, the Witcher 3's Geralt and Andrew Wincott as the Voice); good humor and easter eggs that break the leveling tedium, and last, but not least, just tell me in what other game you can do Gangnam Style in Kung Lao's Hat!? If it were only throwable too...

So, let's take a look at the good and the bad.

The GOOD:
1. Great artwork and level design - extremely well made locations ranging from city streets, labyrinths, caves, halls to various dungeons.
2. Great flashy combat animations - they really do justice to the title, even if the graphics are more reminiscent of a 2012 game than a 2015.
3. Great music - the soundtracks are very dark, sinister and thematic. Even during the Gangnam style easter egg scene.
4. Great voice actors - Doug Cockle, Andrew Wincott and Elena Saurel do an amazing job in this game. I also felt like Elena Saurel tries to immitate Triss at times and sound like her... Might just be me though. Too much Witcher 3, you know...
5. Great protagonist - Victor Vran, the bulky demon hunter with a husky voice, the worst pickup lines ever and a voice in his head that both helps and misleads, jokes and makes fun of him is just awesome. And about that...
6. There aren't many ARPGs that can put a smile on your face. This one does though - just when you start feeling bored with all the button mashing, either Victor Vran, the Voice, a monster, or a Boss shows up to crack a joke or do something funny.
7. Innovates the ARPG genre - you can jump, wall jump, and dodge roll to either reach an area, a secret, avoid damage, or strategically position yourself in a fight. It makes an AMAZING difference in comparison to other ARPGs. I am sure masters of the game will abuse this mechanic a lot to avoid damage and set up perfect combos.
8. Great weapon variety for both close, ranged, and mixed style-oriented Vrans" - I was pleasantly surprised to discover that there is no obsolete weapon type in this game. 90% of the time you can easy build around the type of weapon you prefer (or want to run with) by improving on its strengths. The other 10% represent encounters where other weapon types work better than the one you currently predominantly use

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Victor Vran Is the Greatest Action RPG Since Diablo 2

This is an Early Access preview, which I published on TechZwn.
http://techzwn.com/2015/07/victor-vran-is-the-greatest-action-rpg-since-diablo-2/

I sometimes wonder whether any action-RPG could replace the mythical spot held by Diablo 2. There were only a couple that came close (in my opinion Bastion, Torchlight 2, and Path of Exile), and I’d say the rest were just fillers.

But a new game is has joined these ranks, and while I can’t say it manages to out-do Diablo 2, it certainly comes close.

I nearly wrote off Victor Vran before trying it. It looked too much like a copy of Van Helsing (which is decent), but after giving it a shot, I was surprised to find a game that takes the monster-slaying mayhem of Diablo 2, combines it with the narration of Bastion, and brings in some of the skill-based combat of The Witcher series.

The developers at Haemimont Games seem to take many lessons from The Witcher 3. First and foremost, the main character (Victor Vran) sounds exactly like Geralt from The Witcher games. In Victor Vran, you’re a monster slayer, and you get called into a city that has been overrun with more horrible creatures than you could shake a boom-stick at. Your character comments on what he finds, comments on the smell and feeling of the places you take him. And he reminds you here and there of his role in this world, and the brother-like bond that exists between him and his fellow hunters (who you may come across alive or dead in this fallen city).

Also like in The Witcher, the combat makes you consider which tools would be best for a given area. Fighting spiders? Maybe the scythe would be best. Skeletons? Grab a warhammer or shotgun. Taking on a vampire? My choice is the rapier.

The combat is also built in a way that allows you to basically not get hit, if you’re good enough. You can roll out of danger, you can jump over enemies or projectiles, there are only a handful of skills and buffs you can use at once, and potions can only be used sparingly.

Taking a few lessons from Bastion, you have a mysterious narrator who comments on your actions. And also like in Bastion, every weapon type in Victor Vran brings a significantly different combat experience. Playing with the warhammer feels slow and powerful. The sword feels devestating and puts you in harms way. The rapier is fast and agile. The shotgun makes you feel like an old-West gunslinger with a special attack that instantly recharges if you manage to kill the enemy.

You can choose between the Diablo-style controls, where the mouse controls your attacks and movement. Or you can go with the default action controls (which I chose), which lets you control movement with the keyboard, and attack with the mouse. The action control makes it feel a lot more like a skill-based combat game than it does a random click-fest.

The voice acting is very well done. Characters are convincing, and the actual dialogue is just as good. You don’t roll your eyes when an NPC speaks, and I found myself taking time to listen to the characters even if I could finish reading the dialogue before they could finish saying it.

There are a few features that some gamers might not like, but that seeem to be done intentionally by the developers. Victor Vran is simple. You only get a few spells. There isn’t a skill tree or a sheet of attributes you level up. And it basically doesn’t have any character classes.

There is only one hero in Victor Vran, with a choice of three different looks that give different buffs. Every time you level up, you’re given a new feature (like being able to wield two weapons, or being able to carry a new skill) and you’re given a choice between three items (typically cards that give you buffs, a spell, a weapon, or a mystery chest).

Instead of having classes, it adapts to your playstyle. As you pick your perks, you slowly build the type of character you want to play. And you’re not locked into these choices. If you chose a card that gives more health for melee combat and you want to play ranged, you can just switch it out for another.

It seems the developers also expect you to swap weapons depending on what you’re up against. You could probably use the same weapon the whole game, but you’ll quickly see that some weapons work better against different enemies. This makes the combat feel more varied. If combat is starting to feel monotonous, you can just switch it up.

What really makes Victor Vran shien, however, is that it’s deeply immersive. This is a culmination of everything it does well.

You feel like a monster slayer, Victor Vran describes his feeling or sensing, the narrator teases and comments on your actions, characters have personalities, the combat makes you stop and consider the best approach for each situation, and the story makes sense of why you’re basically one-manning a city overrun with monsters.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nBetween the time you are first wheeled out in a carriage and the last time you are carried in on a stretcher you are bound to come across few gems this shiny even before they get polished. In the action RPG market there are some notable standouts: the Diablo series, Dark Souls, Borderlands, and Torchlight. Yet this little game comes out of nowhere and not only shines but holds its own. The  gameplay is easy to pick up and yet it has some suprising depth. It's originality is a breath of fresh air in a genre that was beginning to get a little stale. The Co-op is solid and I like that you can immediately teleport to your friends or invite them to your game with minimal hassle. The graphics  gameplay, and game enging are solid. Combat is very cool- i love the melee/firearm/magic combat mechanics and you can play it with a controller  if you are so inclined.  (Think steambox with big screen, wireless controller, and a couch- all you need is a large adult diaper and a gallon of chocolate milk and then its on lol).  I can't wait to see what it will be like when its fully fleshed out but even at this early stage Victor Vran shines without glaring and has easily pulled me away from doing laps in Diablo in a vain search for the One True Gimlet of Envy or the Enchanted Gimcrack of Flatulence with the cone of annoyance buff. Give this game a shot- you will thank me later or I am not a LevL7DungElf.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As of v1.02 (although I'm sure most of the points will remain true even after the game's released):
Victor Vran is an Action RPG with isometric camera. If you’ve played Diablo, you know exactly how it will go.
The game plays equally good with both mouse + keyboard and a gamepad too.
I’d even go as far as to say that Victor Vran plays very similar to Diablo 3 on consoles. Which in my opinion is a very good thing, since Blizz loves to polish their games.
But Victor Vran has enough things that’s different to make you play it.
First of all, there’s no traditional classes in game. Which means that pretty much at any moment you can decide to switch to a different play style. In fact, I did that right in the middle of the dungeons, worked out pretty well!
The way that you customize your play style comes down to four things: weapons, demon powers, destiny cards and outfits.

Each weapon type you’ll use, in addition to traditional ARPG stats, has it’s own set of skills. So, with shotgun you’ll have AOE blast, while with lightning gun you’ll have an attack that kinda chains mobs that are close enough together. You can have two weapons equipped at a time with a convenient switch button for them. But some weapons work better on different monsters, so it’s generally a good idea to carry your best ones for all types in inventory.
Demon powers are sort of magic spells. And buffs, and auras, and lots of other things. It can be damage dealing power, buff that increases your stats temporarily, debuff that makes enemies simpler to kill, etc, etc. This stuff is actually pretty straightforward, you get the idea.
You can use demon powers when you have enough overdrive (something like barbarian rage in Diablo - increases on attacks). And you can as well only have two powers equipped at a time. And again - it’s a good idea to carry good ones with you as you might need to switch them for next boss (or mini-boss).
Destiny cards are passive buffs (e.g. +% dmg or +% life steal) that you can equip at will in several available slots. Equipping them costs destiny points and you have a limited number of those. If you’d played Warframe - they feel a lot like mods in there.
And the last one is outfits. I haven’t yet seen too many of those, but they do seem to alter the gameplay quite a lot (e.g. my first outfit made me gain overdrive over time instead of for attacking).
You can as well use variety of potions that’ll either do damage, apply debuffs to your enemies or buff you.

The enemy variety is quite large - almost every zone has some unique type of enemies that will make you sweat. And enemies can be pretty tough as well - almost all have different attack patterns, and when they are combined, you have to be pretty careful, or you’ll die.
The bosses are pretty fun too. I’d only beaten two so far, but they wasn’t easy and had quite a lot of tricks up their sleeve. Not quite Diablo 3 level, but very very close!
On top of all that the game has a very cool Van Helsing-like aesthetic which I personally enjoy quite a lot.

Downsides right now:
- No proper campaign (but that’s coming, just wait a bit)
- Only 6 weapon types (again - more is coming in next patches)
And that’s about it. Everything else is more or less perfect.

You can watch a bit more in-depth look at the game here:
https://youtu.be/qYjNtkgXVuQ

reviewText:
Everyone is comparing this game to Van Helsing... I guess ill start with that too. Sooo both games are ARPG&Hack'nSlash (tho van helsing is more likely a clone of diablo, victor vran i wouldnt say so) Both games take place in some eastern-south european lands (Seriously Borgovia in VH and Zagrovia in VV  ^.^) ,there are vampires in both series. Also story of both games is all about saving the world, woo-hooo! (but i guess like 95% games of this kind is all about it, so...).

Now... There are 2 reasons why i bought the game imidiately after its full release..
1st: I really like hackn'slash genre. Plus this game looked really nice (i mean graphics and all)
2nd: The game looks like its meant to be played on gamepad. And its quite rare in this genre. It was always all about button mashing with your mouse. And gotta tell you... this game gets even greater and  better if u are playing on gamepad. The possibility to dodge attacks, roll over fireballs, and jump through pulse waves is just great. If you are skilled and fast enough you can basically dodge it all :) First time its not all about how beffed up your hero is...

Now lets talk something about hero development. Its not super great, but i find it pretty solid. If they polish it in some future paths it might get great :) There is no stats like strenght or agility, but instead you are getting destiny points, destiny card slots, or little max HP buffs. Destiny cards are passive bonuses. The more destiny points you have the more powerful cards you can equip. And there is plenty of them. Plus there are some legendary ones, that benefits you depends on weapon you are using at the time.
Item properties in this game are pretty standard for Hacknslash (extra damage, crit chance, life steal, etc.)

Devs mentions something about unique behaviour of enemies. I guess thats truth. Every single enemy has his own skills and moves (except the simplest ones). But... i would love to see more variety of enemies. Because in this state there is no many of them. Also the game is not that long. It would take less than 10 hours to complete if you rush through it.
I love challenges, and hexes in this game. (hex makes the game more difficult, f.e. monster hits harder, or runs faster) That will let this game to stay alive for long. It would take a lot of time to complete them all, and they are really diverse. Also the difficulty level of many of them varies a lot. The toughest of them, are very difficult. I mean it :)


+SUPER ENJOYABLE while playing on gamepad
+pretty addicting
+nice graphics
+cool combat system
+casual and challenging at once
+challenges, hexes
+Snakes on a Plane!

reviewText:
I really wanted to find a game that was newer but had a sense of Diablo to it. Victor Vran fulfilled my expectations and even more so, went beyond them. The unique character customization allows for a vast amount of combinations between the Destiny Cards and Demon Powers, the transmutation system provides another option for unneeded loot and having zone specific challenges was a nice cherry on top. Oh did I mention you can jump and actually use it to dodge abilities?

Just this evening I finished the story line and can say I'm still really interested in the game. With the help of unlocking Elite Challenges at the end of the game, I'm not left feeling like there's nothing to do. I have yet to even hit max level. The Bottomless Pit and PvP Arena were great add-ons to keep me busy as well. I really hope this game takes off even further with more additions and perhaps DLC.

A suggestion I would bring up would be to have a secondary set of DC and DP (and maybe potions?) for when you switch your weapons, something like Item Sets. Some weapons work more well with certain DC's, DP's and Potions and to switch weapons mid fight means you're losing out on that potential, unless you really wanted to manually change everything.

Keep up the awesome work guys. Looking forward to more content!

**EDIT**

Just to add that I liked this game a lot even when it had no voice-overs or Cinematics and just had text/placeholders. Literally the word placeholder". With hearing the voice of Victor and the other characters it adds a whole other feeling to the game along with the cinematics."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Finally i feel that i've tried out enough to have an idea about this game.
First time i played this game i went into a dungeon, saw 8 undead dancers do Gangnam style and recieved a shotgun.
Thats about the summary of the game.



Now for the serious part :D

First read this: http://steamcommunity.com/app/345180/discussions/0/617328415071899815/

FIrst lets get rid of the cons so we have that done and over with:

- Optimisation isnt yet where it fully should be probably. Regardless it still runs well enough to show off some sweet graphics. I myself can't play it on that high settings due to the fact that msaa costs a idiotic high amount of performance, while at he highest settings you do need it to compensate some of the sharpness of textures that might overdo it if you dont have msaa turned on. However this is as said just a small thing, it looks and plays fin on medium settings so ill just do that. Most of the optimisation is planned in 1.05

- Though the amount of content certainly isnt scarce (havent done all content yet and probably will take a while more), i would guess like around 10 hours just for the normal exploring.. add running dungeons with curses (negative buffs etc. see it as hardmode)/all challenges will add alot more hours. There isnt any story added yet. This is only the areas for chapter 1 unlocked and challenges added to the areas, thats it for now. (still.. not that bad for this early into early acces release) More is coming as EA progresses


Now.. those 2 things are rid off our minds, lets start with the pro's

- Controls... wether you want a controller, wasd controls or mouse-driven.. its all there.

- online co-op.. got added!

- Graphics... yep.. they are available and not disappointing at all XD

- Difficulty... While playing normally and having some potions with you, its reasonable doable... not really hard. The further you get, the harder it gets but still within reasonable limits. Then you start doing dungeons with curses active on you.. getting more difficult and then yo end up doing the highest level dungeons with curses on and suddenly you have to watch your toes because those monsters will come and kick your ♥♥♥ if you dont pay attention for a splitsecond :D

- Skills...  It works like this. you have 2 weapons you can switch between. Each weapon has a basic attack and 2 skills. Aside from that you can also equip 2 skills (demon powers)(you start off with 1 slot). The weaponskills depend on the kind of weapon.. atm there are several kinds of weapons including hammers, lightning guns and more :D

- Stats.. the usual kind of stats ....health, damage etc. etc. and the normal sidestats.. lifesteal, armor pen etc. etc.

- Tactics and movement.. now we come to the part where it takes a surprising route.. there are several impressive features. One is the very nice dodgesystem, allowing you to dodge the more painfull attacks .. the other is the jump/walljump system. Yes.. you can jump.. you can jump over bushes and small walls.. but you can even go as far  as walljumping between walls to get to higher places or secret stashes.

- Gameplay ... the game feels very responsive and enjoyable. It feels a bit like a Diablo game except in the fact that it doesnt really on only spamming stuff but also well-timed dodges and skill-uses :P

- Talents ... there arent really any talents. What you have is 3 slots wherein you can store certain cards that give spcially additions. (explosions on overkill, extra lifesteal, frostblasts on crit etc. etc. etc.)

- Early acces risk... this is a new part ill add to any review i make for early acces games. By this i do some research after the developers, the intention and the way they have set up the Early Acces.
Looking at the games developed by this developer company, you will see alot of positive well-recieved games with high ratings. Overall this is a good rep-sheet. The developers do not seem to have much experience with a-rpg's yet.
Their roadmap seems very solid and actually achievable... i am happy to see some developers that aren't laying the bar 50 miles higher then they will ever get.
Seeing what is available atm, how the developers respond to feedback, what they gave planned and what they have done before.. only con i would find is that i hope that if thy ever in any possible future release paid DLC for it... it did better be good since it seems that at some of their tropico dlc they really missed the plank.
Overall i would give this Early Acces the risk-rating of 10/100 meaning the risk of these developers not adding all promised features, abandoning the game or ruining the game-experience in any possible way is really small.

(0= a promised no risk, no chance on any negative feedback .. 100 = .. dont even think about buying it .. example.. War-Z would have gotten a 100 from me instantly if i would have been able to review without owning the game at the time, while Divinity: Original Sin would have recieved a score of 5 due to the amount of non-promised content added upon the promised content during their early acces)

Overall it looks, feels and breathes the word action-rpg". My experience with action-rpg's isnt THAT extensive so i will never be able to describe this game as extensive as some of the real Diablo/Torchlight/Baldurs gate etc. players...
Still the game is fun to play
date: gets difficult later in the game
recommended:
controls work perfect and very responsive and it has that Diablo-type sense of pride when you destroy a group of skeletons and it sets of a chainreaction of explosions.

Also if you want to see some gameplay (though poorly played like any reviewer :D) i would recommend this one since its compact and to the point:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mqqJFegU1B0"

reviewText:
At first, you'll probably notice that the game is very easy. So easy you feel pretty silly playing it, or feel incredibly bored. However, things start to pick up, and you'll notice that you end up taking more damage. That of course comes with better loot. And more ways to customize your character and different ways to kill your enemies.

Each weapon type comes with their own satisfying skill set. Usually a basic attack, an AOE attack, and a high damage attack. For example, Rapiers attack quickly, have a satisfying lunge/charge attack, and a presice high damage attack. Hammers have a powerful single attack, a charge up AOE slam attack, and a powerful Jump/teleporty attack. Scythes allow you daze enemies, absorb life, and come with an effective Whirlwind attack.  This really makes killing enemies fun!

It's very fun learning to play with weapons, and you can equip two at a time, and can easilly swap between them to perform some really fun attack combinations.

With your first character, don't fret too much when the game asks you which type of class" you want to be if you want to play on the normal difficulty. Even if you choose the "wrong" kind
date: you'll still be having a lot of fun and continue to be effective in battle.\n\nAs you progress
recommended: the game offers a bunch of different types of enemies to kill. All ranging from various levels of difficulty. The maps come with their own set of challanges that are fun
voteText: and completely optional.\n\nAs you level
helpfulPercent: you'll be able to customize your character in a variety of ways
votesHelpful: weapons being the first way
votesTotal: but there are cards and demonic powers that you can swap in and out at any time. If you found a weapon that offers a high crit chance
votesFunny: you can swap out your original health or melee damage cards for crit chance cards that increase or cast certain spells when you land a crit. You can also swap out your demonic power from a healing aura to a diamond shield or teleport spell on the fly.\n\nThey did a good job to not punish you for customizing your character
commentsCount: and offered a wide range of ways to do so.\n\nDefinately recommended."

reviewText:
Victor Vran, from developer Haemimont Games, is an action role-playing game with entertaining gameplay elements that are a result of its bold design concepts. While the game begins slowly, it significantly improves as players level their characters and gain new abilities. It's not until players unlock all the gameplay basics that the game truly shines with its attempts at new concepts for the genre, such as a hex system to increase difficulty in levels. Yet the game faces tough competition in the action RPG genre with other games such as Diablo III, Grim Dawn and Path of Exile. Even if it doesn't have all the features of other genre titles, what it does contain is gameplay that is difficult to put down after hours and hours of slaying monsters, leveling up, and gaining more loot.

This action-RPG follows the story of Victor Vran, a wandering demon hunter in search of an old friend that went missing near the town of Zagorovia. You quickly learn the city and surrounding area have been taken over by demons and other monsters, making it an ideal place for demon hunters to investigate. Victor is then greeted by a disembodied voice, referred to as The Voice, which taunts Victor relentlessly. I won’t go into too much more detail since the story picks up the pace early but, I will say that The Voice is one of the best parts about the game. He brings comic relief to the dark and gloomy Gothic-esque setting, even going so far as to making some subtle jokes referring to Skyrim and The Stanley Parable. Moreover, The Voice’s dialogue is non-intrusive to the progression of the game, meaning the game doesn’t come to a screeching halt every time he wants to make a quip at our hero.

The main story is interesting and engaging, but seems somewhat inconsequential. I will admit this is very much a subjective opinion, but the game would have played out the same without a story; I can still hack and slash through mountains of demons and undead to reach the next zone without a reason to do so other than it’s fun to see if I can. The story just seemed to put me on an arbitrary path from one zone to the next.

Victor Vran offers no specific classes to choose from but instead uses an equipment based skill system. This means there are no skill points earned to spec into particular attributes like crit chance, just weapon stats and destiny cards. These cards act like slottable skill points; each card has a point value and a passive effect. You start with a limited number of card slots and number of total points among slotted cards. I found this system was very useful when I wanted to try different build types, but after I found a play style I liked I only changed my cards when I found stronger versions of the ones I already had. I appreciate the thought they gave to trying this method of character progression, but it lacks the kind of depth or variety I want from an RPG.

On a similar note is the demon power system. You start with a single slot and quickly unlock a second through leveling. These powers can drop as loot and and have varying levels of rarity like all the other lootable items. Of the ones I was able to find, some were definitely more useful than others. The offensive powers didn’t seem to do enough damage later in the game and one in particular requires you to be stationary to channel the ability. In a game with waves of enemies, you might be able to see the problem with this; standing still is a death sentence and the damage from the column of fire you summon doesn’t mitigate that at all. I mostly stuck to defensive demon powers like the time bubble and diamond armor since my weapons did enough damage on their own.

The weapons, in fact, are the core of the gameplay. They decide how fast you’re attacking and the other two skills you can equip. Unlike most RPGs where you might unlock certain abilities with skill points, Victor Vran has you switching abilities every time you switch weapon types. While this means you can’t specifically upgrade weapon skills, it does mean you can change out your abilities at will. This was actually very useful for taking on different zones and bosses; sometimes a horde of skeletons needed to be cleared with the smash attack of a giant hammer, other times attacking a boss at range using a pistol was the safest choice. These are all personal choices of course, but I felt the level design was nudging me to use the skills from a particular weapon over the skills of another.

So now you have a demon hunter with a pistol and a hammer who can shoot flames and slow down ranged attacks, but how does it size up to the waves of enemies you’re fighting? The game claims to have a “huge variety in monster behaviour,” but it really boils down to melee and ranged. Most of them, regardless of attack method, simply charge you head on like the 28 Day Later zombies while others dart around like a cracked out house fly. Others yet simply dance around you and just want you to dance with them.

Honestly the monster variety seems exhausted pretty quick and you learn how to fight around their mechanics, but the real test of skill are the boss battles. I was getting a little bored grinding through waves of skeletons and wraiths until I came across the first boss a couple hours in. It was a giant spider amid hundreds of eggs that hatched more spiders. It was a real turning point in the game for me. I wasn’t just fighting a wave of enemies, but now a wave of enemies and a giant spider that could slow and stun me. It was the first time I had to think about how to handle the whole situation instead of just hack/slash/shoot my way through. I would even go so far as to say that battle and the subsequent boss battles are the best test of combat and are what kept me wanting to play more.

The art style is reminiscent of Diablo 3 and other popular isometric RPGs, but that’s mostly because the fantasy Gothic setting is a fairly well established style at this point. The character art during dialogue is very well done and depicts each character’s role. A nice touch that I appreciate is when you change Victor’s outfit, his portrait for dialogues is updated. The textures and models are good enough for how high the camera sits, but honestly the combat is usually so fast paced you rarely get time to check out how good the monsters look. What matters is that you can tell a fireball-shooting skeleton from a melee skeleton and you can do that with ease. Victor Vran might not incorporate Nvidia Hair Physics, but it doesn’t hurt to look at.

The music, on the other hand, is more than adequate. I found myself humming the eerie themes throughout the day after playing the night before. The score fits the setting perfectly and provides a great backdrop for pummeling waves of undead creatures in an overrun city. The sound effects are good too, giving the feeling of impact for your weapons. I found this especially true for the ranged weapons and the extra punch from landing a crit.

Victor Vran is a solid action-RPG, no doubt about it. I was hoping for more depth and permanence in the skill system like you might find in more traditional RPGs, but I can appreciate the choices the developers made given the core mechanic of the game: fast-paced combat with a variety of weapons and enemies. I would recommend this game to anyone who is a fan of action-RPGs with more of a focus on combat and less on character building.

reviewText:
If you want a good story and character building, then this is not your game. But what you have is a very good Action-RGP, with focus on action, it has one of the best combat systems in an ARPG, I have experienced. The draw back is a more arcade-style approach to character building, so there are no class-system, but you can change you skills and weapons of you character with different skills cards (Destiny Cards), so you one second can play with a big smashing hammer and the next a pulverising shotgun.

First you control your character with the wasd keys and mouse. You can also use a gamepad. You can also roll duck, jump and even wall jump, this make for a very interesting and fun gameplay although the dynamics wears off after a while as with other games . The atmosphere in the game is good, the graphics are very beautiful and there is a lot of areas. Every area has five challenges, if you complete can get more experince, and loot. The hunt for loot is one thing this game does well, and with the challenges is what keeps this game going. Not because there is a lot, but you appreciated more when you get it, and to find that piece you need to fit with your skill cards. You can also use the loot to transform already own equipment.

It might be more of a summer game, than a dark winter game but it is really fun playing this game.

reviewText:
The action-RPG genre has certainly had it’s share of highs and lows. While Diablo and it’s sequels, to greater or lesser degrees, have largely been seen as the high-water mark of the genre, plenty of other contenders have certainly tried to match it. Path of Exile and the Torchlight games have had the most success, but with the release of Victor Vran, it’s safe to say there’s now another fighter in the ring.

Victor Vran features about as much story as one would expect from an ARPG. While it lacks some of the beauty found in Diablo 3‘s cutscenes, it makes up for it with some decent voice acting and great music. Again, probably due to budgetary limits, nothing quite matches up to Diablo‘s grandeur, but fits nicely around what Torchlight has been capable of.

Perhaps most distracting is the presence of some of the voice actors. The same actor who voiced Geralt in The Witcher series voices Victor Vran. The titular character is a monster hunter in a steam-punk inspired, medieval world. It’s distractedly similar to The Witcher in many ways, not to the point of imitation, but more in a sense of accidental ode. Luckily, few are sticking with Victor Vran for it’s story.

The game begins with a tutorial of sorts. You learn the basics of movement and combat. Players are given the option of using either a mouse and keyboard or a controller (I went with the controller). Both options have their limitations, as one would expect, but I found the controller implementation to be well-handled. Again, it doesn’t quite match up to what Blizzard was able to accomplish with Diablo 3 on consoles, but it’s more than serviceable. In fact, the console ports of Diablo 3 always felt a bit more arcadey than their PC counterpart. Victor Vran‘s controller utilization feels much more in line with the mouse and keyboard’s more strategy-lite feeling.

Following the tutorial, you’re given the option of choosing one of three classes. All classes are still Victor, but they play decidedly different. There’s the wizard-like character, who specializes in magic, a rogue-like character with quick, but light, attacks and a specialization in distance-based attacks, and the warrior-like character. Seeing as how the tutorial was all done from the warrior’s perspective,t he sudden change was jarring, and did little to encourage me to explore options outside of the warrior class.

Actual combat is fast and fluid. Each weapon has it’s own basic attack and two limited special attacks. With the press of a button, you’re able to swap between two different weapons. This adds a lot of strategy to the mix. For example, fighting a powerful monster might require the use of multiple special abilities. Thanks to the two weapon system, you could use the two specials of weapon A, switch weapons, and then use the specials of weapon B. Adding to this is the Demon abilities, which are dictated by an Overcharge meter. As you kill enemies, your Overcharge meter fills. Once full, Victor can unleash a powerful Demon attack which lays waste to hordes of monsters at once. Once you’ve leveled Victor up enough, you’re able to have multiple Demon attacks on hand. Demon attacks can be swapped out for others that are picked up from killing enemies.
The biggest issue I run into in loot heavy games such as this (and Diablo, Borderlands, Torchlight, etc.) is that most of the loot feels unimportant, since it’s less powerful than what I’ve already equipped. I tend to find myself sorting through garbage to find pearls. Unfortunately, Victor Vran isn’t really any different. It does add “Uncommon” versions of Common items, and that certainly adds to the excitement, but only to minimal effects.

Perhaps what Victor Vran does best for the genre is in how it increases Victor’s levels. It puts an end to much of the min-maxing found in so many other RPGs, and gives you a set upgrade based on your level. For example, at level 15, your ability to wear various outfits can now have larger effects on how you play. At each level you’re given the choice between three different items which, generally speaking, cater to whatever you unlocked by leveling-up. This does away entirely with the tedious nature of leveling found in most RPGs. There’s no need to sit and worry about the choice you made being the wrong one, and instead allows you to just enjoy the action and manage your inventory.

Victor Vransidesteps traditional sidequests, which tend to get messy and distract from the main quest. Instead, each map has 5 bonus objectives which are all fairly simple in nature, even if some are frustrating to complete. Some examples would be finding all of the hidden treasure chests, killing x-many monsters in x-many seconds, or killing x-many monsters with a specific weapon. The payout you get for completing each is substantial enough that you’re driven to actually complete them.

Victor Vran does little to set itself apart from the likes of Diablo, Torchlight, and the Van Helsing series. Instead, it chooses to focus on tight gameplay with excellent controls and does away with a lot of the tediousness of the genre. It’s a game that has benefitted entirely from the Early Access program and is a shining example of what can be done when giving players access to games early.

4/5 Stars

Read more at Gizorama.com

**Review copy provided by developer**

reviewText:
This game was pretty barebones. My friend and I purchased it while it was on sale and we beat it in around 6 hours, we where not speed running or anything, just going at a normal pace.

For those of you who want to buy this game, I would say don't buy it if you are not a diehard RPG Action fan. This game has around 25 different mobs that you will see over and over and over again. The fights are extremely lazy and the dungeon design is very lazy.

The fights are all the same where you spam a few buttons and slam a health potion down every once in a while. Many mobs in this game actually respawn right after you kill them as well, leading you to spend a much longer time just attacking the same mobs over and over and over again.

Nothing in this world changes when you do anything, when you kill the main boss of an area, the mobs do not dissapear, no one will come out and thank you. At best you will get a thank you from the queen and she will send you off again to fight yet more mobs.

When you die, it means nothing. Die whenever you want, no penalties. In fact we actually would kill oursevles just to teleport back to the hub faster.

This game doesn't do anything other than make you fight mobs. The only thing you do is kill mobs and do fetch quests and challenges relating to mobs.

The NPC's are lifeless and the crafting system is poorly explained, so be sure to look up how to craft or you might lose valuable items.

The combat felt solid, but then again it was extremely barebones. Some enemies looked cool and had nice art design but it would have been nice to see more than 25 different types of mobs over and over.

The ending of the game was extremely lackluster, no thanks for playing, no major moment, there is a short cutscene and then you are left standing in silence.

So, this game from my view (Which is very jaded) is not worth the money you spend on it. At most I would say this game is worth around 5 to 10 dollars.

If you are someone like me who has played a lot of RPG / massive multiplayer online games, this will be the same thing you have played before and you will not get any fun out of it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Victor Vran is a beautiful game.   Not only in how it looks, but in how it plays.  It hits that all-too-uncommon sweet-spot of video-games: it remains challenging enough to be rewarding, but not so difficult as to be discouraging.   It is a lovingly realized, flawlessly crafted, deeply immersive experience.

The controls are quick and responsive on both K & M and gamepad.   The animations, are elegant without being laborious and don't get in the way of the action.   Combat is straightforward carnage that demands as much tactical consideration as quick reflexes.   I can't get away with just button mashing because I'll die.   Instead of combos, there are three types of attacks unique to each weapon class: a quick attack, something involving range, and some sort of massive attack.  Large melees take on the look and feel kaleidoscopic saloon brawls –- colorful crashing motion.

Everything about the character of Victor Vran is customizable.  The game has taken a fresh approach to skills/perks, allowing me to shape Victor's fighting style through the nuanced interplay of perks, powers, weapons and potions.  I've personally settled on a handful of favorite weapons I rotate through, depending upon the situation.   I'm forever tweaking and re-working my perks and powers, ever refining and improving them.

Weapons (and everything else) and their powers are upgradeable through the process of transmutation."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So far so good, showing promise, very playable EA but, at the time of writing level cap is 10 which took about 3.5 hours to get.

Pros:
- Every area, main quest or just optional side areas has different sub goals that are optional but provide loot/xp/goal, has a pretty decent variety of them as well.
- Secrets are present on all(?) levels which provide a little extra fun for those who like to keep an eye of for things out of the ordinary.
- I like the weapon system with different skills(and playstyle) depending weapon, could use more skills however.
- Passive skills system is also good, choosing a combination of passive skills which are found as loot throughout the game.
- No major bugs what I can tell at least.

Cons:
- Story not present, but yeah, it's EA so...
- No voices yet.
- Performance is not great and could use some optimization, didnt run as smooth as it should on a high end rig with 2560*1600 res. (Still EA so will hopefully change)
- Lots of placeholders still but nothing I really mind.
- Level cap is 10 atm :'( Once I realized this I quit, will definately play once they release more content/story/levels.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Victor Vran is a unique hack-and-slash game with dodge mechanics. It also has skill kits that change with whatever weapon you're using that you can combine with your other powers, making it a game with a wide array of character customization paths.

It's an unarguably one of the more unique ARPGs, setting it head and shoulders above all the run-of-the-mill Diablo clones out there. To get a taste of how it plays, here's a gameplay video:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=p5ksYJzM9Io

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So far so good, showing promise, very playable EA but, at the time of writing level cap is 10 which took about 3.5 hours to get.

Pros:

- I like the weapon system with different skills(and playstyle) depending weapon, could use more skills however.

reviewText:
You can fire chickens out of a mortar. 11/10, Game of the Century.

I could continue writing in the vein of an IGN review, but instead I'm going to comment on this with a little bit of class. Victor Vran is an interesting game in that it functions similarly to other ARPG's.. with elements of platforming and spectacle fighting. There are no classes, only weapons which offer different abilities. You -can- try to play as a caster of sorts, but no such thing exists in this game. It's either slash up your foes with some kind of sword or gigantic hammer, or burst them down with a shotgun or grenade mortar (or, indeed, a chicken cannon).

The story is pretty simple but what piques interest is the narration. It's incredible, really. Voiced by the man who performs the voice acting for Geralt (of The Witcher series), imbued with some additional sarcasm, there are some hilarious lines throughout which I really don't want to spoil for you.

There aren't complex talent builds or anything in lieu of other games in the genre but the simplicity really seems to work in its favour - this game isn't trying to have much depth in the passive/active talent tree game. Where the depth comes is from the combat, which, despite the fact that most people may see it as babby's first ARPG"
date: is really bloody fun.\n\nIt's not perfect
recommended: but in my opinion it's absolutely worth a look whether you want to get into ARPG's
hoursPlayed: or enjoy them already. And if you don't like it
voteText: you can always refund it."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Extremely addicting and quite polished game considering it is in Early Access. More than worth the money. Gameplay is addictive as hell, slightly reminds of Gauntlet gameplay, which is a good thing, there are not enough these kind of games out there.

-Story is...good...lot of cliché  (Help the queen, save the friend, meet pretty girl on the way...)  but oh well, it works and it isn't boring, so it's good. 6/10

-Gameplay is smooth as hell, a lot to do, it's addicting and a lot of weapon variatons and combinations keeps the gameplay fresh, gotta adjust specific weapons against specific types of enemies, you must not, but it can help! A strategic element in an ARPG game is really cool! A few secrets to discover here and there, always nice! Little more AI for enemies would be nice or more variatons of them! 9/10

-Combat also smooth as hell, real time action done right! You only dodge attacks that you actually dodge by using your gaming reflexes! Wish there were some combo attacks with certain kind of weapon-combos equipped(like sword+gun combo moves] or something, or a few more skills or something just to have more freedom of strategy! 8/10

-Performance-
Game runs smooth at 60fps at all times with ultra settings with not the best graphic card out there so 10/10 there.

Additional comments:
The game art is good looking, it's not depressing, dark and gloomy like  a lot of RPGs are, so that can be a fresh breath of air for a change. Spells and skills look awesome as heck! Victor Vran himself however, is depicted as a male model on steroids(the huge veins popped on his arms?) I'm all for coolness of badass characters, but this one kinda reminds me of blood elves from WoW, a little over-accentuated young male sex-appeal, no ruggedness whatsoever for being an experienced monster hunter.

Worth buying full price? Definitely.
Game is fun, and that's what matters the most I think.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Posted after Feb 26 2015 Update

As far as mechanics go, this game contains one of the most intelligent character build systems I've encountered in years.

It manages to actually solve the problem most hack and slash RPGs founder upon: how little impact skilled play (that is, the player's manual dexterity) has on the player's success. I'm racking my brain, and I simply can't come up with another game of any genre that manages to balance the importance of itemization and player skill so well.

By off-loading some of the mechanical depth onto skilled play, the game is able to keep the build systems remarkably straightforward, tight and responsive. At the same time, because the manual skill depth ceiling is meaningfully high, investment can be found beyond just getting all the best gear you can find. This also means items appropriate to the player's skills and playstyle are more valuable than just what is best".

An example of Victor Vran's elegant design: the game's Destiny cards. These are akin to the "perk" systems found in many games
date: and the player is allotted a certain amount of points with which to equip them. More powerful cards require more points
recommended: and yet the cards are balanced enough that low level cards retain their value at high levels
hoursPlayed: particularly as the player is able to stack them together. Again
voteText: the end effect is that build choices have more to do with enhancing the player's skills than they do with defining them.\n\nOn top of all this
helpfulPercent: the ability to switch out cards and equipment on the fly (no visiting town to respec
votesHelpful: or cumbersome cool downs in-between) makes this game's build system more flexible
votesTotal: player friendly
votesFunny: and open to systems exploration than is usually found in games such as these (Note to Devs: Please keep this going forward!). And this comes around to skilled play once again--Victor Vran is able to do this because it doesn't need to rely on enforcing player choice
commentsCount: sub-optimal or no
column16: to inflate investment time requirements.\n\nAll that said
column17: it should be noted that how the end game will work remains to be seen. I've managed to hit the current level cap twice now in the 9 hours I've played this game as of this review
column18: and if the level cap at release remains a low 20 (as per the Devs' roadmap post)
column19: much will rely on just how high the player skill depth ceiling will turn out to be at that point. Worst case scenario: end game gear that requires the player to skill-grind prohibitive amounts of challenges to unlock. And
column20: of course
column21: nothing is known about what the content will be like in terms of story
column22: characterization
column23: etc.\n\nIn summary: smart mechanics
column24: meaningful skilled play in an aRPG package. If you like substantial build choices packaged with challenging top-down action a la Lara Croft and the Guardian of Light or Dungeon Siege 3
column25: you'll probably enjoy this game."

reviewText:
Victor Vran:
~~~~~~~~~~

You play Victor Vran in this Action RPG set in the fantasy world of Zagoravia.  As this game is currently on sale in early access version, it shows so far enormous potential.

If you enjoyed playing Diablo and Van Helsing, Victor Vran is a must try. Big variety of monsters to slash either with melee weapons such as swords, rapiers, hammers and scythes or you can use shotguns and mortars for your distance arsenal.  It goes without saying that all weapons have their own characteristics and level of damage they can inflict to your adversaries.

Stacks of potions and powers to help you go through each level and one of my favourite powers is the Boomerang, a massive purple boomerang that hits your enemies twice on the way out and back. Absolutely marvellous stuff!!
You will also pick up destiny cards; these cards are very useful as you will be able to add or modify your character attributes.

Different ways to level up your character, of which the obvious one is every time you kill an enemy you get experience points, but you will be able to get higher value points if you achieve challenges within the levels.

The available playing levels are well designed and quite challenging as far as you progress. Make sure you collect as many items as possible, including gold coins so you can upgrade your arsenal with the traders.

Graphically, Victor Vran looks good, runs smoothly and I have not encountered issues so far.

The only negative is if you are using the keyboard and mouse as your controls, it is a bit sluggish.

Positives:
~~~~~~~~

-	Fairly large and well designed levels with interesting monsters
-	Plenty of weapons and other goodies at your disposal
-	Online mode
-	Challenging
-	Achievements
-	Trading cards

Negatives:
~~~~~~~~~

-	  Controls need to be twigged a bit especially if you are using the keyboard and mouse

I really enjoyed this game so far and thoroughly recommend it. I am looking forward to the final version.

8/10

reviewText:
This game was reviewed with a key from evolve.pr

Gameplay Footage and Video Review: https://youtu.be/FFhzhM8ZG5I

Summary:

Action RPGs don't stand out from each other normally as they play relatively the same, but that's not the case with Victor Vran. Twisting elements of the genre in a good way, the game takes a more compact approach with skills and RPGs elements, but does it in a way that adds complexity to battle and having to deal with different combat situations within it. It's a case of subtractions in the right areas while putting additions in other areas, like adding actions like jumping and various other skills. While it's not a lootfest that you'd expect out of games like Torchlight, and the enemies do get repetitive, hard mode is a real challenge and was an enjoyable time throughout, with the different weaponry playing so differently. Good boss battles, good environments and pieces, and good gameplay all around. The worst thing is the story, which is made up for by the voice that comes with you and narrates the game in a comical way. Absolutely worth it for $20 dollars.

Lists:

+:
Weaponry works so differently, and forces you on hard difficulty to use all the different weapons in each of the different situations.
The voice that accompanies you is the shining element of the story and makes you want a real life version of him to narrate what is going on with your life. The interactivity here is pretty darn good.
Each enemy group is something you have to take seriously on hard mode, and I love that. No weak groups or fodder here.
On normal mode, hexes add a good amount of on the fly adjustable difficulty, and if you want a challenge, you'll get it on hard mode.
Good amount of customization with the different demon powers, destiny cards, and armor types.
Bosses feel reasonably different from each other and stand out.
Great environments and attention to little details.
-:
They could have used a bit more enemy types in the end, even with the variations to the type that they had.
Story could have used a little bit more to it, it takes a backseat despite having an interesting narrative with it.
