reviewText:
The Circle of Loot

Baldur's gate, Diablo, Torchlight, you know where you stand with a good action RPG.

You build your character, enter the  game world and hack and slash your way through hordes of monsters on a quest for lovely loot, loot which will make you more powerful, so you can take down more bad guys and get even more lovely loot.

It's a tried and tested format, it works and for the most part Victor Vran sticks to the staples of the genre, but is does bring a few interesting idea's of its own to the table.


Victor of Rivia

When you dive into Victor Vran the first thing you'll notice is the voice of Victor himself.
You're going to recognise it, at least you will if you've played the Witcher games recently.

Every ones favourite white haired witcher is voiced by an actor called Doug Cockle, Doug has now bought his talents to bear by giving voice to Victor Vran.
Which is great, he's a talented guy, but I did struggle with it a little, if only because Victor Vran is the first game I've sank a decent amount of time into following completion of The Witcher 3.

The problem I had was that every time Victor opened his mouth I heard the Witcher speaking which had the undesired effect of distracting me from Victors world and reminding me of Geralts.
It's only a little thing but when the small voice in your head keeps asking What's Geralt doing here?" it can't help but break the immersion a little.


Padding around Zagoravia

The next thing you'll probably think is:
"Hey
date:
there's no camera zoom" closely followed by "These controls are weird"
Both of which are true.

The first thing I tried to do in game was zoom the camera out by scrolling the mouse wheel
recommended: but instead of the camera moving as I'd expected
voteText:
which of course led to the second thought "These controls are weird".

Well the default mouse controls are weird anyway.
This is easily fixed in the game options but I'd strongly recommend playing with a controller if you have one. It makes a world of difference to the feel of the game.

Unfortunately the inflexible camera is not so easily fixed.
The ability to pan the camera up and down as well as zoom in and out would have made navigating the world Haemimont Games have created a much simpler task.


Victor Vran Helsing

You'll be playing as the self titled Victor Vran
helpfulPercent: he looks a lot like Van Helsing doesn't he?\nAnyway...\nVictor is demon hunter
votesHelpful: he's not a mage
votesTotal: not a paladin or a priest
votesFunny: he's not even a vampire slayer
commentsCount: he's a demon hunter.\nThere's no class selection here
column16: Geralt was a Witcher
column17: Mario was a Plumber
column18: Victor is a Demon Hunter
column19: that's just who he is.\n\nHaving said that
column20: this game does still have an element of class customisation
column21:
it's just more subtle than you'll  probably be used to from other ARPG's you've played.


The Clothes Make The Man

You will
column22: quite literally start tailoring your character from the very beginning of the game.\nAfter you've finished the brief tutorial by way of rotating the camera and squishing a few spiders you'll be given a choice of three outfits
column23:
each one will slightly change the way your character generates "overdrive".

What's overdrive?
That's your "Mana"
column24: the resource you use when you're spell casting or rather "using your demonic powers"
column25: but we'll talk about that later.\n\nSo you'll be given the option of three outfits
column27:
Cavalier or Vigilante.

The Hunter outfit generates overdrive when you're damaged.  (This is the balanced play option).

Vigilante focuses on armour and only grants overdrive when you land a critical hit (this is your "warrior" focused play style).

Cavalier generates overdrive automatically over time. (This gives a little more emphasis towards spell casting).

Don't make the mistake of thinking you can play as a mage though
column28: there's no class selection remember
column30: you gain demonic abilities (spells) as you play through the game but you are limited to only having two of these equipped at any one time.\n\nThis is a hack and slash title
column31:
you can use magic to supplement your slashing and hacking but it can't replace it.


Progress for the Victor

You can further tweak your character to suit your play style as you progress through the game
column32: there's no RPG style skill set to level here though
column33: you  manipulate your available abilities through the weapons
column34: powers and destiny cards you equip. This isn't as limiting as it first sounds
column35: there are plenty of variations you can try out. It's a fresh and interesting approach to character progression
column36:
it just takes a little getting used to.


Weapon of Choice

There are plenty of weapons for you to loot or buy in the game
column37: each type bringing its own flavour to combat.\n\nThe Rapier is ideal if you're looking for some fast "staby
column38: staby" action.\n\nThe sword is your hack and slash staple
column39:
it's a little slower than the Rapier but swinging it around will damage multiple enemies if they're bunched up tight.

There's the scythe for some wider spread slashing  mayhem and the hammer for some slow and heavy squishing.

These are just the melee weapon types
column41: electric zappers etc. to choose from for your ranged attacks too.\n\nEvery weapon comes with a standard attack and two special attack abilities
column42:
each of which is distinctive and noticeably different between weapon types.
You can equip two weapons at a time (once you've progressed far enough to unlock this ability) and switching between them is quick and easy so you'll have multiple options available to suit whatever situation you find yourself in.


Might and Magic the Gathering

Magic in the game takes the form of Demonic Powers
column43: again there are plenty to pick up throughout the game but as I said earlier
column44:
you can only equip two at a time so you're not going to able to play through Victor Vran solely as a spell wielding mage

Whatever your characters wardrobe and equipment you're going to need to get your hands dirty with some melee combat.
However the spells offer some satisfying options in combat to supplement your might with a blade
column45:
whether it's raining down meteors on unsuspecting enemies or throwing up a shield to the damage those endless hordes are throwing at you.

Destiny cards serve as the passive ability mechanic in the game.
You can equip up to five of these cards (depending on your level) which grant various passive abilities from increased health to damage bonuses which will further customise your character to suit your play style.
They're a nice touch and give a tired mechanic a fresh feeling.
I like destiny cards.


Location
column47:
Vocation.

You have a home hub (The castle) and travel to various locations to deal with the horrible hordes that reside there.
There's no open world here though

reviewText: So, now that the game is out of early access, some few words on the final product.  First of all, everything I said below still stands (except bugs...the game is exceptionally clean).  This game is a gem and you should get off your ♥♥♥ and buy it. Haemimont has continued to tweak the balance of the game and it continues to improve (even in areas where it already felt pretty darn good). And there's more coming: the Tome (a caster weapon), more multiplayer stuff, and something every game should have, an expansion featuring Motorhead. Seriously, if you don't like this I don't know what the ♥♥♥♥ to do with you.\n\nA really promising ARPG, now content complete and just in the phase of polish (of which it already has an abundance).  Are there bugs?  Yes, but they're pretty few and pretty far between.  Do the prevent the game from being fun?  Hell no. This game has a great, engaging single-player campaign and is just balls-out fun to play with your friends. There's a really great feel to the control scheme they've put together for this game, and it's very much at home on your living room TV.  Good looking visuals with a unique Eastern/Slavic style totally in keeping with the whole vampire epic storyline, surprisingly good voice acting (surprising because I'm always surprised when voice acting isn't awful), and great weapon mechanics make for a ton of quality gameply.  This game is a good one, well worth your money.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=37-ddPc0yDY

Supprisingly good, lightweight action-RPG from the creators of Tropico series. Satisfying, fast-paced gameplay that requires reflex and agility - you need to move, roll and jump (yes, you can jump, you can also bounce off walls to get to secret areas) a lot on the battlefield, as huge groups of enemies easily surround you. Interesting and well thought character development - instead of choosing skills and investing points in stats, you equip new weapons, spells and destiny cards that provide special bonuses and modifiers. You can change them any time, so your character is able to adapt to every situation in an instant. If you like action-RPGs, you won't be disappointed.

reviewText:
This is one of those times that I wished Steam offered a number or star rating rather than just a Yes/No.

I'll give my critiques in a Pro/Con format:

Pros:

* Graphics - It's a pretty game, pretty scenery, cool particle effects for weapon/power actions, effectful lighting
* Sound - Good voice acting, sound effects add to feel of the gameplay, nice music.
* Gameplay - Movement is tight and has an interesting jump mechanic
* Combat - (Lower level) is fun, lots (number) of mobs to kill, feels impactful

Cons:

* Combat - (Higher levels)
- Scaling is horrible once you start getting over level 20.
- Mobs scale up faster than you can upgrade your weapons and items.
- You get mobs that can hit through your gear and have so many hit points that it takes a lot to burn them down.
- Mobs start hitting so hard that they can effectively 1 or 2 shot you.
- They'll stun or slow you then throw down a power you can't get away from fast enough.
- These overall problems make combat needlessly hard with lots of deaths and generally not fun.

* Transmutation
- It takes 3 of the exact same type/level of item to transmute.
- These come mainly from random drops, the store" rarely has what you need so that means more grinding and leveling up faster than you can transmute better items.
- For weapons
date:
you have no control over attributes of newly transmuted items (random).  Legendary items are a random chance from transmuting epics
- Demonic powers transmute into a random other power.

It's a really close call
hoursPlayed: at the end of the day
voteText: I can't recommend the game because of the horrendous scaling that ends up making combat at higher levels just not fun.  I even bumped the level down to "casual"

reviewText:
I haven't had this much fun in a game for quite some time, and this game had me stuck from the get-go. I think it's great that the game doesn't focus on having classes, and finding the right armor pieces for that specific class. Instead you have all these very unique weapons, and the hammer quickly became a favorite of mine! There are alot of destiny cards and powers to experiment with, so you can build together something that you really like.

I  think that what makes this game so good, is that it differs so much from other games in the genre. Just look at the jumping mechanic (which isn't even a spell), you can find hidden paths by jumping up walls, which is why you always want to remember that you can jump in this game.

I love the 5 star challenges in each area of the map, some are easy, but some are really hard. But everytime you fail, you just HAVE to do it again in order to beat all the challenges. Completing all challenges in an hard area gives a very delightful feeling.

Just one thing: How do me and my friend play together?
Friends (0) and I can't find anywhere ingame where you can add a friend or invite a friend.

reviewText:
Awesome ARPG, on par with Diablo / Path of Exile but very different gameplay-wise
This is an AAA-quality title despite it being an indie project.

The gameplay is similar to Bastion in that every weapon type has unique mechanics and abilities, but unlike Bastion you get a variety of items with random affixes (and of course, the much sought-after Legendary weapons with their own unique behaviour).

I'll add a small tip for those who always choose a mage" playstile in RPGs. You can't play that way from the start but you can get there in a few hours: just choose a Cavalier outfit (you get to do that once you complete the "tutorial" mission) and  improve your Overdrive regeneration as much as possible. For that
date: try to get as many "Tower" Destiny Cards as you can. (Check the Destiny Card vendor often.) Aways use weapons with "Zealous" affix. At level 16 you can use the Transmutaion feature to combine 3 same level Tower cards into a higher-level one
recommended: and if you get a Legendary (purple) Destiny card that you don't need
hoursPlayed: you can use it to upgrade your Cavalier outfit for even more regen. This way you'll eventually get to spam Demon Powers as often as you want.\n\n"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Below you'll find a written and video impression on the game
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZM62s3uqtfI

Victor Vran is an ARPG that has combat and twitch based action at the forefront. It has some interesting systems in play, such as your main skills are attached to your weapons. Since you can take 2 weapons into combat at any given time, it basically allows the player to take 2 sets of skills into combat, switching to maximize DPS and cool downs. Couple this with the ability to dodge we have an ARPG that's very much focused on the A part of ARPG.

Victor Vran has a lot going for it. It has great visuals and audio, a stream lined build system where it still allows for a great degree of customization, and an action focused, and very enjoyable combat. But since the game is in early access, all of it's current flaws lay with this fact. There's no narrative or a proper campaign currently, a lot of models, items, and mobs are reused, and the progression of the game is excruciatingly dragged out. I attribute all of these flaws to it being in early access. I feel the biggest flaw is the slow progression. I have over 7 hours pumped into Victor Vran and barely leveled above level 10. It almost feels like the developers artificially inflated the amount of gold and xp needed to progress in order to hide the lack of content the game current suffers from. It just doesn't feel rewarding and I stopped out of boredom.

Sure I have my complaints but almost all of them are tied into it being in early access. The fantastic combat and how polished every thing feels is my best indication that Victor Vran isn't a lost cause. In fact I highly recommend people to keep an eye on this one. I'm hoping that once it's fully released it'll be something really special. As mentioned before, the game has a lot going for it. The Combat and character build systems in place already are very strong and very enjoyable. The presentation is eye catching and polished, it just needs to be done. There simply just needs to be a lot more of these things.

Overall Victor Vran is an interesting ARPG that has a lot of promise, but in it's current state there simply just not enough of it. Keep an eye on this one.

Pros:
- Polished Visuals and audio
- Fun combat and character build design
- Accessible and easy to get into

Cons:
- Feels very incomplete
- Drawn out progression
- Lacks story or a proper campaign (currently)

reviewText:
═══════════════════════════════════OVERVIEW
Victor Vran an action RPG from guys that made Tropico (???), well sure this game will suck right? Well... no. You play as Victor Vran, a demon hunter, there are no classes, no skill upgrades, you can alter your damage output by changing weapons and outfits or by taking consumable items. There are also destiny cards which give you various passive abilities. Game has an amazing soundtrack which you will make you wait in a cleared area and just listen to it for a bit. I recommend playing with a controler because it will greatly increase your overall statisfaction with this game. Also it seems that Victor had some parkour lessons before he started out his demon hunting job which will surely help him to discover many hidden areas and bonuses.

reviewText:
Victor Vran is something that could be considered a classic if it was tailored for both the devoted audience and casual players. It's a game I almost couldn't stand because of its deviations from what I expect to enjoy from an ARPG.

Over four months ago I had first played Victor Vran for six hours before coming to the conclusion that the game wasn't for me or for casual ARPG players. Now, after 18 hours, I'm going to recommend this game—if you're willing to look beneath the surface.

Why the Change of Heart?
I had a negative impression for numerous reasons.

I was worn-out after 50 hours of Van Helsing: Final Cut. VV's streamlined gameplay didn't convince me there was any longevity/depth. The enemy variety was/is too limited and it became tiresome quickly. Worse of all,  I had thought the game had respawned enemies every time I left a general area for a mini-dungeon. (Not the HUB.)

Only by happenstance of me testing out the Steam Controller did I learn that almost all these issues could be fixed by looking further into the game. (Which is a problem for first-impressions or people not willing to experiment with the game.)

I also learned my black mark—of respawning enemies and of erasing progress—was outright false. Something anyone who read this review, played the game and didn't agree with my thoughts should've pointed that out, not argued about the rating.

That misunderstanding is why I re-reviewed this game. Because even if I don't like a game I want to always be correct about my complaints.

The Stagnant" Progression
There was a misunderstanding when I said progression feels stagnant. It's not that there is no depth or no way to improve yourself—the problem is that your character himself does not show gradual changes as you play
date: so everything feels the same.\n\nIt's better to say progression is abrupt
recommended: and entirely dependent on the player's involvement. Leveling up unlocks new things to experiment with (Destiny Card pts
voteText: a second weapon
helpfulPercent: item or demon power slot
votesHelpful: etc.) They also unlock other additions like the transmutation system
votesTotal: another outfit
votesFunny: PvP
commentsCount: endless arena and Hexes (difficulty modifiers).\n\nThese are all options
column16: options which you may or may not care about as you play. You're enjoyment of the game is based on how much interest you want to put into tweaking these options to create your own character
column17: from the weapons/skills to your playstyle.\n\nZero Classes
column18: All Tailored Adjustments\nIn order to appreciate the benefits of a "no-class" ARPG
column19: you have to have some interest by experimenting with all these options. If that doesn't sound appealing than having a class-system laid out for you
column20: then VV is not for you.\n\nThere are no "active" skill improvements other than finding a new demon power or a new type of weapon. But there are only eight weapons (and about the same number of demon powers): Swords
column21: Hammers
column22: Scythes
column23: Rapiers
column24: Shotguns
column25: Lightning Guns
column27: Tomes. Each weapon has three active skills (one standard attack
column28: two specials)
column29: and you can have two weapon equipped and two demon powers at most. (10 total skills.)\n\nThe make-or-break deal is whether or not you like the weapon presets. On the one hand
column30: each weapon is tailored for one playstyle and you can master it as you play. But if you don't like it
column31: then that limits your options even further.\n\nThis could be fixed if the game offered new presets of skills. Instead
column32:
you have to find what weapon is for you—and if you combine weapon's abilities together (like the shotgun's speed boost with the hammer) you can get some interesting weapon synergy.

(I still think the combat would flow much better if the devs took a page from Bloodborne used changing out weapons as another attack skill based on your weapon choices.)

The best part about this system is you can beat the game
column34: without ranged weapons or one specific weapon type. Something that I had originally thought was mandatory
column35: and yet I finished the game
column37: on Normal with two or three Hexes added.\n\n(Hexes
column39: made me ignore the Transmutation system entirely. I still got plenty of legendaries and good loot from random drops.)\n\nThe real source of improvement comes from building your character around the buffs of your Destiny Cards
column40:
your weapons/inventory and focusing on what weapons work best.

The Only Passive System that's Not All Boring
If you took a look at this list
column41: you'd be forgiven thinking these things are unnecessary to pay attention to as you play: Destiny Cards[victorvran.wikia.com]\n\nThe reality is that is your source of builds in VV
column42:
and if you want to play the game properly you'll have to figure out what works with your playstyle (and weapons). The game's spike in difficulties at some points will force you to focus on this system.

Some cards provide the basic whatever-percent value boost while others give flashier effects by taking damage or dealing out critical hits. Some will give you weapon modifiers. Some of which will help you stay alive by siphoning off health with each hit or kill.

There are also random effects (divine or wicked) that make lower-tiered buffs worth more than higher valued stuff. (A Divine Rogue 1 with armor penetration is much better than a Rogue 3 for some instances.) And because you have a limited number of Destiny Points
column43: you have to take the time to figure out what selection is for you.\n\nCombine the Destiny Points with each outfits'/armors' adrenaline system to use Demon Powers
column44: and you can find as much depth in this game as you would in most other ARPGs. The store-page was not lying when it said you need as much as skill as you need a proper build.\n\nThe question is
column45:
"Will you want to invest any interest in that system?"

A Streamlined Game with Hardcore Demands
Again
column46: you have to invest a lot in this non-casual-friendly system to play properly and to also understand its appeal. That is something that should be addressed as other similar games provide a simpler system
column47: though they may be more or less complex than Victor Vran.\n\nThis isn't a cry for a game to become dumb-downed. I want more people to play this game
column48: and I would bet that many who didn't enjoy it (based on my old review's ratings
column49: 398 out of 503 upvotes) would come to love it if the system was developed more. (Either by more weapons
column51: more card variety tied to these changes
column53: etc.)\n\nIf you're not sure if the game is for you
column54: then  I would urge you to try it for yourself on a sale
column55:
and if it is something you'd enjoy convince your friends to join up with you for cooperative play.

Suggestions for ImprovementAdd another skill between weapons to make combat flow better. (Ex. Bloodborne.)
If we can't choose our skills for weapons
column56: then let us have various presets for different playstyles. (It'll give us a reason to try weapons more.)\nMore interesting enemy variety.\nLess arbitrary "challenges" (no-hit
column58: etc.) and more Hex modifiers for challenge."

When I heard that the Tropico developers were making an Action RPG game my interest on it grew very fast.
Saw the trailer, and I thought: Well, it seems amazing!
Then it got released on Steam Early Access for only R$29,90 (Brazilian Reais). I thought: Well, the game's very cheap...
So, I saw ZiggyD's First Look video... And I decided, I must buy it!
Finished downloading it, and then...
It's a AMAZING game! Really! One of the best Action RPG games around!
You MUST play this! No kidding!
Can't wait for the complete version!

* Pros:
Amazing graphics.
Good soundtrack.
Gameplay is smooth and fun.
The challenges are simply brilliant! They make us explore the entire scenarios to complete them all.
It's so cheap!

* Cons
From what I understood, you can only equip one Outfit, so there's no armor customization, like different pieces (Helmet, Chest, Boots, things like that). It might be changed in the future, but for now, that's the only thing I disliked from the game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So, I played Diablo, Torchlight, and other ARPG's. I do not feel that the WASD controlls are bad, it's just a variety. I recommend getting the game, if you won't ♥♥♥♥♥ about the controls, because as far there's no way to bind the controls to other keys. (Might change in further updates)
You get 4 different styles of weapons, and you can equip instantly 2. All of the 4 have diffrent abilities, and require different playstyle.
You get Demon Powers, which drop as loot when killing a certain mob, or achievement drop.
I recommend reading the Developer's further patch notes, as they explain, at this point the plan of the game's evolution.
All the dungeons have a certain amount of CHALLENGES, complete them and you will be rewarded.
I do recommend the game, and I do trust the developers that this game will be fully released.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

You know what I really hate about this game? There's not enough of them! Some of my favourite games of this genre consist of 'Diablo', 'Torchlight', 'Grim Dawn' and 'Van Helsing' just to name a few. Well 'Victor Vran' is now rated up there with the best of them!

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ATNQ94_qhww

Victor Vran is an isometric Action-RPG with a massive selection of weapons, items, outfits, demon powers and destiny cards. Experience intense combat action with dozens of enemies attacking you from all sides and unleash powerful skills to finish them off! Forge your own personal version of Victor thanks to a vast array of powerful weapons, game-changing outfits, wicked demon powers and destiny cards. Use special moves, combine skills and weapons to wipe out hordes of hideous beasts and clever boss monsters. Slaying demons doesn’t have to be a lonely affair – team up with friends online and explore the story of the dark world together in a full co-op experience. - Highly Recommended!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have now invested a good amount of time in VV and can honestly reccomend it.

The dev's have promised to add a great deal more to the game, and they have replied to a fair amount of my posts on the Steam forums.

If you like ARPG, then this game is for you.  It's highly addictive, difficult at times, and rewarding to.

I'm going to list some pro's and con's based on my personal feelings on the initial 13 hours I've played.  (I've completed the game and got to level 10 which is maximum in it's current iteration...

Pro's
+ Great combat
+ Nice graphics
+ Jumping!
+ Nice music
+ Loot Grades (green and yellow so far)
+ Replayability ( Can reset any area and replay for killing and looting)
+ Scaling levelling - so no area becomes too easy, effectively the mobs gain new abilities as you do
+ Very stable for the initialy early access release

Cons
+ Only 4 weopons at present (more to become available)
+ Not enough loot dropped by trash mobs
+ No armour slots yet- only outfits
+ Difficulty needs some balancing still
+ No story in game yet - that is to come of course
+ No weopon skins in game yet - I hope these make an entrance, as weopon's should look different

So there you have it.  I suggest you pick this up whilst it's on sale, it's a steal at this price.
voteText: 15 of 21 people (71%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I'm only some 4 hours in, but am really enjoying this game!
I am a huge ARPG fan, and basically will buy and play any ARPG that has even decent reviews.

Victor Vran did something I didn't believe I'd enjoy, and that is offering dodge / jump in an ARPG. Something we've seen before is the option to have two weapon sets (in this case just two weapons) equipped, and in Victor Vran due to the special move charge mechanics I find myself switching all the time. It's really fun, too! Nothing like jumping in the fray with the 2H Hammer leap slam, and then demolishing the rest with my sword or rapier.

Due to the somewhat peculiar (for an ARPG) mechanics, I now find myself trying to take down packs of mobs unscathed. Dodging here and there, using leap slams etc.

The voice acting is quite entertaining, especially the guy mocking you as you go. I once lol'd when I went back to find a secret I missed, to which the commentator remarked how Victor decided to go the wrong way. :D I mean, that's just awesome. :D Then when I went where I should, he made of of me by saying how I finally decided to go the right way. That's just brilliant coding imho.

I also enjoy the fact that very little in the character is locked, so you can switch out demon powers and destiny cards to change your play style. This is a nice casual change to having played Path of Exile recently.
In the beginning you choose class (actually an outfit) which determines what your character is like. Not sure if you can change it, I heard something about changing outfits later...

The map challenges are great as well, and some of them are actually quite hard.
Secrets are a nice addition too, having to wall jump to special locations etc.

There isn't much on the loot side, but I haven't missed that so far. Usually I love farming items and perfecting my gear, but in the case of Victor Vran the gameplay itself is just so fun I don't really care for the lack of itemization.

Regardless, can definitely recommend this game to ARPG fans! Easily, you will not regret it.

reviewText:
This game is great.  Fight off loads of monsters with your equipped weapons and demon powers, while trying to discover why there is such an outbreak of monsters and so many of your fellow hunters dead.  Quite a few maps to explore, fun bosses, lots of enemy variety, and lots of loot.  Finish some maps, and come back to the hub to trade with NPCs, stash items away, hear what new things they might have to say, and then head back out to do a new quest.

As you level up you'll earn the ability to equip a second weapon, a second demon power, multiple divination cards (which can do a great number of things), and more.

Fighting off hordes of monsters is really satisfying, and the story seems pretty interesting.  A very enjoyable game.

Victor Vran is awash in psudo-Victorian action and gameplay that harkens back to the best aspects of games like Diablo II and Castlevania: Symphony of the Night. reviewText:
Having played a lot of ARPGs, Victor Vran is a great game that really stresses the Action part of ARPG. It may not have some of the typical bells and whistles some of the other games have like skill trees or a perma-death mode, but the fast paced fluid combat really makes this game shine.

Pros:    The combat in this game really stands out from other games. I know some people have complained about there being only 3 skills per weapon but I find this lets you focus more on the combat itself then managing a larger number of skills and cooldowns. The ability to quickly swap between two weapons also helps keep the action fluid even in changing situations.
The artwork is wonderful. Maps are so finely crafted I seem to spend a great deal of time futilely attempting to enter non-playable parts just to explore.
Map challenges and secrets provide a fun reason to more fully play each area and or return for future visits.
The Destiny Card system which is a passive skill system is interesting, requiring a different kind of balancing act then a more typical point based skill.
Cons:    The first thing that should be noted here is that there are still a number of bugs in the game. The majority of these for me at least are minor, not greatly affecting my play through. The developers also seem to have an active enough presence on the forums that I’m confident that these issues will be resolved.
There is no trading at the moment. I can understand the reasoning for not having this in the game as items do not have level requirements, but at the same time it can make things a little frustrating. For example I’ve mostly been playing coop with a friend and while I’ve gotten a lot of good weapon drops he’s been using the same weapon since almost the beginning as nothing better has dropped for him.
This is more of a personal pet peeve then a full con, but the chat system can be a little frustrating to operate when using keyboard+mouse to play. After sending a message the game keeps you in the chatbox until you either hit Enter, Esc, or click outside the box. It can make communication a little difficult when in the middle of combat.
All in all, I’ve been very happy with Victor Vran and would definitely recommend it as a great ARPG that puts a different spin on some of the core concepts of the sub-genre.

reviewText:
I haven't played a long time yet, just an hour but I have enjoyed it.  I am a huge fan of TiaoVH trilogy which it is hard not to compare this game against but I think the game holds it's own rather nicely.  I do not believe it is a clone like some have said.  It has a similar feel yes, but plenty to set itself apart.  I haven't ran into any major bugs or problems yet.   I like the WASD control scheme with it.  All in all it is a very nice ARPG game.   Is it ground breaking?  No but is it a must have for a ARPG fan, I would say yes, even in it's pre-release state.   Due to being sick I haven't been able to play it as much as I would have liked and only in real short spurts of time but it has been well worth the time I did play.   I give it a thumb up for sure.

Post Launch Update 7/25:
I have added a bit more time under my belt on this one and I have to say that I am digging it more and more now that it has launched.  I have actually switched to playing it with an XBOX 360 controller over WASD/Mouse controls and found it to play very nicely that way as well.  Honestly it plays like Dungeon Seige 3 wanted to play, IE an diablo-like, action RPG with smooth controller mapped options.  I like it because it is straight forward and while it has a lot of depth it doesn't seem to be cluttered with a bunch of useless stats and stuff that cause me want to bang my head.  So with a couple more hours now under my belt I have to say that this game is quickly rising in my ranks of MUST play.  Really enjoying it.  The story so far hasn't been anything amazing, and the graphics are so/so, but the game play is very fun.  Word of warning though and if you don't already know this Victor Vran is voiced by the same voice actor that does Geralt from The Witcher, so that is one of those things that once you have heard it is hard to unhear since Geralt is such an iconic character.  Outside of that I am LOVING the game.

Update #2 on 7/25 - This is my new favorite game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Victor Vran is an aRPG with some twists.

It has a rotating camera, which is extremely helpful. It also has a dodge system which makes combat quick, addictive, and enjoyable.
The way you play the game is very immersive, there are no skill trees and stat selections upon leveling up, instead you're given bonuses and upgrades, you get to select one of 3.
There are no classes, your playstyle is based on your outfit (which determines the way you gain overdrive, which is used to activate demon powers), your cards (which grant specific buffs and abilities, you can select multiple), and your demon powers (powerful skills aquired from killing enemies with demonic powers, you can equip two of these.)
Now, one thing to point out, all the items in the game can be upgraded. Everything can be transmuted and made stronger. Weapons can have power stones, which add stat buffs. Outfits can be upgraded to gain traits from legendary cards. Cards have regular versions, and the more powerful wicked and divine versions which have useful passives and buffs.

The game also has plenty of MMO like challenges minus the trivial part of actually acquiring the quest and going back to the person for your reward. There is also multiplayer, a PvE arena, basic fighting pit PvP, and probably more things that I still havent found.

This game has been very active and the devs seem to be putting all of their effort into this game. Overall its a beautiful game, I have had no bugs or errors, the game runs perfectly. More content is added weekly.

To sum it up; if you like aRPGs but you're looking for something different, refreshing, enjoyable, and challenging, just buy this game and stop looking. Seriously, this game is amazing. Easily the best aRPG since D2.

Buy Victor Vran, buy it now.

Very fun game. Has a great combat system, good customization, and very nice online play. Italso has impressive camera work, making seeing where you need to see possible in all areas of the game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Victory Vran is a top-down isometric action-RPG where you play as a man with a fidora whom probably gets asked if he can lift, and although I wanted to be a different fedora man to play as in my adventure of killing a lot of cool looking dancing skeletons and getting to be Aladin, this game is a hidden gem I never expected to love.

The graphics are good with a nice art style to it, especially the handful of character art in the game along side its description, which does look great, and what give the game that awesome graphical touch aside from its general look, is that you can rotate your camera around, giving you the control of looking wherever you want to see the games world and beauty from multiple sides, adding to the immersion and connection you'd have to the world.

The sound design is good too, but the soundtrack is just great to listen to. Although there isn't voice acting at the moment, it would definitely help if there will be, adding to the overall great production of a game.

The gameplay is great with a lot of weapons to play around with, different armor/clothes types to wear, a lot of variety and fun in its different mechanics like simply jumping, which most if not all games in its genre does not use, wall-jumping which is extremely satisfying (as well as normal jumping) to access new areas, and finding secret nicely hidden areas which is awesome to find and rewarding.

Also, when going into a dungeon, or any level, you would have a nice little preview of that dungeon/level before going in. The game is moderately challenging, with boss fights being unique and extremely challenging, even with a coop friend. Mentioning coop, it's really nice with no complications to come along with it, as you just invite and your friend is in your world to slay monsters with you.

What I want from the game is voice acting as I mentioned above, and the ability to tilt the camera up and down as it sometimes feel weird not being able to do so. Another thing that's more to spice and mix things up a bit, is having a different character other than the main one, or at least having the opposite gender, not that important but would definitely add more value to its variety and somewhat to its overall enjoyment factor.

I was reluctant of trying this game out, but after my friend pushed me to give it a go, I was extremely surprised of how good it is and how it's adding features to its gameplay that no other in its genre is doing, and those features are blowing my satisfaction of the game and its genre sky high, more so than the top dog which at the moment which is Diablo 3. Definitely give this game a look as it deserves your attention, as it did mine.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It doesn't take much to make a good Diablo-Clone.  Just take what made Diablo great and expand on it.  Simple right?  If you know anything about these games, you know more times than not, it's either Hit or Miss...Hit meaning classics like Titan Quest, Torchlight, and Grim Dawn...or Miss meaning pieces of trash like Blood Knights, Sacred 3, or The Incredibly Impossible Adventures of Van Helsing.

Anyway, Victor Vran takes the ARPG formula and makes it real simple and functional.  Firstly, you get to choose your controls - WSAD to move & click to attack, Click to Move/Attack, or gamepad.  You read that correctly...all three are options, as well as key mapping for either keyboard option you choose.  Why other dungeon crawlers don't attempt to adopt this kind of setup is beyond me.

That said, there's a reason more people enjoy playing Diablo III on a console..using a controller feels so excellent for this type of game, and it's actually very responsive.  Your attacks are quick, but weighty, and you actually get experience points for doing more damage to an enemy than needed.

They've added a jump button, which at first seems stupid, but combined with the ability to wall jump, it actually allows you to get to secret areas and get away from enemies.  They've also included a dodge button, taking a page out of the Dungeon Siege III book.  There's no cooldown or stamina bar for dodge rolls like there is in Risk of Rain or Dark Souls, respectively. You can do it as many times as you want and it really comes in handy.

Sound is great, voice acting is pretty spot on as well.  From time to time it DOES sound like the voice actor is reading his lines..because he is...but it's still well done.  Looting is par for the course, and you'll be able to upgrade your weapons, transmute, etc.  Since there's no skill tree or even any classes so-to-speak,  your skills and based on your outfit and the weapons you use.  It sounds strange, but it really does work.  That ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ skill tree in PoE turned a lot of people off, myself included, so to have things simplified so I can concentrate on killing stuff is a breath of fresh air.

Each dungeon actually gives you 5 tasks to complete, each one giving you a star for completion.  Some of them require you to take no damage, use no potions, or slay a certain number of beasts in a certain amount of time.  If things get hectic and you can only accomplish 4 out of the five, no biggie.  Just leave, get your mind right, go back later and get that 5th star.  It's pretty linear gameplay, but if you're a fan of this genre, then you've come to expect that.

So far the game's a lot of fun, and it's only gonna get better.  Grab it now while it's in Early Access or wait til the 26th when it gets a full release.  Either way, it's worth owning.  Hands down one of the best ARPGs I've ever played.

reviewText:
If you like games where you start to play and you realize 2 hours just went by, you like Diablo type gaming, endless loot, very cool and varied enemies and cool mini and main bosses, plus great level design and graphics, then get this game. I picked it up during the Exploration sale, and I’m so glad I did. This game takes an old school type of game and turns up the coolness to 11. If you’re a stats person, this game has stats on everything. Plus you get to transmute everything in the game which, changes, improves, or makes new weapons, cards (I’ll get to that in a moment) runes, and more.
This game when it comes to weapons reminds me of Borderlands, with tons of different weapons, and stats to blow your mind. But this game has way more than weapons to think about, it uses cards that have special powers, that you can equip to increase so many different things I couldn’t begin to list them all . It’s also a huge game, with secrets to find in every level. There is so much to do, it always feels fresh. The combat is amazing. You have many weapon types to use, as well as tomes, which have special powers, plus each weapon type has a main and two special powers. But that’s not all. You also can equip Two Demon Powers, which can be powered up by fighting. And like the weapons, you have a huge choice of powers to choose from. All are awesome, and look really cool when used.
As for controller support, it works great with a 360 controller. I like using a controller on this game because you have to be able to switch weapons and powers in a blink, and this is all a button away.
Don’t let this game slip away. If playing games where time flies and you I don’t want to stop playing because you want to see what cool thing is next then this is the game for you.

reviewText:
It is fine, but compared to it's obvious competition (The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing - same genre, very similar setting of Demon Hunter in steampunk world) it fell short.

Combat mechanics and skills are great and I loved them. There's also some new ideas making game more skillfull than your average other aRPG, but the story was very weak and very badly presented and some complex loot system and some stat system would help the game a lot.

On the upside - there is crazy amount of additional optional stuff. Only like 1/4th of the locations are mandatory for story (plus each location comes with set of challenges and secrets) so there's a lot to do besides story itself. But with very basic loot system there is no real motivation to do so, from like 1/3 of the game I basically ignored most of the optional locations because there was no reason to do them or to max challenges.

If you're not intrested in story or loot hoarding, only in combat elements of aRPGs - it will offer you a lot of content. But if you like core aRPGs, collecting equipment, maximizing your hero, trying different builds etc - it's fine, but not the best.

reviewText:
Fantastic little ARPG here.
It is very streamlined compared to most traditional rpgs, you wont be sorting through piles of loot to find marginally better pants or whatever. There are only a very few things that monsters drop and those are automatically picked up meaning that you dont ever have to stop killing monsters unless you want to.

The games class system (or lack thereof) is where it really shines though. Victor wont be slowly putting points into a skill tree and becoming a better mage/swordsman/archer or whatever. Oh no Mr Vran can use all weapons right away and can even swap between 2 at any time.
This makes for very dynamic gameplay as you can swap things out instantly mid combat, allowing for all sorts of awsome combos and gameplay variety.

Finally the setting/theme/voiceacting etc are all great. The narrator is particularly funny as he quips when you reach certain areas.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is shaping up to be one of the most fun isometric games I have played in a long time. Although one thing should be clear about this game is the fact there is no typical skill progression where you spend points on skills, the skills you have are based on the weapon you equip. Thats not to say you cant make your own build as there is other types of skills you can Loot/Equip called Powers which all have there own Rarity, Along with Weapons > Prefix > Suffix.

As you start your adventure on this game nothing to begin with really stands out, other than the wasd action movement and being able to jump over objects or down/up terrain (which is really satisfying on an isometric) along with dodge.
This game seems like nothing out of the ordinary and then some time down the line you start to realize the game has ideas, mechanics, and similar music from other arpg/isometric games all put into one game, minus skill progression.

The music in Victor Vran is good, it reminds me of some music in older games that I played in the past years.
Transmution is incredibly addictive, along with trying to gamble with transmution, you can transmute many items including your powers.
Monster zone venders in games are nice but one thing VV does different is when you find the vender, you need to fight him untill he submits....Nice Touch.

This game is Beast there is no doubt about it hopefully other arpg game devs take notes these guys clearly did.

I really did struggle to find something wrong with this game, but if I was to be picky there is no jewelry, the videos before a boss or quest dialogues are capped on 30fps and the melee aiming could be a bit better but in general movement is good you can even wall kick =).
Van Helsing is one of the only isometrics that I didnt enjoy, but this game seems to have filled an empty void.

Good game, lots of items, magic find, many bosses, transmution, multiple potions, endless dungeon, pvp arena, bank stash, creative world map and each map has its own challanges along with being able to add map Prefix and Suffix.

Im glad I bought this game, Its not a game I would suggest to wait for it to go on sale, its worth every penny.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you're looking for a very solid ARPG with a superb combat system look no further, this is the game.

The feature that makes this game fun is its combat, it is very refreshing to see something like this in a ARPG.  You actively dodge and jump around to avoid damage.  Basically the movements and attacks is like an MMO, but in a top-down view like traditional ARPG's.

The character customization isn't super deep like other ARPG's, there are no specific classes.  The customization comes in weapons, destiny cards, and demon powers.  There are different weapons that you can use and each weapon has their own special skills to use.  There are no rings or accessorie slots, but there are items called destiny cards" which are similar to those.  These cards give passive bonus' to your character

reviewText:
I enjoyed Victor Vran and played through it on hardcore mode. Even though I prefer a challenge in games that I play, the hardcore mode in the game didn’t feel hard until the last ten percent of the game, and instead felt annoying. This is because it took forever to kill enemies, especially when you first start playing, mainly because of the hexes you have while playing hardcore. To remedy this, I built my character as a glass cannon meaning that I ignored defense items and purely went for offense, so that it wouldn’t take forever to kill anything. Even though I had no defense, I almost never died except for when there were huge groups of enemies and sometimes on bosses. In other words, hardcore mode is mostly annoying instead of hard, and normal difficulty is probably too easy. Other than the game’s difficulty, I also loved the amount of content the game has in completing challenges and finding all of the secrets in every level.

A video with some gameplay:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Uat0yhvq23M

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Victor Vran, while appeareing to just be another hack-and-slash Diablo clone, is much more than that. The combat system allows for graceful combos by swapping between two sets of weapons at any point and the use of the Overdrive system, in which you use fuled up skills to unleash torment against the armies that fight against the demon hunters.
While the story may be a bit lack luster, the humor is solid, and the gameplay itself is compelling enough to keep you slaughtering the demons that block your way of finding your friend of old that requested your presence.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I was really surprised when I heard Haemimont was making an action RPG. I loved their Tropico series of games, but the action RPG genre isn't something you just dive into when all you're known for are sim games. I'm a huge fan of the Diablo series, I've played quite a bit of Marvel Heroes and Path of Exile as well as both Torchlight games. Victor Vran is like a breath of fresh air in the genre, and it's not just because you can jump and roll around - the game does a good job making all drops feel valuable, something that very few action RPGs succeed in doing. The story and voice acting is average, but the combat is really solid, the idea of switching weapons and having no classes is pretty unique and well done.

In Victor Vran you can switch between two weapons at any time, giving you access to a total of four weapon skills (plus regular attacks for each weapon). You can then equip two different Demon Powers, which are essentially spells, giving you access to six skills total. Then there's two slots for consumables and trinkets, like potions or a lucky rabbit's foot that gives you 100% critical hit chance for five seconds. To further customize your character, you gain access to Destiny Cards and that's when Victor Vran gets really awesome, because you can switch how your character players pretty easily. If you want to be able to live longer, you can put on a bunch of life steal and armor Destiny Cards to make your character tanky. Or if you like playing ranged, you do use the Archer card for increased range damage and stack critical hit chance and critical hit damage. Be able to switch up how your character is at anytime is pretty rad, especially when you can upgrade nearly everything in the game through the transmutation system.

I wrote a longer and more detailed review here: http://www.fullcleared.com/2015/07/18/victor-vran-review-haunted-past/ but really, if you're a fan of action RPGs, you should definitely check out Victor Vran. The end game is pretty solid right now, and Haemimont has been adding a ton of content, so I expect it to get much better in the coming months.

reviewText:
Great little ARPG that even gives Diablo 3 a run for its money... and I've been a D3 player since the open beta.

The game doesn't use the usual mana pool system to cast spell. Your abilities are determined by what weapon you equip, destiny cards (i.e. passive skills) and what demon abilities you equip (think super moves from fighting games).

The game works well in melding these layers of customisation so that you can create some interesting builds.

The ingame stash is shared between all your saves... and it even grows a new tab when you need it!

Controls via mouse + keyboard, and the controller feels great but I find the controller to just feel more natural.

With 4 player co-op included, Victor Vran ticks all the right boxes for what needs to be included in an ARPG. IMHO, this is simply the best ARPG you can get on Steam at time of writing.

reviewText:
My experiences are SOLO PLAY only. I have not tried multiplayer.

I've played similar games, Van Helsing 1 & 2, Diablo 3, Torchlight, and this is in the same vein. It's not anything new, in fact I feel like Van Helsing at least gave some replay value with different classes.

+ Weapons are tied in to skills and there are no permanent talent decisions.
+ Bounties for killing elites & Treasure hunts (finding pieces") reward you with gold and chests/items.
+ Campaign took me 10 hours of playing
date:
fairly straight through but taking a detour now and then to get a visible secret or complete a bounty.
+ You get access to all the inventory slots pretty quickly.
+ Transmute system for upgrading your equipment.
+ Seems to be an active community with build guides and such on Steam.


- No classes
recommended: you can change your armor to affect how your Special Ability (Demon Power) works
hoursPlayed: but that's it.\n- I didn't know if there was enough replay value to make me continue playing.\n- Switching to "casual" mode didn't really seem to dip the difficulty as much as I was expecting - but that is not really a plus or minus but I was hoping for it to be very casual because I just wanted to experience the story without having to worry about perfecting my gear or build."

reviewText: Victor Vran enters the fray as a surprisingly well polished and exciting action role playing game to sink your teeth into. It’s got some decent humor, solid gameplay mechanics and a stat system which allows for multiple ways to tailor the character to your liking. With lots of loot to find, and plenty of enemies to lay waste to, there’s enough entertainment here to reach into double figures and beyond. For the asking price though it’s great value for money and if you’re into Gothic games of this nature then it comes highly recommended despite being a little simplistic overall. Aside from a lack of local multiplayer, a camera that’s perhaps too far away at times and no other characters to choose from there’s little else to complain about here making Victor Vran well worth checking out.\n\nScore 8.5/10https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=z_FN0aGp6jE

reviewText:
The follwing is copied from my review on pressa2join.com/victor-vran-review and is for a as yet unrelaesed (it is due for release soon however) early access title
[Disclosure: Game copy supplied by Developer]

Victor Vran is the isometric action-RPG (ARPG) published by EuroVideo Medien and developed by Haemimont Games. Haemimont Games are best known for their work on the Tropico series however they have also developed games such as: Celtic Kings, Imperium Romanum/ Grand Ages: Rome, the Tzar series and Omerta – City of Gangsters as well as a few others. Haemimont Games have as this list suggests primarily focused on RTS and city building games, it’s nice to see a developer try something new, but not without its risks, does the risk pay off? Read on to find out.

You are a demon hunter with a secret, you made a pact some years ago in order to wield Demon powers. A message arrives from your friend Adrian in the land of Zagoravia, a land that succumbed to a Demon invasion one year earlier, telling you he’s found the thing that you seek (what this is, is yet to be discovered).

You do not know much about the land of Zagoravia only that many Demon Hunters travelled to the land only to never return including your friend Adrian. The travel to Zagoravia in order to find out what happened to your friend and also in the hopes of finding this secret that your friend discovered. Perhaps you may find out what exactly happened in the mystery of the Demon incursion into Zagoravia. Upon arrival you start hearing a character calling himself “the voice” that resides apparently in your head.

Victor Vran is an action-RPG that focuses on customisation as opposed to classes as there are no specific classes to speak of, essentially you can customise your character to play in a class of your own design. You can choose to wield up to two weapons consisting of mortars, swords, scythes, lightning guns hammers and rapiers (there may be perhaps others I have yet to discover) you also have a choice of outfits and can even customise its colour if you so desire. Additionally you have a choice of multiple Demon powers and can wield up to two of them there is also a choice of what is called “destiny cards” which you collect and they provide you with various buffs. Each of these items have various levels and/or rarity.

There is also a variety of consumables that can be used from the basic health potion to the more advanced leech bomb. Upon reaching level 16 you have access to the “transmutation” facility which allows you to combine all of your pickups except potions into either a generally improved item, an item of higher rarity or if you so choose a random item.

In Victor Vran you are extremely mobile and have the ability to jump or dodge to avoid incoming damage. You can also wall jump in order to reach otherwise inaccessible areas, and can also use the mortars special jump ability to reach even more inaccessible areas. Each of the levels have various different optional challenges that you can attempt completion of, which will provide a reward of some description from money, XP to a reward chest that can contain a random item of the same level as the chest.

In addition to the normal and hard modes players can also add further levels of difficulty with the addition of “hexes” which add certain buffs to the enemies granting a further challenge and higher reward. Players can also join in multiplayer with up to 3 other people for Co-op action or even venture into the PVP arena to find out who is the better hunter.

Mechanically speaking the additional mobility of the character provides an extra layer of skill which helps with the overall immersion of the game. The loot, items and challenges/rewards system all work really well together. The only issue I found was a slight graphical glitch which occurred under certain circumstances I have however alerted the developer to this.

However this is very minor and is to be expected of an early access title. Graphically speaking the game has a dark Gothic theme which suits the era and overall aesthetic. As for sound the soundtrack is suitably Gothic and dark, the music and sound assets all work well, the combination of which adds to the overall immersion of the game.

Overall I found this game to be an absolute joy to play, it of course has similarities with Diablo 3 however I found that I lost interest with Diablo whereas with Victor Vran I thoroughly enjoyed it and find myself itching to play some more. This can be attributed to the customisation of the character, the hilarious movie quotes (Monty Python and the Holy Grail and Star Wars to name but two) and other equally hilarious abuse received from “The Voice (inside your head)” or perhaps it’s the hilarity that ensued from meeting the “Gangnam Style” dancing skeletons. Sufficive to say this new direction for Haemimont Games paid off with dividends, and I for one can’t wait to see both what additions they make to the game and of course the next game they work on.

10/10
voteText: 8 of 9 people (89%) found this review helpful

reviewText:

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Imagine a Van Helsing that is actually fun to play, armed with a choice of weapons (Sword/Hammer/Scythe/Shotgun and Rapier), you can wield two at a time as you wade through enemies and augment them with magical powers and increase your stats with Destiny cards which can be changed at will (which means you are not locked into a skill tree).

The combat controls are sublimely responsive, best controls I have used in a game like tis ever!

As you progress through the story and enter dungeons (which each have their own unique sets of challenges and secrets), you will have a really fun experience, I highly recommend it!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Updated 7/8/2015

My review was at the character limit already, so with this update I had to delete what I had written previously.

Rather than doing a long, in depth review of the game as I had done previously I will keep this short and sweet and try to justify changing my recommendation.

While I still feel that the shallow character progression and the lack of skill progression is a huge drawback, the recent updates including itemization changes, the addition of an item transmutation system, the addition of voiceover content and other small changes have matured this game into what the developers had envisioned.  The transmutation system did a surprisingly good job of making the itemization feel deeper and more established as well.

Having Doug Cockle (Geralt of The Witcher) voice the main protagonist was certainly a point in the game's favor.  I honestly never expected such talent to lend their voice to the cast.  Rather than limiting the voiceover work to cutscenes and active dialogue alone, as I had thought they would, Victor Vran and other characters routinely spout out lines during gameplay.  This has the effect of making the general hum-drum of monster bashing a little bit more interesting and even humorous in at least one case.

I have to admit that when I restarted the game with the sole purpose of re-evaluating my review, I never expected to change my recommendation.  I started with a new save slot and played to where I had left off before my last review.

The game as a whole seems to gel better than it had previously.  The voiceover work did a surprisingly good job of making the experience more engaging.  The combat is still excellent.  Don't get me wrong here, the combat is far, far from deep and intricate, but it's fast paced and feels impactful.  I like it.

I only experienced one bug which forced me to turn off reverb in my sound options.  With the option turned on character voices were accompanied by an incredibly annoying scratchy hum.  Other than that, I played with every option on ultra and had an enjoyable, smooth experience.  I also have to mention that I play on an ultra-widescreen monitor and had no stretching or UI issues at 21:9 aspect ratio.  Definitely a plus in my book.

I now feel that despite it's flaws this game is worth the cost of entry.  It has become the game the devs meant for it to be.

reviewText:
Victor Vran is marketed as an Indie game, but it simply doesn't feel like one. The game has the kind of generous polish you'd expect from a higher budget project.

This game shines in its combat interactions. It is very addictive and can be enjoyed for countless hours. The precision is superb and the creatures' AI can be quite challenging. The only issue with it, is that there isn't enough. Unfortunately the game itself on normal mode will feel easy to any experience gamer. Start a game on Hard and you'll encounter some of the problems with Victor Vran. The balancing of the game is basically an exercise in changing numbers. Creatures have more armor, hit for more and may be faster. You can tweak these characteristics by enabling handicaps called Hexes, but in the end the fights do not change much. Once you've mastered all creatures, then the game becomes an exercise in finding better equipment and it basically becomes a grind.

Victor Vran's equipment scheme is a basic one compared to other RPG types. Most of the equipment that is found (weapons) is useless and can either be sold or transmuted. This is my second critique of the game in that it doesn't really establish any links with the character you are building. It's basically like a Chinese buffet. You can do everything you want as long as you're grinding for it. Demon Powers and Destiny Cards as more equipment are supposed to replace a skill tree, but the level of interest isn't great due the limited options or the limited benefits they bring.

My third and final critique is that the story isn't very enticing. It's very basic and unfortunately it doesn't really immerses the player effectively. The game exposes too many challenges while the story is unraveling and it's really easy to get side tracked just trying to get better equipment to answer those challenges.

With these 3 point in mind, this game still rocks. I'm actively wishing for a sequel where these issues are answered.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Victor Vran Review

Tl;dr If you enjoy playing ARPGs and you're aware of the early stage of the game: go and buy it, Now. Victor Vran is one of the most amazing ARPG so far in my opinion.

Combat:

Not the stereotypical you're used from other games like D3 but that's not bad, it's the complete opposite! It feels really great. 10/10 would kill again.

Graphics:

They are really great. I'm playing on high because some options on ultra (for example shadow) don't run smooth on my rig.. but they are great to look at. Pretty D3-ish tho.


Gameplay:

The Gameplay is a bit monotone at some points. For example every dungeon has 5 unique challenges, yet they are all like Kill X Monster with Weapon type Y" "Kill X Monsters without taking damage" "Kill X Monster within Y Seconds of entering the Dungeon" but I believe that this will change (Note: It's Version 1.0.0 in a EA game).


Conclusion:

Victor Vran is a really great game which is in it's current phase of EA a solid game. The Graphics are good but a bit too Diablo-ish
date: the Combat System feels surprisingly good and smooth. The Roadmap also offers a lot of stuff you can expect in near future."

reviewText:
Victor Vran is an excellently crafted hack and slash RPG that does things a bit differently than your typical diablo like game and in a good way that shouldn't be missed.

The story is, ok let's get real nobody ever plays a hack and slash for the story, there are demons and such and it has good voice acting that paints a compelling enough backdrop for which to murder to your hearts content - that's all that really matters in that department.

The combat and mechanics around it are where it shines. There are a few different weapon archetypes (around 8) that all share movesets with one another - so if you find a sword, it will have the same moves as another sword you find, a rapier will have the same as a rapier, etc.  You can have 2 held weapons at once and most of the skills have a cooldown so you will dance between both weapons triggering cooldowns while dodging enemy attacks and unleashing demonic super moves.

You can equip yourself with:
Cards -Apply a passive bonus to you stats or cause things like explosions when you overkill an enemy
Demonic Ability - Active skills used after charging a meter, can do things from rain damage, shield, slow time and others.
Weapons - The various weapons all have different moves that feel very different when switching between styles.
Armor - The armor you choose can change heavily the focus of how you play causing you to either gain demon powers faster, give you more armor and others.

Everything that you can equip can also be modified via the transmuation (crafting) system allowing you to upgrade most things you find.

The game also boasts a challenge system that unlocks fairly early on (level 13) that you can turn on various bonuses for the enemies to increase the experience and drops you get from them but also increase the difficulty for you.

Each of the areas within the game has set challenges tied to it as well allowing you to try and do various challenges every stage for rewards - they may be things like kill this boss without using a potion, find 3 secret chests, kill so many enemies with a hammer and so on - these make the trek the each area all the more interesting and provide you with gold, experience and items should you choose to pursue them.

The game also has online capabilities but I have not played that so I can't weigh in on that particular aspect of the game.

Anyone who likes action games, diablo clones or RPG's should really probably give this game a look - and it even has a indie game price to make it all the more inticing (<20$ at launch)

reviewText: The game feels like a mash-up of Diablo/Torchlight, Bastion (narrator and player control), and Van Helsing. Victor Vran is a superb addition to ARPG games like Diablo and Torchlight, with minor differences that allow you control your character's movement using the keyboard and lets you jump and roll around. Attacking and using special attacks or spells is the same as in other games. The loot in this game is pretty limited with only a few different types of weapons and only a handful of armors to select. Leveling up is not as exciting as in other games as you merely only get health or destiny points, where destiny points allows you to equip different cards which all have different perks (this is where the majority of the character customization comes from). The game is ~20 hours long if you want to see all the areas and play the story in detail while finding all the secret chests scattered around each area. The game adds challenges for every area, which start out pretty fun but near the end of the game the challenges get ridiculous and can be frustrating. Once you beat all the regular challenges there are elite challenges that get unlocked which are even more insane. The game has a bottomless pit and an area that has a randomized dungeon to increase the longevity of the game, however the end game is shallow compared to other ARPG games. Overall, the game is a lot of fun, very well done and If you're looking for an ARPG game this is a must play.

reviewText:
This game is fantastic and a breath of fresh air in this genre.... almost to the point where it deserves its own genre.

Yes, it is a Hack & Slash.  Yes, it is an Action RPG.  However, it is like a mix of Bard's Tale (humor), Torchlight (graphics, music, tone), and Diablo (loot, polish)... but most importantly, the combat feels like Bastion.  It can be challenging, requires some tactical thought and planning, and timing.  It is very engaging and rewarding - hands down the best combat system of any game in this genre before that I'm personally aware of.

I cannot recommend this game enough if you are a fan of RPGs, Hack & Slash, etc.  It almost feels like an old-school Zelda game but with Diablo-like loot.

reviewText:
Set in the fictional land of Zagoravia, this action RPG adventure from Haemimont Games gets back to the genre's hack n' slash roots. Engaging combat and skill based gameplay are this title's cornerstone features in a crowded market. Utilise powerful aimed abilities, demonic magic and timed attacks as you jump, dodge and smash your way to victory.
Join Victor as he journeys deep into this monster infested kingdom in search of his lost friend and fellow hunter, Adrian. Along the way, encountering beautifully drawn and well voiced characters who help us uncover the truth about Zagoravia and the hideous beasts that plague it.

Victor Vran represents a departure from current trends in the genre, trading loot grinding for subtle, mechanic shifting gear choices that shape the way the player approaches the games many challenges. While it borrows much from esteemed contemporaries, such as Diablo, Torchlight and Path of Exile, Haemimont Games have managed to create their own unique take on the modern Action-RPG while also managing to invoke some of the spirit found in hack and slash classics like Blood Omen.

The graphics and art in the game are a real high point, perhaps eschewing the expense of fidelity for a dark and sombre, with a hint of the fantastic, style that is carried consistently throughout out the gameplay and story segments alike. The music is moody and subdued, matching the setting perfectly and complimenting the action with aplomb.

I highly recommend it and you can check out my Let's Play if you want to see the game in action:

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=493416711

reviewText: This review is for the final game. I've completed the first Act and have aquired the hex" system for increasing difficulty (explained below).\n\nAs a long time fan of the action RPG (ARPG) I'm always on the lookout for new entries in the genre that Diablo made famous. With some glaring exceptions
date: the ARPG over the last few years has not disappointed with games like Torchlight 2
recommended: The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing
hoursPlayed: and Diablo III (post auction house). I'm happy to report that Victor Vran is another excellent example of ARPG done right.\n\nGraphics: Let's start off with the least important (and least impressive) thing in this game. ARPGs rely on visual indicators to tell you what kind of attacks you are being subjected to and they can't clutter the screen with tons of words and icons like a MMO or traditional RPG. Victor Vran's art style is clean and fits the dark tone of the game
voteText: it's not visually amazing even with everything cranked to the max
helpfulPercent: but the information the game and its user interface delivers to the player is streamlined and I never had trouble figuring out what I was looking at or what exactly an attack was.\n\nSound: Fittingly spooky music
votesHelpful: good voice acting (the main character sounds remarkably like Geralt of Rivia)
votesTotal: and some really "meta" lines from the narrator (which you will either love or despise
votesFunny: believe me). The weapon attacks sound great from the boom of the shotgun to the weighty thumps of the hammer.\n\nGameplay: Ok
commentsCount: let's get down to what really counts here. What makes this game worth playing amongst its peers? The action it puts back in ARPG. Victor can run and jump
column16: roll deftly
column17: and leap down from ledges to explore lower areas. The gameplay feels great and the controller interface is nice and smooth without taking away from mouse-driven staples like clicking away frantically at monsters. The skills are weapon based
column18: but the game really encourages you to switch weapons often and doesn't use a skill tree so you're always going to be very efficient with every skill in the game (more or less depending on your other gear synergy
column19: of course). Fans of the genre may lament the lack of a sprawling skill tree with tons of customization options
column20: but this game places skill above build and you will need to actually learn how each skill interacts to clear all the "kill monsters with x weapon" challenges.\n\nVictor can also equip potions and bombs (on cooldowns
column21: no spamming) as well as two magic spells called Demonic Powers. These powers range from beneficial auras to meteors that fall from the sky. The destiny cards you find or get at level-up grant your passives and can be swapped on the fly to mess with your build. There are also outfits that change how your demon power is restored (amongst other bonuses) so there is plenty to tinker with even without the skill tree.\n\nThe most interesting thing for me about the gameplay was the challenge system. Each map has a few challenges to complete that really direct your gameplay. The effect of these challenges cannot be understated because their presence keeps the game from feeling repetitive. On one map you may be trying not to take a single hit and on the next you may need to use a weapon that you haven't mastered yet. Past level 12 you pick up "hexes" which are similar to Bastion's gods or Transistor's limiters in that they reward you with greater prizes for suffering buffs to your foes and debuffs to you. The rewards are so amazing that I was tempted to leave them on
column22: and they even have a leveling mechanic of their own to intice completionists.\n\nVictor Vran is a lot of fun. I don't know how long the game will remain fresh without different classes and skill trees
column23: but for the money to time ratio
column24: it's a definite "buy"."

reviewText:
I'll start of with saying hack 'n slash games are not really my thing. Once in while i do feel like playing one. After reading some positive reviews i decided to pick up Victor Vran during a sale. Here my pros and cons:

Pros:- Co-op (4 players) - I have played this game in solo mode but i think playing this in co-op would make it more enjoyable.
- Different difficulty settings - Added hexes for even more challeging gameplay.
- Voice acting - The voice acting is hilarious at times.

Cons:- Limited character development - Yes, you can change your weapons and subsequently your skills but it still is too limited in my opinion.
- The biggest drawback of the game is the repetetiveness - I got bored about 20+ hours in. If it wasnt for some achievement hunting i would have dropped the game right there.

Verdict:Pick up when on sale 7/10
