reviewText:
Title says it all: it's an ARPG, a genre you can't talk about without mentionning Diablo at some point of the time.
The reason is pretty obvious, Diablo was really the pinnacle of the genre. Especially Diablo II, but that's my opinion.

Thing is, Diablo II was so damn good it became hard to *really* enjoy the genre for more than a few hours, whereas most fans of the genre probably spent hundreds, if not thousands hours into Diablo.

Yet many tried, and many failed. Titan Quest was good and full of good ideas, but due to the lack of promotion and refined online, it didn't work. Torchlight was boring after a playthrough. Plus, it was way too easy to cheat. Van Helsing had its moments, but then again it was so easy to cheat and so short people didn't stick to it. I could mention more and more, but you probably get the idea.

What really differentiates this one from the others, you may ask?
That's the point of this game really. One of the reasons Diablo II succeeded was that the online pretty much prevented cheating (though there were some shady methods, but certainly not as easy and risk free as duplicating your save). Another is that getting loot was damn easy. Sure, the drop rates were terribly low but running a boss again and again was so easy that it pretty much became the point of playing Diablo. Back then, farming was called MF running.
Here, in Victor Vran, I'm not exactly sure about the real profitability of running boss instances over and over, but the game definitely makes up for it.

Here's how.
1) Loot. No good ARPG game without a good loot system. Man, is this one satisfying.
What makes up for the MF runs are not only the MF runs themselves, but also a fantastic addition under the form of bounties and treasure hunts. Basically, you and people can share keys under the chat that you can activate to either receive a bounty or a treasure hunt map. To complete them, you have to visit some maps and either kill some bosses or fetch treasure hints. Upon completing the tasks, you'll get some good loot.
And that's the thing really. This is just the dose of addicting farming an ARPG needs to succeed. Something that keeps you playing and puts you under pressure because the bounties are time limited. As a result, you might feel like doing them with buddies. Oh yeah, there's some online.

2) Online. First of all, whether you prefer playing solo or online with some people, you can still get access to the chat. Meaning you'll get all those damn keys even if you feel like being alone. I haven't tried the game in COOP mode just yet, but I don't see this being anything else than awesome. However, I'm not sure how the loot gets splitted, so you might wanna stick to your friends.

3) Equipement. This is kind of bothering. While there's a neat addition in the form of cards that you can equip to add a various set of features to your build, such as life leech, more melee / ranged damage or cast damage whenever you get it, I'm a bit saddened by the fact there's only one slot for armor. Yep. No gloves, no helmet, just your armor. That said, you can still personnalize your character with the sets of outfits and dye them according to your preference.
Also, the skills are weapon based. How does this translate to gameplay?

4) Gameplay. One of the strong features of Diablo II was that you could be pretty much anything. Your build was the one you decided to use, as even sorceress could be damn powerful in melee. This isn't the case in Victor Vran.
The skills being weapon based, your build is kind of on rails based on which set of weapons you prefer. Set, because it's so damn easy to switch to your other weapon that you are pretty much going to use both sets of skills.
With that being said, Victor Vran is no common hunter as he can uses to demon powers" which are two bonus spells. Bonus spells that you can actually choose! So in the end
date: there are some build possibilities. Berserk Aura
hoursPlayed: gives you better damage which is pretty much handy in every scenario. If you're more of a melee guy
voteText: Diamond adds you another layer of life in the form of armor. If you wanna stick to the spells
helpfulPercent: I'm sure Meteors will handle that boss just fine.\nThe demon powers use your second bar
votesHelpful:
called the Overdrive. This thing is pretty much based on your outfit which gives it a critical importance. Whether you prefer to gain overdrive over time or after each kill is up to you.

6) Misc.
The game story is quite nice. Hard to tell much about it without spoiling anything

reviewText:
Played the GOG version a lot before I also bought the Steam version so I have around 14 more hours than it says I do. Basically, this game is FUN. It might not be perfect, but it does a great job at entertaining.

+ The game is fun as hell, the levels mostly varied, and things remain largely fresh for a lot of the time.
+ It's an Action RPG, best played with a Controller (from my perspective) but KB+M is just as good. There aren't too many good ARPGs around these days.
+ The weapons are interesting and all different, especially some of the late-game weapons.
+ VV is responsive and easy to play with, you aren't likely to die because you tripped over your own feet
+ Did I mention this game is fun? Imagine Diablo's hack-n-slash, except each button press is a single attack instead of having to click and hold to automatically attack until the enemy is dead. Think Isometric God of War.
+ Geralt of Rivia is in it. Kinda.

- The game, however, can be boring in parts. You go through enemy after enemy after enemy and they never seem to stop. The most annoying thing? Some of them require a critical hit to die properly; if they're just hit normally, they break apart and come back together again as good as new, so they need to be killed again (although a normal hit will do it that time). There's no way to guarantee the final blow will be critical, although you can improve your chances of a critical several ways.
- It's less RPG than I'd like. Yes, a deck of cards can be used to increase percentages: Damage, Crit Hit chance, Defense, etc. and outfits act slightly differently (your mana" for Demon Powers is built up either by Critical hits
recommended: or over time by itself depending on which outfit you choose). Pick the wrong outfit
hoursPlayed: and there's no changing your mind 10 minutes later - you're stuck with it for a long time. The problem is there really is no traditional skill progression so to speak
voteText: it's all just increased arbitrarily by pickups.\n- I don't find Demon Powers all that useful
helpfulPercent: at least not until they're upgraded significantly. I also wish weapons were balanced differently: You can hit multiple enemies with a sword or hammer
votesHelpful: but a shotgun? Nope
votesTotal: not unless it's using one of its "Special abilities".\n\nAll in all
votesFunny: great game
commentsCount: I highly recommend you give it a go
column16: it's fun to pass some time with and I can guarantee you'll be coming back to it for a long time to come."

reviewText:
This game is fantastic and a breath of fresh air in this genre.... almost to the point where it deserves its own genre.

Yes, it is a Hack & Slash.  Yes, it is an Action RPG.  However, it is like a mix of Bard's Tale (humor), Torchlight (graphics, music, tone), and Diablo (loot, polish)... but most importantly, the combat feels like Bastion.  It can be challenging, requires some tactical thought and planning, and timing.  It is very engaging and rewarding - hands down the best combat system of any game in this genre before that I'm personally aware of.

I cannot recommend this game enough if you are a fan of RPGs, Hack & Slash, etc.  It almost feels like an old-school Zelda game but with Diablo-like loot.

reviewText: I bought the game in a humble bundle offer. Actually, I bought the whole bundle just for Victor Vran and I didn't regret it. reviewText:
Editting my review to try to make an even stronger recommendation.

The fact is, this game has a remarkable amount of engaging gameplay hooks.  Clearly, a truckload of thought was put in to how each weapon would have different timing and triggers within it's own move-set.  It really keeps you engaged to the action, and rewards you greatly for using your skills intentionally (rather than just mindlessly mashing buttons.)

The customization options (with the fate cards, and the combination of weapons you will equip) allow for some very thoughtful and useful choices.

I don't make a habit of ever reviewing Steam games - but this one is just so impressive in the execution.  Stick with it, maybe crank the difficulty up a notch or two, and push yourself - this game can be rewarding in the same way as Dark Souls or Bloodborne.

reviewText:
Victor Vran is pretty much your generic RPG. The game is fun to play and enjoyable in most aspects, but it's not anything special.  I do recommend this game for it's positive traits, but know ahead of time that there are also some considerable negative traits.

You have a third-person isometric camera view that you can rotate around your character. You kill things, they drop loot. Difficulty level can be adjusted with any combination of 5 hexes that will cause you to lose health, increase movement speed or attack of enemies, etc. Each area in the map has secrets to find and optional challenges to complete that grant loot, experience, or gold. Your character can equip two weapons, an outfit, two special abilities, two potions, and up to 5/6 cards that grant various perks. Each of these items have their own traits, and you can swap them out from the inventory menu while out in a level, so you can essentially customize your character to exactly suit your play style. You will occasionally find bounties and treasure maps that require you to visit 3 to 5 areas in the map in order to get even more bonus loot. I felt all of these elements meshed together very well to create a fairly enjoyable game. The game also runs incredibly smooth with no lag or frame rate drops to speak of.

By the way, your character also has the ability to jump, which I seldom seen in RPGs. Jumping is great! It offers a nice way to bypass a group of enemies, and it integrates very well for finding secrets.

Despite all those aspects that I enjoyed, there were far too many aspects I didn't enjoy:

Menu controls are not intuitive, especially when using a controller. I switched to keyboard and mouse every time I went into my inventory or traded with a merchant.

Leveling up requires you to access the inventory screen and choose 1 of 3 bonuses you get for leveling up. If you want to do this while in a map, your character will continue to be attacked while you are stuck navigating through 3 menu screens before the level up is complete. The game should instead just give you the stat bonus for the level and let you choose the item bonus later, but instead you have to choose your bonus before you get the stats increase.

The thing that completely ruins this game for me is the inventory management. This is hands down the number one reason you would NOT want to play this game. Early on, you have to spend an awful lot of time managing your inventory if you want to always be carrying the best gear. You pick up so many weapons early in the game that you're almost guaranteed to get something that is better than what you're currently using. Later in the game, monsters get more powerful but Rare and Legendary items don't get any stronger. This means you are unable to keep up with the growing difficulty in defeating monsters, causing you to die more often or constantly run away from a fight so you can heal. To account for this, you have the ability to Transmute weapons and items, making them stronger or improving their secondary effects. The problem here is that it takes hundreds of items to level up a pair of weapons to max stats, so if you later find a weapon you like better, you have to repeat the process. AND, you can only increase the stats of an item by using items of equal rarity or better. This means legendary weapons require legendary items in order to level up. In the 26 hours we played, I found a total of 9 legendary weapons, so it was impossible for me to level up any of them any considerable amount.

Transmutation is clearly meant to be a key element of this game, but I hated it. The game punishes you for not choosing a single weapon and sticking with it forever. I liked playing with the Hammer, Rapier, Shotgun, and Mortar, each of which has a particular situation they are well-suited for. Unfortunately, Transmutation is designed so that I must pick one of those to use at all times, unless I want to spend another 20 hours getting enough legendary items to upgrade all of them.

If you play through the game once to finish the story, it will be fun. If you try to actually level up your character in a way that suits your play style, you'll end up grinding for hours through the same level trying to find more and more items to use in Transmutation. I personally hate grinding, especially since now the only reason to get better weapons is so I can replay levels I've already completed. No thanks!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It is far for perfect, but it feels extremely enjoyable. An arpg with wasd movement and dodge.

If you feel it is too easy, at level 12 you will unlock the dificulty modifiers, which allow you to increase the dificulty and get higher rewards. (Ex. Some monsters will be elites. Another modifier makes the monsters have regenerating health which makes the fighting so much more intense, making you play more aggressive)

Plays great both with the keyboard and mouse, and with a Xbox controller

It lacks the variety of Diablo or Torchlight, but it is a great game regardless.
voteText: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Very solid and addictive game. Game mechanic is easy to understand, yet it takes time to master. No classes, but variaty comes from combination of outfit, chosen weapon, demonic powers, cards and playstyle. 3 difficulties, solid campain with 40+ maps (some of them are optional) with challenges and secrets. Even a bit of endgame for a lasting pleasure!

It's Diablo+Painkiller (don't ask me why) mix with nice music, great graphics and immersive combat. Add to it cooperative game, quick support (I was very surprised to find a bug, report it and it was fixed in next patch which comes just few days after), daily randomly generated map, infinite descending mode, 3 difficulties....

Player base it not big, still there are good chances for a random cooperative fun (for those who don't have friends.. haha) or a question answered by another player (even in single player game chat is enabled). Open game if you need help (and you may need it on hard difficulty, unless top geared). Share treasure hunt/bounties with other players (and get their to complete and get rewarded with shinies).

reviewText:
To be honest - bought this game out of boredom and a price tag.

One of the best 20 hrs i spent on any game so far.
Simple, but very clever ARPG that is mainly focused not on stats and builds, but on how you actually behave in combat (which is intense and satisfying).

Add an option to boost the enemies on-the-go" (5 different Hexes which will make your life harder) and the pack of challenges for each map - and you're good to go.

Probably will give it another playthrough just to hit lvl 50.

9/10"

reviewText:
I'm only a couple hours in but I am really enjoying this thus far and wanted to get a review out while it was on sale.  As a 'Living Room Couch' PC gamer, Victor Vran certaintly scratches the itch I have of wanting a Diabloesque action RPG that can be played comfortably with a controller and easy on the eyes as well since I am using a 1080p television.  Smooth gameplay, addicting side quest missions, great graphics and a simple to use UI.  Plus any game that features the suave voice of Geralt of Rivia is A-OK in my books.  I couldn't really get into the Van Helsing games that are also in the genre and didn't feel the controls were as well done in those either...Victor Vran does a much better job, and they aren't nearly as 'clunky'.

At the moment the big cons for me would be:

- Lack of any in depth skill trees.
- Lack of overall character customization.

Well worth the current $10 sale price.
voteText: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Amazing game, a truly different ARPG experience.

Classic story, classic Van Helsing universe, it's the gameplay that makes it shine:
instead of weapons having almost no effect on the skills of the character (like most ARPG out there), the skills available to use here will depend (almost exclusively) on the type of weapon equipped.

This means that you will swap weapon types often to fit every situation: sometimes it's better to go 1vs1 with a Rapier, sometimes you'll need a good old Hammer to crush those swarming spiders, and sometimes you prefer to stay the hell away using a Lightning Gun.
Also, in this game you can jump and evade by rolling over.

The consequence of those design choices is that it's far more action-packed than any Diablo or Diablo-like game, and that your personal skill actually matters. Yes, you can be good" at this game
date: and it will make the difference.\nI should mention that I never tried the normal mode
recommended: started in hard mode and loved it.\n\n10/10

reviewText:
EDIT: ran out of things to do in the game.  good but short.  worth the sale price for sure, full price if you have plenty of $.


read the negative reviews when i saw the sale.
can rebutt the neg feedback right away:
1) you can control the difficulty of the game at will.
2) i use kb/m and was able to remap all keys (can't speak for controller).
3) if you don't like smashing hordes of monstars, this game and others like it probably are not for you.  if you liked titan quests, sacreds, diablos, poe, van halen, torchlights, ultima 1 (still the best).  this game will be good for you;  no brainer at the sale price.

graphics good.

acti0n smooth, animations accurate.

gameplay fun.  overall map has a mario 64 feel with earning stars and finding secret treasures.  will have to replay to earn them all.

keeps you on your toes because you need to be smart and on time.  use  'hex cards' that instantly add difficulty to the map you're on in exchange for more xp/item chance.  some challenges require use of them.

will update as i progress thru the game.

playing with others is smooth mostly, and more fun.

once you are used to the transmog cube process, upgrading your cards and gear will help to do enough dps/survive for all hexes.

the bounties and treasure hunts help keep things fresh... until I ran out.  now there is limited interest in continuing to mess around with plain/elite challenges.

when you complete a treasure/bounty the poster in your inventory turns gray, and you can trans 3 of these for a 'memento of zagarovia', which have no purpose yet.  these can be progressively combined into higher tiers, guess will be a mat for something some day.

all in all, very fun until there is nothing new to do.

reviewText: With Victor Vran, you're getting a really cool game with beautiful environmants and plenty of loot opportunities. If you're looking for an ARPG with vast skill trees, and everchanging character gear, then Victor Vran is not for you. The simplistic mechanics and straight forward controls makes this game different, fun and pretty addicting. There are all kinds of common loot along with some sweet legendary type rare items to be found. I personally like the challenge goals that exist in each area which give you bonus loot, gold and XP. Its a nice insentive to spend some time in those areas.\n\nOverall Victor Vran is a solid game and a nice step away" from the traditional ARPG's out there. At the time of writing this
date: the price dropped to $9.99 which is a steal for a game like this. Give Victor Vran a shot!\n\nCheers!"

reviewText:
overall, my experience with Victor Vran has been positive. instead of game like Diablo, which are very large, open areas pretending to be small, enclosed ones, Victor Vran has a mix of both closed, and open areas, with varied terrain, and a range of weapons that have unique physics which accomodate or are penalized based on them. the mortar, for instance, is very good from above, but more difficult to aim from below, especially on the side.

there are an array of weapons that vary greatly. there's the rapier, a single target, close range weapon. this weapon offers high armor penetration, and quick strikes, allowing you to dodge in and out and pick off tough enemies first. then there's the hammer, a weapon whose sole job is to slowly smash the ground into crowds of enemies, to do large amounts of damage. personally, I think the hammer needs armor penetration, given the role of combat hammers vs. armor historically, but that's just my opinion. the hammer also compliments other weapons as one of its attacks finishes with a life steal buff that remains when you switch weapons. the sword is a weapon that is excels when you time your attacks and special attacks properly. the third swing of your sword makes enemies vulnerable, making the next attack against them a critical, and your main special attack has its cooldown reset on critical, allowing you to endlessly cycle your attacks. mess up on your cycle, however, and you suffer greatly, as there is a delay at the end of your third swing, like if you fail at striking effectively with a real sword. every weapon has a unique playstyle to it, and you can equip two at a time, and cycle through the two you have equipped, letting you compliment your attacks.

Victor Vran doesn't collect armor in the way that traditional RPGs do, assembling them piece by piece, discarding them as you level. the weapon system does that, and you can grind out new weapons forever. Victor doesn't concern himself on grinding out the perfect buckler to accompany his shiny chestplate. no, he's satisfied with an outfit that provides him with passive bonuses, and altering his playstyle. to compensate, he collects demon cards, which grant him further passive bonuses, some to him, some to his strikes, and others are penalties that he applies to those he strikes, or that strike him. one argument against Victor Vran is the simplicity of the equipment system, but those claims are made by those who have not gone very deep into raising the power of their outfits, or their demon cards.

there is a potion and bomb system that is very simplistic. I was, and still am underwhelmed by the effectiveness of bombs, for the same reason I am for the levellable 'potion' - the medkit. they use static numbers for damage and healing, rather than a percentage, like ever other potion does. this makes them useful early in the game, but they quickly lose usefulness, especially if you play on a higher difficulty.

lastly, there's a supplimental active ability system in demon powers. there are four main groups of demon powers. the first is the direct attacks group. these are meteor, shockwave, and boomerang. these abilities don't interrupt your regular attacks, and some have secondary effects. the second group is sustained direct damage attacks. in this group are dark mist (turn into a cloud of poison, weakening and damaging enemies), sunray (fire a continuous beam from your hands), and purging flame (control a zone of moving flames, damaging enemies in an AoE). the third group is passive effects. in this group are sanguine aura (health regen/armor), berserk aura (+damage to everyone in range, even mobs), and diamond (damage absorb/ranged reflect). the last group is utility. in this one is blink (teleport, damage a single enemy, and make him vulnerable), pull (shoot out a number of projectiles, pulling them to you, and stunning them for a period of time), and time bubble (create a zone in which enemies and enemy projectiles are slowed, but friendlies and friendly projectiles are not). I find that the powers in which you lose the ability to be active aren't powerful enough to justify using them, while enemies that use them don't have to lose the ability to be acive. in particular, enemies have the ability to place a sunray that spins outward slowly from a focal point, that you do not.

the difficulty system is achieved in the way of 'hexes' that make enemies more difficult, but also provide more experience and loot (a la Bastion, et al). there is also a hard mode, which turns on all hexes and supposedly provides some other buff to enemies, but I've been unable to locate any documentation about this to confirm it.

in Victor Vran, you can also jump, which is useful both from a time saving standpoint (as in other games, you would have to go all the way around, just to get over that stupid railing), and an exploration one (to find secret areas). you can wall vault up to twice before landing, which means you can scale some two-wall areas to reach otherwise unreachable areas, some hidden, and some not. this helps to eliminate a lot of wasted time, and also makes level design less bland. dodging is also a very important mechanic, and allows you to both travel faster (Victor Vran's version of the FPS bunnyhop), and also avoid enemy attacks. it immediately interrupts attacks, which is a welcome mechanic, one that some games lack (Fight the Dragon, I'm looking at you).

it runs reasonably well on my system, using Arch Linux, but there have been some technical issues. principally, F1 (used to file a bug report) has created an instant crash on Linux for some time, and has still not been addressed. former incarnations of the game also seemed to be a bit more optimized, and there are some random crashing and networking issues.

reviewText: There's a GebaN in the game. You can dance (Gundam style) with skeletons. You can fight monsters with a lightsaber. It's an ARPG wherein you can actually jump up and down areas (or just jump as you please). It's a parody of Van Helsing of sorts and it's voiced by none other than Geralt of Rivia....and somehow all of this doesn't make it feel any less like a classic RPG styled game.

reviewText:
When I started playing I didn't expect much, it turned to be one of the best arpg I've played in years.
The combat system it's more action oriented than diablo, you will need to dodge and jump while the movement is assigned to the Wasd keys, in alternative you can use the gamepad which works really well.
If you played guild wars 2 you already know how the skill system works : you get abilities based on the weapons you choose, you can carry 2 and switch between them any moment.
It's fun both in single and multilayer (4 players max), so far I played 3 hours on it and no lag at all.
Just don't expect the millions items that diablo make fall on you, here the choices in both items type and stats are very limited, still shows a good amount of personalization, this isn't bad, it's just not your usual arpg.
Overall a great game, fair price, if you like the genre go for it.
voteText: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Victor Vran is a rather dark but comical ARPG that isn't afraid about taking the mick out of itself. If you're reading this you probably already know what the game is. You're a demon hunter called to investigate a city overrun by demons.

While I'm writing this review I haven't finished the game yet. I'm playing this game with a friend of mine in coop. I have played a lot of its competitors like Diablo, Sacred, Torchlight and what not. I will refer to them frequently.

The game has quiet a lot to offer, hence while I would recommend it.

Graphics:
The graphics are slightly more demanding than Diablo 3, but the game runs fluid on a mediocre system. It looks pretty and I haven't had a single graphical glitch during my sessions.

Difficulty:
I played the game on normal and it's a fair difficulty. Just as a reminder I play multiplayer not solo. So the game might be a lot more difficult in single player. There're three difficulty levels: Casual, Normal and Hard. For an even further challenge you can even play Hardcore (perma-death). During my sessions I died quite a lot, but I'll come back to that later...

Audio:
The voice over is awesome. The narrator did an incredibly good job capturing the atmosphere of the game. Victor tends to talk to himself a lot, refering to the voice in his head as headman. Those monologues are brilliant sometimes. The downside is, that all the other characters fade a bit in his shadow.
The musical score is good, but nothing to write home about.
I noticed a crackling sound every now and then which is quite annoying. Haven't found a fix yet.

Gameplay:
The gameplay is quite different from what I was used to. There are no classes or races, just Victor Vran. But there is still room for some customization. You can choose from an arsenal of different weapons (e.g. Rapier, Sword, Hammer, Shotgun). Each weapon has a different skill set: a standard attack and two special abilities. You can equip up to two weapons simultaneously. Swapping weapons during a fight is just one click. There is no classic magic system. Instead you have a demon power item which you can equip two of. It's a little like Sacred 2, tho you cannot upgrade those runes". Last but not least
date: there's armor which you can get by reaching a certain level.\nYou can carry around two different sets of items. One of which is usually occupied by the health pots. You can equip buff potions
recommended: bombs and medi kits as well.\nFinally there are destiny cards which further enhances your stats (e.g. critical chance
voteText: health).\n\nOf all the equipment there're four different qualities. White
helpfulPercent: Green
votesHelpful: Gold and Purple. So no real difference to all the other ARPGs out there. Only difference are the destiny cards. Some of them have a slightly glowing effect to them. Those are divine cards
votesTotal: which have some additional effects.\n\nThe maps are really great. Every map has a different medieval theme and they look gorgeous. There is no random map generation tho
votesFunny: so replay value is limited. Each map has five challenges
commentsCount: which give bonus XP
column16: gold or items. Some want you to defeat champions
column17: others to achieve a certain number of kills with one weapon. Later some need you to activate hexes
column18:
which either buff monsters or debuff you.

Also every map has a set number of secrets to find. Those are item or gold chests.

The number of different enemies seems a bit limited so far. Most share the same model and have just a few different animations. There're some hilarious gimmicks
column19:
but a few more different mobs wouldn't hurt the game at all.

Controls:
And here comes the big let down. The controls are abysmal at best. There're two different control sets. Normal and Mouse Movement. Normal is WASD movement control
column20: which is... well... you might get used to it... I simply can't. I played every ARPG on god's planet with mouse movement... why you might think not in this game? Well... to be honest the mouse movement is totally broken. You might remember Diablo. You click with your left mouse button and the character moves to this position. You hold the left mouse button and the character moves in the direction your mouse cursor points. This totally holds true for this game
column21: but... not really. The most distinct feature of Victor Vran
column22: namely elevation and jumping
column23: made a total mess of that. I have been in High Quarter yesterday. To reach a certain secret chest you have to jump up over a few balconies and down on a roof. Sounds easy... yeah... no! The game has a problem calculating the exact position of your movement order. I was walking on the roof. On the backside of the mansion was an alleyway. You can access it if you walk around the house. But while I was clicking on the roof
column24: the game thought I clicked on the alleyway behind the house. So Victor moved in every direction instead of the one I was pointing at. Also jumping over fences or hedges can get frustrating if you're not at the right angle or distance. The only workaround is
column25: to constantly rotate the camera in a position where there're no obstacles. As much as I love this game
column26: this really makes me want to rage quit sometimes.\n\nI really enjoy the game so far. But the controls need a serious overhaul."

reviewText: Great arpg! The thing I love especially is the ability to completely play with a mouse. To most that would seem tedious and boring, but for me it's a relief. I can only use one hand, so games where you usually have to block/dodge etc. can be hard to do if it requires both keyboard and mouse to execute a certain action that involves moving and blocking/dodging at the same time. The fact that one can actually choose from 3 different options on how to play the game is something more developers should implement in their games. The choice of HOW to play, and make it therefore also more easy for those who love to play games, but can only use one hand. Diablo III is also very playable with one hand. Grim Dawn is another. There are games that are very playable. But the majority of cool games alas do not support it so far. I can now run, hack, slash and dodge without having to go back and forth from keybord to mouse. :)

reviewText:
The core gameplay is a lot of fun and much faster paced than other games in the genre. Can't expect everything -- this is an alpha purchase as you should know.

Still, I'm giving it a positive review because it gets frequent, large updates and shows a ton of promise.

Post Release Edit: The game has a lot more polish and a ton of more features (including a new weapon class and local co-op mode) on the way. Level ups come far more frequently than other games in the genre and plenty of good customization options exist to define your character. All-in-all, I definitely feel like I'm getting my money's worth on this one.

reviewText:
Victor Vran is a rather dark but comical ARPG that isn't afraid about taking the mick out of itself. If you're reading this you probably already know what the game is. You're a demon hunter called to investigate a city overrun by demons.

While I'm writing this review I haven't finished the game yet. I'm playing this game with a friend of mine in coop. I have played a lot of its competitors like Diablo, Sacred, Torchlight and what not. I will refer to them frequently.

The game has quiet a lot to offer, hence while I would recommend it.

Graphics:
The graphics are slightly more demanding than Diablo 3, but the game runs fluid on a mediocre system. It looks pretty and I haven't had a single graphical glitch during my sessions.

Difficulty:
I played the game on normal and it's a fair difficulty. Just as a reminder I play multiplayer not solo. So the game might be a lot more difficult in single player. There're three difficulty levels: Casual, Normal and Hard. For an even further challenge you can even play Hardcore (perma-death). During my sessions I died quite a lot, but I'll come back to that later...

Audio:
The voice over is awesome. The narrator did an incredibly good job capturing the atmosphere of the game. Victor tends to talk to himself a lot, refering to the voice in his head as headman. Those monologues are brilliant sometimes. The downside is, that all the other characters fade a bit in his shadow.
The musical score is good, but nothing to write home about.
I noticed a crackling sound every now and then which is quite annoying. Haven't found a fix yet.

Gameplay:
The gameplay is quite different from what I was used to. There are no classes or races, just Victor Vran. But there is still room for some customization. You can choose from an arsenal of different weapons (e.g. Rapier, Sword, Hammer, Shotgun). Each weapon has a different skill set: a standard attack and two special abilities. You can equip up to two weapons simultaneously. Swapping weapons during a fight is just one click. There is no classic magic system. Instead you have a demon power item which you can equip two of. It's a little like Sacred 2, tho you cannot upgrade those runes". Last but not least
date: there's armor which you can get by reaching a certain level.\nYou can carry around two different sets of items. One of which is usually occupied by the health pots. You can equip buff potions
recommended: bombs and medi kits as well.\nFinally there are destiny cards which further enhances your stats (e.g. critical chance
voteText: health).\n\nOf all the equipment there're four different qualities. White
helpfulPercent: Green
votesHelpful: Gold and Purple. So no real difference to all the other ARPGs out there. Only difference are the destiny cards. Some of them have a slightly glowing effect to them. Those are divine cards
votesTotal: which have some additional effects.\n\nThe maps are really great. Every map has a different medieval theme and they look gorgeous. There is no random map generation tho
votesFunny: so replay value is limited. Each map has five challenges
commentsCount: which give bonus XP
column16: gold or items. Some want you to defeat champions
column17: others to achieve a certain number of kills with one weapon. Later some need you to activate hexes
column18:
which either buff monsters or debuff you.

Also every map has a set number of secrets to find. Those are item or gold chests.

The number of different enemies seems a bit limited so far. Most share the same model and have just a few different animations. There're some hilarious gimmicks
column19:
but a few more different mobs wouldn't hurt the game at all.

Controls:
And here comes the big let down. The controls are abysmal at best. There're two different control sets. Normal and Mouse Movement. Normal is WASD movement control
column20: which is... well... you might get used to it... I simply can't. I played every ARPG on god's planet with mouse movement... why you might think not in this game? Well... to be honest the mouse movement is totally broken. You might remember Diablo. You click with your left mouse button and the character moves to this position. You hold the left mouse button and the character moves in the direction your mouse cursor points. This totally holds true for this game
column21: but... not really. The most distinct feature of Victor Vran
column22: namely elevation and jumping

The game has a problem calculating the exact position of your movement order. I was walking on the roof. On the backside of the mansion was an alleyway. You can access it if you walk around the house. But while I was clicking on the roof

reviewText: Great arpg! The thing I love especially is the ability to completely play with a mouse. To most that would seem tedious and boring, but for me it's a relief. I can only use one hand, so games where you usually have to block/dodge etc. can be hard to do if it requires both keyboard and mouse to execute a certain action that involves moving and blocking/dodging at the same time. The fact that one can actually choose from 3 different options on how to play the game is something more developers should implement in their games. The choice of HOW to play, and make it therefore also more easy for those who love to play games, but can only use one hand. Diablo III is also very playable with one hand. Grim Dawn is another. There are games that are very playable. But the majority of cool games alas do not support it so far. I can now run, hack, slash and dodge without having to go back and forth from keybord to mouse. :)

reviewText:
Sick of the Same boring hack and slash RPGS?  If so this game will take away the blues.

This team nailed it. This is what we needed in the world of hack and slash RPGS. I am having so much fun with this game. Introducing jumping + wall jumping WOW. Its about time a developers actually took this genre grew some balls and did something totally off the wall, and I mean that literally. Good for you guys. Very brave, but you nailed it.

Also great controller + keyboard / mouse support. I am having so much fun with this game.

Graphically I also think they nailed it.  Beautiful castle and dungeon environments.  Vibrant colors.

Again thank you for thinking outside the box and making an amazing game. Hope there is more to come for this game.  I would recommend this game to anyone that is sick of the norm" hack and slash RPGS.

Hell even Totalbiscuit liked it.  See his quick look below.  This game is well worth your while.

8/10 for me guys. Keep up the good work.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1KlZkAZILZc"

reviewText:
The voice acting.. The humour.. This game is perfect.

If you like games like the Diablo series, Torchlight, and other similar games, combined with good action and silly humour, this game is a must buy.

It starts off like any other game. You are Victor, a Demon Hunter, whose quest is to search for a close friend in the city of Zagoravia. As you go through the tutorial, you'll learn more and more techniques, from jumping to dodging, using demon powers and learning the skills of several weapon types. Very unique compared to other, similar games.

The game at first seem rather serious, but there are many hidden objects in the game that says otherwise.

From Skyrim jokes to Dancing Skeletons, literally doing the Gangnam Style, this game can have some strange moments, and yet, without completely losing the point.
The voice acting is also supreme, in fact, you might know some of the actors. Victor, for example, is voiced by Doug Cockle, best known for voicing Geralt of Rivia from the Witcher series.

In the end, this game is fantastic. The price isn't that heavy for a newly released game, so I'd highly recommend it.

reviewText:
Ok so this game is good, and here is why:

One word... balls.

I got a legendary lightning gun/lightning card drop that made my lightning balls have hardly any cooldown.  I ran around, balls to the wall crazy, just shooting out as many balls as I possibly could.  These balls will damage you and your allies, so my partner who was balls deep in a melee spec was rolling around desperately trying to avoid my hot, electric balls.  I couldn't stop, though.  Once you go ball spec that's all you can ever do.  I became a ball master.  Dragon Ball VV up in here (VV as in Victor Vran, keep up people.)

Until I got a legendary mortar.

A legendary mortar that shot exploding chickens.

A cannon that shoots exploding chickens everywhere, as many times as you can push the button.

Yep, changed my spec to the explosive poultry/balls nasty spec.

I love you Victor Vran.

reviewText:
Surprisingly good game. I bought it by chance, as there was no hype about it, and soon realized that I got a gem.
Additionally to good graphics, great soundtrack and awesome refreshing game mechanics it offers good story for an action RPG and one of the best (if not the very best) support for gamepad. Don't get me wrong, playing with mouse and keyboard is not worse, but there are not so many PC games that support controller so good. Plus it's very stylish and atmospheric. The last but not the least, the game runs without any bugs.

The only important drawback is that game is short and has not enough replay value. There are no real side quests, and for me additional challenges" are not so interesting. I've just finished it first time

reviewText: This game is surprisingly addictive.  I haven't had this much fun playing a PC-arpg in years.  The weapons are unique and although you play as the same character you truly can make Victor your own.  I played this locally with three other people and each of our builds were unique.  After you beat a dungeon you can replay it again on a harder difficultly for a more challenging experience with varying rewards.  The Bottomless Pit challenges you like no other, with endless waves of monsters and rewards for each level you descend.\n\nI highly recommend this.  For just 19.99 you are going to get at least 30+ hours worth of enjoyable gameplay out of it.  Plus they just added DLC.

reviewText:
Surprisingly well made hack and slash game. The combat feels rewarding, though at times it can be repetitive, but the polish makes up for it. Works perfectly with a controller, and even inventory management works well. It's clear the developer wanted the experience to be as smooth on controller as on K+M.

It is not a co-op game at heart. Co-op was tacked on after the fact and it is evident. Quests track separately, loot tracks separately, objectives track separately. Basically, you can play with another person, but you gain nothing. It's so separate that I stopped bothering and went to single player mode.

Is it worth $20? For the work the devs put in: absolutely. There's a lot of content here and lots of areas to have fun in. I will say that this game is more for completionist, who enjoy finding all the secrets in an area, or meeting all level objectives. If you're not into that, then you'll simply run through each level, and will most likely end up bored. For completionists, there's a lot of depth and content here.

If the game is on sale, then pick it up without hesitation. It's worth it.
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

votesFunny: leaving you with zero spending cash when that awesome weapon arrives.\n\nThe online multiplayer lets you join anyone who has an open room
commentsCount: but will still only let you advance by how far YOU'VE gotten in the story (to avoid power leveling I assume).  But if I join a friends game and they are further in the story than me but 2 levels below me
column16: then we're both making a sacrifice to play together.\n\nThe camera/point and click movement can be a pain often times as well. You'll want to click to go somewhere
column17: but instead you click something that is in the foreground but was invisible (as to not obstruct the player's view) and you'll move in a different direction.\n\nOverall

reviewText:
I'm old Diablo gamer and i've played Diablo 2, Diablo 3, Torchlight 2, Path of Exile and some other similar games. I like the graphics and the game style, but i have to say this game gets boring quite fast. I haven't done all the challenges yet and those are really hard since if enemy has Blink, Pull, Nightmare or any similar Demon power and your challenge is to kill X amount of monsters without using Demon powers you fail the mission pretty much instantly.

I'm still going to play this game and try to reach and do the challenges. I've started on Hard mode and it seems the only fun mode currently. You actually have to dodge and give your everything to survive. There is few negative things like Pull into insta death, but luckily there isn't hardcore mode yet.

Haven't tried PvP either and i think that will be quite unbalanced. (Range weapon with blink and some other weapon or melee with Pull & rapier)

Hope they add more levels and more content to this game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I haven't put alot of time in this game yet, that said what I have played I have enjoyed and I plan on spending more time in it.  I see many people saying this is a Van Helsing clone.  I disagree with this as I have Van helsing 1 and 2.  The games play very differently.

My only complaint so far is the need to use WASD for movement, I am uncomfortable using that playing an isometric ARPG.  I find myself spamming the attack button just to move :) I understand that being this game has a jump mechanic why the DEVS may have thought WASD was a better way to go. Many gaming mice nowadays have enough buttons that a jump could easily be bound to a button. I would at least like to see an option for mouse movement instead of only WASD.   This game also supports a controller, however I am not a controller type player in any game.

Overall Early impressions:  I like the game and I think it has potential.  I like that the DEVS have a clear roadmap of where they plan to take the game and I look forward to spending more time in the Victor Vran world.

UPDATE:  As of today (3/13/15) Victor Vran has added the option for mouse movement.  It is great to see developers listen to thier community and add that option for those of us who requested it.  I also like that it is an OPTION rather then changing the scheme entirely and maybe angering those who actually liked the WASD scheme.  Again I am liking the progress of this game and it good to see that it is being regularly updated with content and with player feedback requests.

reviewText:
After over 50 hours in, I am still enjoying Victor Vran... Alot...

This game copies alot from ARPG's that came before it, but also adds alot, and does some stuff differently to make it stand out from the pack.. The ability to jump and dodge roll are great additions to this style of game, and really make combat feel more fluid..  I have over 300 hours in D3, and that has basically become a stand and DPS style game, a tactic which will simply get you killed in VV.

Hexes are a great way to increase the difficulty of the game.. I found the game quite easy without hexes on, but turning on hexes improves the difficulty and challenge of the game, and I think makes you a better player... You really need to understand the attacks and patterns of the enemies with hexes on, to have any hope of surviving!

The card system for character development is unique, and you can create a number of different builds through the configuration of cards. The game might not have different classes, but with weapon and card combos, you can basically build your own classes up and play different play styles..

Speaking of weapons, most ARPGs it is the legendary items that everyone chases, however in VV through the crafting system, with a bit of knowledge and good luck, you can make weapons that out perform their legendary cousins, which is a feature i love. Not everyone is running around with the same damn sword like most games, and the crafting system is not overly complicated, featuring an in game recipe list, however sometimes getting the items you need can be the challenge!

The inclusion of secrets and challenges has been a great addition! the secrets make you want to explore as you go, and combined with the jumping feature can make searching for all the secrets a great deal of fun!  Each map also has its own set of challenges, some more challenging than others, some require different hexes, some require different weapons, some require multiplayer to achieve, but again it is something on each map to aim for, as opposed to simply running and gunning through!

The end game faces the same challenges as all games.. Once you hit the level cap, you gain renown instead, and completing bounties and treasure hunts, (in which you can find your own codes or share them in multiplayer) is a great way to keep going, and if you read the developer road map in the forums, the future of this game looks great!

Thx to Haemimont for making this game, i am really enjoying it, and hope to for a long time to come!  If you enjoy ARPG's, I can not recomend this game enough!  Have fun, happy gaming :D

reviewText:
Victor Vran is a welcome and healthy addition to the action RPGs that brings rhythmic combat to the clickfests we are accustomed to.

It does what it does well: the emphasis might not be on the quantity of the loot or the high customization of your character but rather on the way you time your attacks and dodge out of the way. It doesn't take itself seriously and has some pretty huge winks at other games. This lighthearted tone goes throughout the game with a voice inside Victor's head that offers some good jokes here and there.

I just wish that the developers used these mechanics to deepen the gameplay even more and make it more varied. I have to admit that after finishing the main story in coop, I just felt that I saw everything that the game had to offer. Sure, there were plenty of other challenges to tackle but I did not want to go back and slay hundreds of the generic spiders, skeletons and vampires. (And don't get me started on those essence type of enemies...)

The game could have definitely used more weapon and enemy variety because its combat system is what makes it unique among other ARPGs. After a couple of hours, you figure out what weapons and spells work for you the best and that's pretty much it. You're stuck with generic landscapes and enemies for the rest of the game and this will be a letdown for many players.

Ultimately, it earns my recommendation because in coop, it is fun with a friend. However, I wish it offered a bit more variety in its gameplay and setting to hook players in the long run. For this reason, I recommend picking it up on a sale.

reviewText:
Yeah, it's goofy and good.

To elaborate: Victor Vran pretends it's an APRG in the vein of Diablo. In reality, it's more of an action game with a bunch of RPG elements. There's a lot of buffs and debuffs and damages and armors but most of it can be ignored during the slaughter. The key gameplay mechanics are dodging - something you'll be doing a lot of in the action game way, by rolling from projectiles, jumping over shockwaves and whatnot - and mastering weapons.
There's under twenty weapon types, but each handles differently (by having three attacks associated with it) and each has different mechanics associated with it - so with a shotgun you'll be timing shots and executing enemies, with a scythe you'll harvest souls of and use them to empower your moves and with a rapier you'll be counting your hits to get the maximum out of its combo-empowering abilities.
You can switch between two weapons on the fly and you aren't locked out of any by stat requirements - simply because there aren't any stats. You get passive boosts by equipping a set of cards with values associated with them and figuring out the most effective hand of cards you can use with your limited capacity is actually quite fun.
The emphasis on action gameplay is also further reflected in level design - the maps aren't randomly generated and there is a set of challenges on each one to complete for extra loot and experience; those range from accidently fulfilled" to "good luck figuring out a build that can do this" in difficulty - and if that isn't enough
date: another set of (really rather ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ly) challenges for each map opens up on beating the final boss.\n\nGraphics are nice enough
recommended: could use less spiders but that's a pretty common issue with RPG devs running out of ideas. I think this game actually suffered a bit in the story/presentation department by coming out at around the same time as Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing
hoursPlayed: with which it apparently shares a lot of style - hell
voteText: even logo/title screen with a steampunky hatted hunter looking in your general direction. I wouldn't call Victor Vran derivative
helpfulPercent: though; for one
votesHelpful: his hat gets mercilessly mocked throughout the game.\nWhich brings me to the story and writing and what's actually tying all that murder together. The story is minimal - there's this cursed city and you're there to figure out what happened and destroy the ancient evils
votesTotal: blah blah skeletons vampires ghosts demons. The game is thankfully aware of how shallow this is and pokes fun at it quite a lot. Victor Vran doesn't take itself seriously - at all. Your constant companion is a snarky voice in your head that isn't ever afraid to deliver a low blow to your confidence - from the abovementioned hat mockery through pondering the meaning of mass murder for loot and experience to videogame references. The jokes are mostly rather memetic in substance and a lot of them fall flat but they're usually delivered fast enough to make at least some of them stick - my favorite is probably the Stanley Parable dungeon.\n\nI don't think this game will ever become a beloved classic
votesFunny: but it's definitely a step above the typical point-and-kill ARPG in gameplay and gets a lot of points in my book for its admitted and embraced silliness. Definitely worth getting on a sale.\n"

reviewText:
If you loved Bastion you've got to try this.

It's essentially the same game (on the technical side) but in a sort of Van helsing/Demon Hunters universe.

During my first run which i did not finish yet I noticed a lot of Bastion influence:

Narrator: This is actually a misterious voice in the character's head but it plays exactly the same role.

Weapons/Skill system: Exactly the same, each weapon type has determined skills affecting the gameplay and allowing to create combos with weapon swap.

Controls and camera: Also the same, it's practically identical.

Maybe the only weak" point of Victor Vran while comparing it with Bastion is that the story seems not as deep and definately not as sad
date:
but it's still good.

Once I finish the game i'll add more info to this review

reviewText: Don't let the name or generic character fool you, this is one of the best ARPGs I've played in a long time and almost unseats Diablo 3 in my opinion as best of the genre. The game features a classless progression model where the weapon types define the skills you use. The entire loot curve is about breaking down the weapons and items you don't want, to augment the ones that you do. The game uses set pieces for the levels instead of randomly generated ones, but each area has a variety of challenges for you to go after for more rewards.\n\nThe game does feel a bit repetitive over time, but that's just the nature of the hack and slash genre. Hopefully it will do well for the devs and we can see more content for old Victor.

reviewText:
This is a great action RPG with a unique combat system and quirky, witty, and often funny writing! You would think that such a dark setting would be super serious right? Well it can be, if it weren't for the brilliantly emotive voices in your head.

I thouroughly enjoyed my time with the game, but now that I am in the end game I find myself being drawn back to Rocket League and not wanting to go back to it to complete the elite challenges. Still, awesome game and you can watch my full, in depth review of the game on the video I'm linking here, as it showcases 20 minutes of gameplay then goes into my own category review system.

I highly recommend this game to anyone who has any interest in a action RPG. I had more fun with this than I did back when i played Diablo 3 for the first time (until Reaper of Souls came out that is) and it raises the bar in many ways. I love the seemless weapon switching, the Destiny card system, as well as the hexes (skulls from halo) to make each level slightly more difficult. Great game, i recommend buying it even at full price!

reviewText:
Victor Vran is an aRPG similar to Diablo, Grim Dawn, Path of Exile etc. It's what I'd consider a one and done experience unlike say Diablo III which you could easily pump endless hours into, and I'd just like to say that's not nesseserily a bad thing in Victor Vran’s case.

The gameplay is quite different to other games in the genre, mostly due to the fact you can jump, roll and even wall jump which allows for exploration and unique ways to traverse dungeons. The skill system is similar to Guild Wars 2 where you're given 3 unique abilities based on the weapon you're using, and you can switch between 2 different weapons freely giving you access to 6 weapon abilities total. On top of this you're also given 2 demon powers which are strong abilities that charge during combat. Finally you're given 2 consumable slots which can be used for potions, bombs, medi kits and buffs.

Character customisation comes in the way of cards, you're given a certain amount of card slots and card points, similar to the Call of Duty loadout system. These cards allow you to build how you'd like by adding passives to your character, you can opt for a couple of high point cards or many low point cards depending on your needs. It's not the most deep system but it does the job.

Where the game really excels is presentation, it looks, runs and sounds great. I was very impressed with just how polished the game actually is. I enjoyed the art style and the overall visuals were beautiful with some fantastic little cut scenes thrown in throughout the story. Speaking of the story, it was interesting and fully voiced, and voiced well. You may recognise the voice actor for Victor Vran as he also voiced Geralt in Witcher III. The game also performs really well, I spent the entire 15 hour playthrough at 60fps locked on ultra settings, I will say one thing though, the in-game VSync is not recommended as it uses double buffering, so any tiny dip in frame rate causes the FPS to half down to 30fps. You can fix this 100% by disabling VSync in-game and forcing it on in your GPU control panel, I personally used adaptive VSync with triple buffering and my experience was rock solid.

I have to say I was pleasantly surprised with the game on the whole, it's definitely worth it even at full price, and especially so at £5 in the sale. I thoroughly recommend it to anyone who is a fan of the genre.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Updated this ever so slightly.

Make no mistake, this is not Diablo.  Nor is this Torchlight.  And, not even Van Helsing.  But, it is a decent ARPG, if not a little bit on the casual side.  What I mean by casual is, fighting is pretty much set on easymode.  Early on, you just hold 1 button to attack, literally the whole time.  As the game goes along, you begin mix it up with 2 other attacks.  I wouldn't expect much build variation, as I said, this isn't any of the above named ARPG's.  There 2 weapon slots and card slots (which act as a sort of replacement for skills).  That's right, there's no skill tree.  Gameplay is pretty arcade-like.  It does however, seems more story driven.  Hey, it's even got the Witcher's Geralt voice actor.  Though the static portraits seem a bit cheap.

What did I like?
Dodging - yes, I like my dodging (hello Guild Wars 2)
Jumping - while not absolutely necessary (well, to access some areas it is), it's always nice to find shortcuts
Precise controls
Smooth gameplay
Appears to be plenty of maps - though with 4 players i'm not sure how loot distribution is done, nor do I know if the size is big enough.

What I didn't like?
It feels pretty empty - After more play, I feel the sound is missing some big effects.  I kinda wish it had some of the annoying Diablo 3 Crusader grunts...
Combat feels a bit bland and simplistic - needs some on-screen oomph (more effects I suppose)
Jumping and attacking is pointless - add in the regular attacks and that might add a bit
Can't rotate images (e.g. weapons and portraits) - You get a cool weapon, but you only get a 2D image of it.
Navigating the menus can be confusing - especiallly when using a controller.
Too much of the 'other' voice (not sure if he's trying to be the narrator) - kind of ruins the brooding mood (I guess they wanted some comedy)
You can still get hit while dodging
While the graphics are ok, there really is a lack of detail.

Keep in mind I've only played a few hours now.  So, maybe some of the 'didn't likes' get improved upon.  And, while it may seem like there's more to dislike than to like, it's actually a pretty decent game.  To me, it's just OKAY (though, it grows on me more and more).  If I had to give it a score, i'd give it a 7/10.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Nearly 1 hour into the game, time for a short review (This review will be expanded / changed on later game versions):

-- Update: 26.02.2015
Spent 2 hours in the game now and I think it's time for an update!
---

First of all, I love the setting, and if I remember correctly isnt there also some connection with the MOTÖRHEAD game? I've read something about that. At least, the setting reminds of something that I have read on the official facebook page.

Anyway, back to the game:

First off: Yes, this game is very early Beta (If not even Alpha).
- Some images are missing and replaced with Placeholder images
- The game is short, ... very short

Is it boring? Absolutely not, slaying Spiders, Skeletons and a bunch of other creatures have never been so much fun to me since Dungeon and Dragons on the XBox (the good old one). Fast game play, very good controlling using a gamepad and the graphics are looking sweet.

Who shall play this game?
Anyone who is not too much afraid about Spiders and thought that Diablo lacks of action.

During my first hour of gameplay, I had so much fun jumping to the enemies, deal loads of damage and jump away to avoid their counter attacks (there is a dodge introduced quite early in the game, but I did not manage it yet on actually dodging an attack. Hope that this will be somehow getting a bit easier to understand).


--- and what are now my new opinions on this game since I spent 2 hours on it?
Character development is really nice.
You do not have to create a character from scratch, as Victor evolves by your choices. By collecting and combining destiny cards, you can be anything you like. As I prefer to tank through the enemies in close combat, I made a selection of High melee damage" and "Vampirism" and combined it with a sword that sends out exploding impulses from time to time. But you can be anything you like
date:
as long you find the cards for it and the right weapon.

---

After my first hour in the game
recommended: I rated the game with a personal score of 85%
hoursPlayed: but more I'm in the game and find out things the more fun it is. Score increased to 87%!\n\nBut keep in mind

reviewText:
I had fun with this game, until about level 25. I'll point out some aspects of the game I liked first:

Pros
~Multiplayer that isn't a hassle.
~Full range of interesting weapons.
~Customizable builds based on style of play. For instance, if you want to tank, there is a setup for that.
~Said setup is made based on Destiny Cards. These aren't too hard to find (some given during level-ups).
~Diablo-style legendary items (no sets). The weapons I got that had legendary effects were fun to use and I tried my hardest to keep them in my inventory at all times.
~Able to change loadout on the fly.
~Large amount of inventory, even for those pesky low-level cards that you need to hoard.
~Boss fights that will keep you on your toes

Now this was my experience before around level 25. After this the gameplay changed, and so did the need for new ways of tackling the game.

Cons
~Getting certain items in multiplayer (esp. lightning guns) will kill your friends in a heartbeat if they are melee. Friendly fire should not have been included.
~Some legendary weapons are too OP to pass up.
~The game forces you to play at a harder difficulty to obtain said legendaries.
~The increased difficulty creates a huge gap from the original gameplay. It honestly felt like a completely different game. Not just a harder game, an impossible one. Here's why:
Enemies can have any Demonic skill in game, including a 5 second stun and pull. No build, even full defense, can handle this later in game. The monsters that can cast this ability are multiplied at this level. You will run into them, and they will murder you.
~Builds become cookie-cutter. Tanks are no longer viable, and the only build you can use includes certain OP legendary items with high-damage output/vamp.
~Money will always be a problem if you decide not to grind.
~You will decide to grind anyway because once you increase the difficulty (which some areas require to pass their achievements) you will run into problems.
~Upgrading cards to have Wicked/Divine stats becomes a larger grind than getting OP weapons.
~Last thing- every area in the game will scale it's difficulty to your level. Going back to old content won't mean easier content.


I became so fustrated with this game after a while and had to stop. I consider myself a common gamer, and this game's difficulty curve is very, very high. Would not recommend to new or softcore gamers. I played  this game in multiplayer with a hardcore gamer, and he was happy with the game in it's current state. To all his own.

reviewText:
VV is a fun hack-n-slash ARPG with interesting skill and item progression systems. The story is good if not a bit slow. The voice acting is okay but the antagonistic narrator gets irritating sometiimes. There is some cheeky humor, but it fits in well.

The graphics are very nice as is the music. The game has an immersive dark atmosphere. Most importantly the combat is fluid and the controls are great both for the controller and M+K. I use a Logitech 710 controller and it works great.

The setting is hard to describe. It's not traditional VanHelsing but like an anime interpretation. I love it. It has the right mix of traditional and creative license. If you enjoy that setting and like ARPGs then this game should be fun for you.

reviewText:
Similar in tone and gameplay to Torchlight or Van Helsing, but honestly, I enjoy the skill and leveling system much more.

You're not locked in to any one class at any time.  Skills are assigned based on the weapons, tomes, and spells you have equipped, so as you gain better items, your skills will become stronger. You can equip destiny cards to add special effects to your attacks. (All of these items can be made more powerful via the transmuting system.)

Each map comes with its own set of achievements, so if you're an achievement fetishist, that will appeal to you. I also think that this game's maps are a little prettier and more varied than most of the ARPG's I've played on Steam.

9/10, my only issue being that some day I'd like to play a game like this that has a more robust story.  With Victor Vran, I'm having too much fun killing stuff and taking its loot in new and interesting ways to give a crap.

reviewText:
A fun Action RPG that is not too complex to pick up but engaging enough to be a rare gem.  I really enjoy the weapon, and relic/ability system.  The controls on my XBOX 360 wireless controller are fluid, fast, and very responsive as they should be.  My only beef was the lack of local co-op which negates couch playing with buddies, but at least it doesn't struggle from camera angle issues those games do pulling you around.

PROS:
Fun game
Cool weapon and gear system
Variety of upgrades
Good graphics

CONS:
Navigation system isn't as intuitive as I'd like
Desperately needs a PROPER in-game communication system
The lobby chat spams you with other people's conversations even in  private game.  Be sure and turn off that
When exiting the game on Windows 10 x64 the process EXE hangs and I have to End Task it

All in all I would definitely recommend this game for some really good Co-Op.  For the $10 sale price this game is a deal for sure.

reviewText:
A worthy replacement for the rather dull Diablo 3 with way more interesting fighting mechanics. Weapon combos, several different weapon types that actually play different (not just bows and swords) and a character whose strengths are defined mostly by cards you can mix and match at your will.

The icing on the cake is that it's fully cross-platform (well, except for savegames) and has good controller support (another thing absent from Diablo 3 on PC).

I'm really looking forward to the planned local co-op feature.

reviewText:
I bought this from the Christmas sale and I wasn't dissapointed a small bit! Overall I'd say this gets from me 4/5 in it's ARPG category.

The game is excellent fun and you can easily choose if you want it to be difficult or not. The normal mode isn't heart wrenching difficult, but the amount of different monsters keep you on your toes. The boss fights will punish you the hard way, if you are not prepared, and you have to figure out the best tactic to defeat each boss. The challenges and hex -system, that increases the difficulty, gives the game nice re-playability and I bet as co-op this is even more fun.

The story in the game is pretty basic stuff but the voice acting of the main characters are excellent. The graphics look good and the screen is some times filled with colourfull stuff when you are in the middle of the enemy pack. The fighting system works at least as an melee hunter. I haven't tried the caster -character yet. There is nicely enough variety in the weaponry, but the types are pretty basic. Still the different weapons plays differently so you can easily find ones that suit your game play style. The trasformation -system is slightly confusing at start and it took me few tries and errors to get the hang of it.

I do recommend this game, especially now as it's on sale. It's worth the full price though so give it a go!

reviewText:
Casual ARPG fan like me ? this is an awesome game for you ..

pros:-
- You will like it from the very first Minute .
- Right into the point, no dramatic game Devs crap .
- Very interesting story .
- Many Fighting styles choices .
- Not bad Gfx over all .
- The Game runs Smoothly no fps drops or errors or what so ever .
- Very nice background Music that fits the stages and places you travil through .
- Very simple and easy Spec's to build .
- Challenges !! So yeah the objective is to find someone or kill something but you can clear the whole map to do some bonus objc's using special weapons for gold and gear .. Very well designed .
- The Voice that keeps following you is just amazing Idea .
- I thought its going to be another Van Helsing rip .. ITS REALLY NOT .
- Tis game beats the hell of Path of Exile .

Cons:-
- Fighting doesn't feel Heroic, when you hit something and do some serious damage you just don't feel it, Only Diablo Players would understand and agree on that .
- Fighting Sounds when you hit something or use an ability isn't satisfying .
- The character can use some Personality, Like when you use a Cooldown or when you kill a boss .
- Coop would be great if it was hosting by the game servers not P2p system so people wont lag to death .

I believe in this game, if they expand it to the next lvl of Hardcore ARPG its gonna be a big hit for the Studio behind it .. 100 YES i recommend this game .

reviewText:
Everything you love about hack 'n slash, with some of the expected shenanigans

Pros: Gorgeous - superb visual design, addictive gameplay - very fun, which is why we play games, right? Includes some level-gamification for replayability (challenges, secrets, etc.) Supports resolutions other games don't (Diablo, why you hate 3440?) Entertaining voice work, and overall nice coat of polish.

Cons: Suffers from the same hack n slash clichés - smash the pots... ALLof them...(can we not do pots anymore? A small handful of boxes and crates are just fine), then travel over there (again), fight another couple dozen of the particularly annoying monsters along the way... None are awful, and actually kind of help keep the player in a blissful mind-numbing gaming coma.

Good value, no regrets.
