reviewText:
Much more fun than I expected - 8/10

Victor Vran is a really interesting case of taking your typical ARPG hack'n'slash game and mixing in some more direct control than the genre got us used to, as well as turning the class and build issue on its head. What we get is a really enjoyable exercise in mowing down hundreds of enemies without much repetitiveness kicking in.

Character progression is tied to loot much more than usually in such games - since Victor has no skills of his own, only the set of them dependant on the weapons (you can quickly swap between two) wielded, the best tools of destruction you get are going to influence your experience quite a bit until the next big drop. And we are talking real variety. With the sword in hand the game is a crit-based slash-fest, shotgun provides some more control and a slight rhythm-element, scythes add secondary resource to strengthen your attacks, tomes provide great positional control at the cost of engaging in a 'minigame' of picking up special powerups... it is quite a treat, and no two types of a weapon work the same. In the later parts, Legendary versions of the weapons start appearing - these don't just give different stats, they also directly modify some of the abilities granted by your weapon.
To back these up, Vran can also equip up to 5 Destiny Cards, that grant either passive or triggered bonuses (and can randomly have another one in the form of Wicked/Divine boon), two Demon Powers (additional activated skills, weapon-agnostic) and an Outfit, which modifies stats and/or base mechanics of the game, usually related to the charging of Overdrive, a fancy name for what is basically a rage-bar that powers Demon Powers.

And that's it. No talents, no skills, no attributes... quite a novelty, with its own set of upsides and downsides. The good is, once you find a weapon type you like more than the previous you use, switching is not a problem. With a proper set of Cards, Powers, and Outfits, any combination of weapons can be re-adjusted to. Which, in turn, kills much of the possible repetitiveness.
Thankfully, the high dependence on gear doesn't hurt as much - the crafting system in Victor Vran is built to make sure you can continue using just the weapon you like the most; leftover loot can be used to increase critical chance, damage, and power of special properties of your weapon, going even as far as adding one property of your liking (provided you can 'craft' it). By combining lesser weapons of a specific rarity and type the player has a chance to craft a higher-rarity weapon of the same type, so getting better sort of your favourite weapon isn't all that hard either.

At the same time, this means that no specialized and truly intricate builds are achievable. Which becomes even more apparent as some of game's balance issues are revealed. Victor Vran favours critical hits by the virtue of having a lot of effects that can be triggered either on a critical hit or overkill (killing an enemy with quite a bit more damage than was needed), of which critical hits are easier to achieve. If you back it up with the fact that Sword is a premiere critical-hit based weapon and Sword-centric Destiny Card is stupidly powerful for sustaining yourself... yeah, you can guess how I built my character pretty much by default. There are also slight concerns about some weapons being just too unwieldy or fun but not powerful enough (non-legendary Tomes are problematic, and Lighting Gun seems like the clunkiest thing ever to me) but it might be on the fact that I wasn't the greatest player skill-wise.

Despite the above, you can still enjoy any sort of weapon combo you decide to stick with, and if it happens to be too powerful... well, the game has you covered. With 5 activable Curses, which strengthen your enemies in specific ways while increasing the experience gain, you can quite easily make sure that the enemies can and will overpower you. Mix in the map-unique Challenges, which are sets of arbitrary tasks to perform for additional rewards (and 5 more of them for each map are achievable once you complete the game once) and there is a lot to do.

So, the gameplay is great, but what else is there? ... not much, actually.
The story is ore of a throw-away, even if it doesn't present itself terribly. It is just uninspired and serves mostly as a reason for all the slaughter to occur, rather than a point of focus. Voice acting is kept on a sensible level, aside from how edgy our protagonist appears - both in lines and delivery, but the lines aren't inspired all that much overall. Side characters have some interesting bits to say sometimes, and the Voice proves to be amusing on a handful of maps, but that's about it. Just a slight spicing for the gameplay.
Art and music actually positively surprised me, especially the latter - fits the mood perfectly, even if the mood is built on the premise of your typical 'spooky' invasion of countless ghosts, skeletons, vampires, gargoyles, spiders... if not for occasional elementals, you could say that the entire range of enemies is just Halloween scares. Thankfully, the lack of interesting creations is backed up by how varied their methods of attack and ways to deal with them are.

I can safely recommend this title, great fun for a good price - at the time of writing, I had 22 hours clocked, which is enough to complete the game with around 70% base challenges done. Which puts me at roughly 35% of them now that new ones appeared.

reviewText:
General characteristic:
To be honest I didn't expect much after this title,but now I gotta admit that I was wrong :) Victor Vran is really good aRPG.All the basic mechanics are made well,the game adds to the standard range of moves also dodges,making the fights more dynamic and jumping,which lets you to reach for example for secrets.

The main story was a little bit too obvious for me from one point of the game,but I liked it anyways.The plot took me about 10 hours,but a person who likes to max out the games will find here hundreds of hours of gameplay more taking in account how many challenges there are.

There's a few types of weapons that the character can wield,including scythes,swords,rapiers,shotguns,hamers etc. Every type of weapon has 3 different skills.Additionally Vran can use various special powers powered by the overdrive.

You won't find here the standard statistic points known for example from the 2nd Diablo,those are modified by the Destiny Cards found on the battlefield.

Advantages:
+A few new systems in the genre
+Good soundtrack
+Good,dynamic,engaging fighting system
+A sea of loot for the main character
+Every weapon has a different feeling
+Vast content,letting for many hours of fun
+The multiplayer mode
+Well-made locations
+The Destiny Cards let you for many builds
+References to the pop-culture
+Some funny moments with the Voice in Vran's head"...

Disadvantages:
-...but mostly it's boring and adds nothing to the story
-Jumping in an aRPG is a nice novelty
date:
but it could have been made better
-The locations are not randomly generated so you'll be getting back to literally the same places
-I faced a few problems with controls
-Soulless main and side characters
-Too predictable story
-Just a few
recommended:
one-piece armours for the protagonist
-A demon hunter in a hat? I've seen it somewhere...
-Some boss fights are boring
-THOSE DAMN ENEMIES
hoursPlayed: GETTING BACK TO LIFE! :D\n\nConclusion: I don't regret buying Victor Vran.Satisfying fights and dark atmosphere make it a great experience.If you look for a new aRPG to spend some time with

reviewText:
I've played numeros ARPG's over the years... I started with Diablo 2, then played Diablo 3, Path of Exile, Torchlight II, and other games that are similar but somewhat different (magicks 1/2). I think Victor Vran is an amazing ARPG. The combat is extremely fluid and rich, reminding me of diablo 3. Where i felt Torchlight II was somewhat lackluster in combat and i got the feeling that i was just dps-kite and wait for mana-dps-kite and wait for mana, etc. I feel that Victor Vran completely eliminates that feeling.

Combat: First of all, there is no mana bar in this game, at least traditionally. There is a yellow meter called the overdrive meter, which can be charged in various ways depending on your characters outfit (read: class), which can be changed throughout the game. The changing of the outfit throughout the game was nice because it made it so you didn't need to commit to anything and that your playstyle can adapt as you get gear better suited to one outfit or another. Anyway, the overdrive meter, as its called, is used to power your demon abilities. Like i said ealier, it can be charged in various ways depending on the outfite, but it is most generally charged by doing damage. This means that in dry periods with few enemies, you likely won't be using abilities, but when you got mobbed by bosses or ads, then the bar will fill up fast and you can start slamming those demon powers. This helps to eliminate one of my torchlight complains about mana.

The other wonderful thing about the combat is just how generally fluid it is. The game is perfectly optimized for a controller, as it isn't cluttered with 9 abilites on an action bar (which i know a lot of people may like as it necessarily provides options and niche abilities). There is also a built in dodge/roll key, as dodging is vital to staying alive. The weapons in this game, which of course define how your character's combat plays out, are nice as the skills tied to each weapon will generally build around itself for a neat playstyle. The tome (free dlc) for instance, produces gems with basic attacks that, when picked up, reset the cooldown to your other abilities. The scythe collects souls of enemies when you auto-attack, and the skills (a daze and whirl) became lengthened depending on how many souls you have when you used the skill. Combining all of these elements to the game creates a very mobile, action packed combat system that really shines.

Customization: In this game, there is not a lot of customization. In fact, there is nothing in this game that can't be undone at a whim, as all of the customizaion is simply what gear you have. That's right, there are no skill trees or speccable stats anywhere. I would normally be upset at this as i really like to build my own characters around a playstyle i want and make something somewhat unique. But, this is not a problem at all. The gear varies pretty typically in the game, but it is obvious that the game was not meant to be one where you make a full mage or rapier specialist. In this game, you play as Victor Vran, who can do everything, which makes it rather nice. As i mentioned earlier, you can switch playstles on a whim if you just pick up a new weapon you really like. If you have a crit build, for instance, and find a really nice hammer, then you can just flip over to a new outfit, throw in some new abilities, and you're suddely a viable hammer user. no strings attached.

With the gear in this game, there are a couple categories, with almost all of them being completely straightforward. The only one that isn't, is the destiny cards. When you level up you have a certain amount of points that can be allocated to your destiny cards. The destiny cards have a class type, such as Strength" or "The Moon"
date: which offer a special effect "higher crit chance" and "frost explostion on crit" respectively. They also have a point system to them

reviewText:
Great game. Bought this after watching TotalBiscuit's review, and I was very impressed with the gameplay. Victor Vran actually has a great deal of complexity after reaching the middle levels. The ability to transmute items harkens back to D2's Horadric Cube, being able to reroll stats on weapons, improve the quality, or just transmuting a bunch of greens and getting a couple uniques out of it.

The challenges for each level, while optional, provide another level of depth to the game that rewards challenging your style of gameplay, and also increases replayability of areas.

Hexes are a cool way to turn difficulty up and down and be rewarded for playing more skillfully. Not sure about the end game yet, but I've still got hours ahead of me.

reviewText:
Wow! I gave this game the cold shoulder due to the silly title and late Playstation 2-level graphics. Picked it up on sale and can say unequivocably: Huge mistake to not jump on this immediately. This is one of the best, most daring ARPGs ever made, full of original ideas and excellent game design.

The first thing I liked: This is a much more skill-based ARPG than a clickfest. It expects you to work on your facing, dodging, and using terrain and abilities appropriately. The monsters have wind-ups and tells on all their attacks and so positioning and paying attention is important. You will have abundant potions but they are on a LONG cooldown so you can't chug your way through fights. Don't get me wrong - this is not Dark Souls but compared to ARPGs where you basically walk through your skill cooldowns and watch everything die it's a big step up.

Second thing I liked: not a bunch of fake choices. When you have a decision to make, it's a real decision between very different choices. Very rarely are you making weenie choices about +3% extra damage stuff. Your passive skills are collectible Tarot-like cards that drop in the world or are rewarded on level up and they all have very different effects. You slot them up and have a quota that you can't exceed.  You also have a sort of mana bar called Overdrive that fills up in different ways based on the kind of clothes you wear (it makes sense in the game, kinda) and once it is full you can use it to unleash a powerful kind of attack or magical effect (meteors from the sky, a time distortion bubble that slows enemies) - and the different kinds of effects are also cards that drop in the environment.  You also have one alchemy slot that you can fill with either a very offensive or very defensive bonus. There's also a gambling system that makes every item, including the trash drops, potentially valuable.  It's interesting and very, very solid.

Third, no bad skill trees that force me to guess-commit to builds based on a couple levels worth of scaling and some ambiguously-worded tooltips. Your builds" are based on your weapon choice - the weapons are little skill trees that you carry around. Each weapon has a basic attack + 2 skills on cooldowns
date: and you get to carry two of them that you can switch between freely. Pick up a new kind of weapon? You can equip it and try it out to check out its skills
recommended: and see how it works fo your character. You might want to do Sword + Shotgun for decent single target + crowd control at both ranged and melee. Or you can go completely nuts and do Hammer + Lighting Gun
hoursPlayed: basically a heavy hitter that carpet-bombs areas and zaps bosses from across the screen when the going gets tough. Or whatever. It's a great system and is IMMENSLY satisying. You get to try all the options
voteText: make your own combos and play with a character that you enjoy and made an informed decision about constructing after weighing all the options through actual play.\n\nFourth
helpfulPercent: very good scaling difficulty system. The base game is fairly easy but starting around level 9 you can equip Hexes. These are cursed items and you can equip as many as you want
votesHelpful: and they make the game harder in specific ways. Monsters start doing more damage
votesTotal: attacking more
votesFunny: and just generally being big PITAs. If you start getting your face wrecked or struggle with a particular boss (respawning resets the boss fights) then turn off a couple of the dang Hexes. Just know in your heart you cheesed it. ;)\n\nFifth
commentsCount: a challenge system. When you enter a new area you get a list of challenges. There are some pretty basic ones
column16: like "Find all 3 secrets". Ok
column17: sure. But some are really good
column18: like forcing you to rush killing 40 monsters in 60 seconds (basically you're going to wade into a huge melee and start wrecking the place) and real tough ones like killing everything in the level without getting hit
column19: or using the "wrong" tactics to fight certain monsters (fighting big stone golems that hit really hard in melee is tough!) If you manage to beat these challenges you get rewards of items
column20: XP
column21: and gold
column22: and also little gold stars on the game's map. I had a blast with these
column23: they added a nice wrinkle to the game and a reason to come back and replay some of the levels.\n\nNow it's not a perfect game.  As I stated earlier the graphics are not great although they are 100% acceptable and communicate game information clearly (there's also a couple of nice moments). The story is kinda weak and I stopped gving a hoot after a couple hours. For some inexplicable reason they used the voice actor of Geralt of Rivia from the Witcher games for Victor so I feel like I'm playing the adventures of Geralt Van Helsing. And lastly there's no way to get a DPS comparison count on the weapons
column24: so when you've locked in your build and started comparing and tweaking drops it gets a little tedious to have to eyeball 8 swords to figure out which one is the best.\n\nBut overall this is a great ARPG and absolutely worth every penny of the full price. I hope you'll give it a chance. I'm glad I did."

reviewText:
Harry's Tuesday Reviews-Victor Vran-
Developer: Haemimont Games
Publisher: EuroVideo Medien

Story:
You start the game as Victor Vran, from the order of hunters who came to Transylvania Zagoravia in search of his friend, Adrian. On his way to the castle Zagore, he goes mad starts hearing a strange voice in his head which often misleads him, or rarely helps.
The clock thickensstory heats up when he realises what happened to his *cough*vampire now*cough* friend.
Will he manage to save almost-crushed land of Zagoravia from falling to the dark side?
Harry's note: It could have been longer.

GameplayI  HATE  ARPG's. But this game made me fall in love with them. *_*
You can either choose to move with wasd and attack with L/RMB, or use the mouse for moving and attacking.
There is no skill system, instead of it you can have up to two demon powers (throw a boomerang which deals damage, create a shield around yourself which absorbs damage, etc.)
Overdrive is mana pool kind of an energy bar which you fill by attacking enemies and it allows you to cast demon powers.
You can have up to six destiny cards (which give you stats like armor pene, hp, armor, damage, etc.) Every destiny card takes a certain amount of destiny points (which you can have up to 24)
Weapons can be:
Common - Gray
Uncommon - Green
Rare - Yellow
Legendary - PurpleAn outfit is like armor, it can give you buffs like armor and hp, or it gives you an additional destiny card slot (base 5 + 1 = 6) or bonus overdrive capacity.

GraphicsThere's not much to be said about it, the game has really good graphics. :)

Final mark:            Story        8                Graphics        10                Gameplay        10                Average        9.3
Overall rating: 9.3Harry's opinion:Victor Vran is a truly magnificent game, very entertaining to play, but gets a bit repetitive after 30 hours in it.
The story falls a bit short, feels like there's a void in it lmao.
I recommend it to anyone who thinks they're a Gamer.
//Gamer with the capital G

reviewText:
Short version: This game is well worth the money. It's an action packed Co-Op which will make you question the reasoning behind the prices of other ARPGs out there.

Pros:

Price - yes really, you're getting a LOT of game for this price. It could easily charge £20+/32$ for what it is. Being so cheap is definitely a BIG plus.
The physics behind all the level jumping involved are executed very well.
Theme: I suspect the studio is based in Easter Europe, and we're lucky that they decided to go with native culture for the characters in V.V. I have never been happier to see an orthodox priest!
Humour - Lots of referencing and joking. It's a light hearted title that doesn't take itself too seriously.
Mechanics - a new, refreshing take on how to customise" your character via the Tarot cards.
Fully voiced narrative! - I can forgive the small budget "rogue-like" games out there that you have to read through a lot. However every decent RPG should be at least 90% voiced. I find reading from a screen
recommended: to be tedious work.\nGood Guy developers - yes this is a pro
hoursPlayed:
I would mention it again if I could. The devs have promised to release several DLC's for FREE. For a game this cheap?! Take a look at Tropico 5 page if you want to see what the opposite of that is.
Treasure hunting - occassionally you'd get a map that requires you to revisit some place to fight a more beefed up boss. It's a nice touch.




Cons:
Content: At this stage there's too little depth in the actual customisation. After 6 or so hours you're likely to have found most if not all the range of weapons (not find all uniques
voteText: but find all variants).\nI would really like to see a new item slot with the same depth as the stuff we've been getting for guns or Tarot cards.\nStory & characters - I have to admit they're all pretty forgettable and insignifficant
helpfulPercent: except for You and the secret voice in your head. I feel like it's worth mentioning as a con

reviewText:
Sort of really love this game.

This is the Diablo style game you've wanted since 2. It's more action oriented with multi-level dungeons that allow you to wall jump to new locations, a solid dodge system and skills automatically generated by the weapon you're weilding (similar to GW2).
For a minute I thought this would have the same difficulty issue Diablo 3 had (however this game at least gives you a 'hard' option without beating it first) however once I got access to the Hexes that was fixed.  My wife and I only turned on the Tyrant/Champion hex and the difficulty felt perfect.  Nice thing is it isn't just a blind increase in difficulty, you get increased experience/items appropriately.

The game also has an objective/optional objective based star system that honestly reminds me of Mario 64 when you look at the world map.  The nice thing is every time you complete an objective you either get a boost of experience or money.  And because you can see the total stars you're encouraged to always try and and get full stars.

reviewText:
I bought this when it came out as Early Access sometime in February 2015. I was looking for a good ARPG at that time to replace Diablo 3 and Path of Exile, as I had played them till utter boredom. Several games, indie and professional alike, had disappointed me, however, Victor Vran did not.
You play as Victor Vran, the titular demon hunter, on his quest to free the city of Zagoravia from a demon invasion. You don't need much more story in an ARPG, and the first versions of Early Access didn't even have that - the quest givers were basically the developers talking to you. The current version has the fill story, which is fine by ARPG standards, but nothing to write home about otherwise.
You can play with gamepad or different keyboard/mouse configurations, I personally like the gamepad controls the best - they are fluent and support the action-oriented gameplay with dodging and a fully-rotatable camera.
To kill stuff (which after all is the prime activity in any good ARPG), you can pick form a variety of melee and ranged weapons (swords, hammers, rapiers, shotguns, mortars and lightning guns at this time). Each weapon time has one basic and two special attacks, which males for interesting synergies in combination with magical properties (up to two per weapon).
Character development does NOT work with a skill tree, but by choosing weapons, demon powers (spells you can cast once your overdrive meter is full; it fills by dealing damage) and Destiny Cards. The latter are items you put in slots that are awarded by leveling up and grant various buffs.
The graphics are fine for on ARPG (don't expect photorealism) and a bit on the bright side palette-wise. The music sounds nice, I think it's a bit above the average ambient music" of many current RPGs.
Is it fun? Hell yeah
date: it is! If you're looking for some fun
voteText: if you're looking for an "MMO" ARPG in the line of Diablo 3 and PoE
helpfulPercent: with trading and ladders
votesHelpful: check out some videos before
votesTotal: it might not be what you crave."

reviewText:
A hack-and-slash ARPG with insane bullet hell-type fights with hordes of demons and undead creatures to have your way with. There is a multitude of weapons, melee and ranged, to be found and used, all customizable in the form of prefix and suffix-type enchantments through the Transmutation feature. Adding to this is your card deck which you fill with Destiny cards (like tarot cards) that drop from enemies and chests, each of which grant a perk. Then you have Demon powers which are special abilities that can be summoned off a charge meter. Putting all of these together, the character customization possibilities are pretty much endless. There are no classes in Victor Vran. Your loadout is your class. And oh yes before I forget, YOU CAN JUMP AND DODGE!

The game is graphically beautiful and the environments well designed. It runs smoothly on Ultra settings at 60fps on my rig, an i5-4690k and Radeon R9 280 with shadows disabled (shadows on creates fps lag, idk why). Controls are intuitive and get easier the more you play.

Story-wise (which is forgettable; you're basically there to clean up someone else's mess), the game takes about 2-3 hours to complete if you're not a completionist and don't care for dungeon challenges and secrets. If you do, it'll bump that up to maybe 10 - 15 hours. You do not have to beat all the dungeons to finish the game.

Overall, this is a good game and my time spent playing it has been enjoyable. 8.5/10.

reviewText:
Victor Vran is a breath of fresh air in a genre(arpg) that has toed the line for decades.  It offers three different control schemes, gamepad, mouse & keyboard, or just mouse which is the usual fare. The default is WASD + mouse which is very fluid and engaging.

You can jump and defensive roll, which is something not often seen in these types of games, both are used to good effect in evading or exploring the various maps for secret areas.

As of writing this I'm merely 3 hours in, but the game has impressed me enough for me to take a short break to sing it's praises.   Now to the details...

Outfits mostly just change how you play the game in small but important ways such as one giving you overdrive(ultimate attack)  by being damaged, one that charges when you crit, and one that slowly charges on it's own and will stay filled.

The loot reminds me of Guild Wars 2, where a base item type will grant you 2 different special attacks along with the tried and tested affixes that range from finding more items, health leech, armor penetration and attack speech.

The voice acting is fairly solid, and humorous while the graphics will not amaze you but they are quite good in their own right both the sound and visuals mesh expertly together.

The game runs and plays smooth as butter. (I'm not sure how the online is but it sports 4 player co-op with chat rooms and the like)


Really, if you like ARPGs-  GET THIS GAME NAO!
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
At first glance it may look like another Diablo clone, but it is clear that a lot of thought went into this game. It is a really fun game with some strategic depth to it. The narrator reminded me of Bastion, at times. You sort of build a ... bond with the treacherous git.

Unlike other games of its kind, the character path is not determined by characters' skill but through a combination of demon power talismans, destiniy cards and the suit he wears. You can make minute changes to each one to suit your needs at the moment. Leveling up only changes how many destiny points you can have on your deck so there is still a difference between a low level and a high level character but the mechanism is ingenious.

Then there is the bounty/treasure map mechanic. Everyonce in a while you will get a bounty or a treasure map which requires you to visit old haunts for new loot and monsters to fight. You can share and use other players' bounties as well (there is a forum thread for this purpose). This combined with elite challenges unlocked after finishing the game adds a lot of replay value.

If you are a Linux user, you may be glad to hear that the game works great in Linux.

reviewText: Look, it`s another isometric RPG that allows for multiple players. And this one is actually good. I don`t know. I guess this game just checks all the boxes. Fun gameplay, engaging plot, actually interesting boss battles, and it even has a lot of interesting new ideas. I never said `oh, if they only did this it would be so much better` that is common with so many of these types of games (except for not rotating the minimap by default). This is the game Torchlight 2 should have been. Although I did encounter an issue where vsync (enabled by default) made the game incredibly stuttery. And things aren`t explained well; I had to go to the settings just to find out how to change between equipped weapons. But it`s really fun to play. There are multiple references some of which I`m pretty sure I didn`t get. And there are gangnam style zombies. Nuff said.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
This ARPG is full of innovative game systems. Basic powers come from the 8 weapon types, not classes (there are no classes). Additional powers come from 2 slotted consumables (of 12) and 2 slotted Demon Powers (of 10?). Additionally passive abilities come from destiny cards, 5 slots of lots and lots. The remaining slot is a costume slot, which can be core to your build.

Some nice features such as seemingly unlimited inventory space and straightforward upgrade paths (no RNG in the gear upgrade system) make this a single character game with maximum tweaking and rebuilding potential.

Combat is good fun and can be spectacular, though in large zones frame rate problems are genuinely serious and do detract from the experience.

One great system is hexes which allow you to tweak the challenge level very precisely beyond the basic difficulty modes as presented. This allows you to manage the difficulty of each encounter if you wish. Load all 5 hexes for maximum difficulty or just 1 if you want just a bit more challenge. In game challenge modes prompt you to try different hexes on individual maps.

8/10
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Given the amount of freshness and raw pure fun Victor Vran brings into the stale ARPG genre, I cannot recommend the game enough and I'm really looking forward to any potential expansions the developers care to bring.

I do, however, have several points I'd like to state about what I think would further improve the game. Don't take me wrong, the game is fantastic and it is both worth it's price and it is totally worth checking out for the reason previously stated, and that's whether you're a diehard fan of hack'n'slash genre or just a casual looking for a fun combat system, yet there are a few aspects I subjectively think could use improving:

1. No trade option nor a 'trade house' - Since Legendary weapons are very hard to reliably drop and most of the times they're totally random, you can walk through the game ending up with either a good amount of Legendaries or next to none whatsoever, and that's without counting that you may both have almost every single type dropped or just a few copies of the same weapon all over again, which is a bit frustrating if you're not a fan of ceaseless grinding, especially for players new to the game. Since Legendaries are among the most fun weapons in the game, not to mention many of their special abilities actually change the playstyle of a given weapon type, a simple Trade option would keep the new players interested in the game instead of being bored to death because of endless gray/green/gold drops all over again, while more experienced players would have the option of sharing or trading the numerous copies of the same Legendaries (that they wouldn't make use of anyway) with their friends.


2. Bounty/Hunt drops are far too few - Yes, I get the idea that they're kept low to encourage the community to work together and share their codes, but given that it's hard to find players online nowadays turns this approach obsolete. Since the endgame consists of challenges (which, once completed, aren't there anymore), bottomless pit runs (which, given the low amount of drops, are in my opinion just a test ground for trying out new playstyles against waves of enemies) and the dreaded cauldron of chaos (kudos for the implementation, more of that please!), the better or simply more reliable drop rate of Bounties and Treasure Hunts tied to some specific activity would keep more players interested in the game and give them something to do each day.

3. Endgame content comes down to Cauldron of Chaos mostly - The implementation of CoC was a perfect move from the developers, as it is essentially a damn hard challenge for players that changes every day, keeping them interested in the game and providing them with some meaningful tests to try their builds and skill. My point here is therefore not against the CoC itself, which is awesome, but because that it's the only meaningful endgame level that has some daily significance and appropriate rewards. The simple idea is that the game could really use more instances like this so that playerbase keeps growing.

4. Victor Vran II? - The point is more of a personal comment from me, so don't take it as an objective argument. As I said, the game brings lots of freshness to the stale hack'n'slash genre and I love the changes to the formula that the devs have implemented. My only wish is that they further expand upon this solid idea basis and try releasing a proper old-school expansion or perhaps another installment for Victor Vran, giving players more of everything - a bigger world, more ever-changing endgame instances, more unique weapon types, more card types, more outfits, more powers, perhaps even a customization of one's own hunter instead of playing as Victor Vran himself. The brilliant basis is already there in VV, so I really hope the devs take it further and give players striving for freshness in the ARPGs more of new stuff to sink their teeth in.

A solid 9/10 from me.

reviewText:
Victor Vran - A Steam Review
[Disclamer - I was provided a copy of by the publisher for review purposes]

The good
Innovative gameplay
Beautiful graphics
Lots of content and playstyles
The not so good:
A bit grindy with repetitive enemies
Generic story
The conclusion:

Victor Vran is a beautiful example of an early access success story. The time spent in early access can be seen in the final product. The gameplay innovations (WASD movement for ARPGs and jumping) blend perfectly with the classic ARPG grind and loot gameplay and it will give you countless hours of gameplay. Different approaches change the gameplay a lot, making it feel like a new game - Duelist vs Sniper or Close Combat killing machine.
It’s an awesome game and every fan of the genre shouldn’t ask himself/herself twice when it comes to buying this.
You can see me playing it here - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=V0Qe0p0V1wA

reviewText:
Victor Vran is my first foray into the aRPG realm and I am glad it is because it's a very solid and enjoyable title. I am not good with words so I will summarize the pros and cons of the game in dot point.

Pros:
* Solid graphics.
* Interesting gameplay.
* Loot aspect really adds to the game, I enjoy finding and trialing new items, especially legendary weapons.
* Transmuting (combining items to get items of better quality) really adds to the game and improves the min-maxing" aspect of it.
* There is a good variety of viable builds.
* Story is pretty decent with an interesting art style.

Cons:
* The game can be grindy in places.
* Some challenges are time based and therefore needlessly frustrating.
* In endgame some areas are clearly better than others for raiding."

reviewText:
BEATEN!
#11 hours / Level 30

Victor Vran is a fun action RPG (diablo/torchlight/etc) with a few interesting twists.  You play as Victor Vran - no matter what style of character you intend to make. There are no skill trees or tranditional point sytems.  When you level up, you get a pre-set bonus and then one of 3 items.

The variety in the gameplay comes with the fact that attacks and specials are linked to what type of weapon you have. Each weapon type has 3 attacks.  On top of that, you have charge attack specials, which are loot-based specials that are triggerable when a meter is full (it fills up when you attack stuff).

One other point of interest is that the game is split into actual levels. Each level has challanges associated with it if you choose.

Pros:
- Play whatever style you like. The ability to use anything is nice.
- Challenges will keep you coming back (and post-game loot hunting).
- A good challenge solo without being impossible.
- Multiplayer is implemented well. Start as lobby that anyone can join.

Cons:
- Not many, honestly.  If you like these kinds of games, you will dig it.

reviewText: So far I'm level seven in Victor Vran and so far I'm impressed. People are comparing it to Diablo II and Path of Exile but this game is it's own different breed entirely. Instead of generic level based skills, you have two weapons each with three different skills apiece. Being able to switch weapons on the fly, this proves pretty handy in certain scenarios. You also have destiny cards" that you equip to act as your passive abilities. Then you have your demonic powers that at level fourteen
date: you can equip two that act as your ultimate attacks. Demonic powers are also cards that you equip just like the destiny cards. I've been strictly playing with my mouse but apparently both the keyboard "Action" setting and the gamepad controls are great. The game is indeed an action role playing game but I wouldn't necessarily compare it to Diablo II or PoE but more akin to Gauntlet than anything else. The combat is excellent and satisfying. The only problem I have is the lack of armor. You strictly have outfits that you equipment for certain bonuses that change your style of gameplay. Overall with the few hours I've put into the game
recommended: it is excellent and I would recommend it."

reviewText: I like it already! Looking for a basic ARPG to play with my non-gamer wife, we ran across this one. We'd just finished up the Van Helsing set (buggy but fun). We just started playing it and are just at the lower levels but we love it so far. The cartoon cut scenes remind me of old Legend of Kryandia somehow but it's got a catchy nostalgia to it. You get a little more freedom of movement than most similar titles which is nice. Seems like less spell tree development but a lot more weapon type choices and corresponding special moves and animations plus all sorts of enhancement cards, potions and charge up demon spells. You can't not love the flying hammer smash + explosion animation--it causes maniacal laughter. I don't know if this is found elsewhere but one cool thing in the gameplay is specific challenges within the main quest. Kill this many things with a sword, don't use potions, find this many secret locations, etc. So, you're not just mindlessly hacking and slashing with the biggest weapons you can find. Definite thumbs up on first impressions.

reviewText:
TLDR: A must buy game.

I have played Diablos 1 through 3, Torchlight 1 and 2, Path of Exile, Marvel Heroes and Divinity... Having said that, I think Victor Vran has reached peak perfection on the ARPG genre. This is the game you should not think twice of picking up. I was hesistant at first since I wasn't an early access buyer and just decided to buy the game based on all of the good reviews on Steam (and youtube gameplay videos). I bought one for myself and for my brother and we have never looked back.

PROS:
- Very fluid gameplay and great graphics. Keeping things fascinating is the ability to jump, and dodge, and so on
- Can downscale graphics to be playable on low-end desktops/laptops
- Decent story with great voice acting (much much much better story than Diablo 3/Torchlight 2)
- A bit steampunk (enough to please fans of the genre, but not too much to turn off non-fans of steampunk).
- The setting and ambiance of the story and game - old eastern European Transylvannia" - is very much on point
- You can change your difficulty almost on the fly with hexes - plus the difficulty setting is so innovatively done (again
date: not like D3 where higher difficulty settings just give more health
recommended: toughness and power to mobs)\n- The outfit you wear essentially determines majority of your playstyle. However
hoursPlayed: the system is easy to understand but at the same time is intricate and deep. No skill trees here - but how they implemented choice is wonderfully done. Your outfit
voteText: weapons
helpfulPercent: demon powers
votesHelpful: and destiny cards determine your "class"
votesTotal:
and there are possibly a billion combination of these
- A lot of people seemingly hate "The Voice" character but I love him. A lot of el-oh-el references and funny quips abound

CONS:
- still some bugs that need to be ironed out. Some champion mobs don't reset from rage mode when you die even though their hitpoints goes back to full. Also there are areas where when you make the mistake of stepping on them the whole screen freezes (but the UI is still active
votesFunny: strangely). happens rarely though.\n- online coop mode works but can be confusing. It turns out that you can only be friends in-game with folk you are Steam friends with. Also
commentsCount:
the UI needs to be worked on to show you if you are already in a party or night as there is no confirmation if you want to join a friend's party when he/she invites you. The game should immediately port you to your friends' instance when you join

MINOR GRIPES:
- no playable female characters (which doesn't matter to me as I'm a guy and I like playing guy characters but putting it here for gender equality - they should make an Irene costume or skin)
- should have a costume/skin system
- more addicting than crack :(

Will still rate the game 10/10."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game has its potentials. Besides those merits mentioned by other reviewers, I just focus on the cons of the game in current version.
1. The mouse control is clunky, but I'm sure the dev will optimize it in future updates.
2. The combat isn't that smooth, but I assume it's OK for an early-access game
3. The challenges are getting boring along the way, they're fairly repetitive and sometimes annoying
4. The leveling system has its validity and creativity, but I still don't find it's very exiting to be given a green weapon after slavery hacking and slashing hundreds of monsters.
5. Some minors, for a ARPG games, the loot system isn't appealing right now mainly due to the limited variety, but I believe loots will be much richer along the development
Anyways, this game is OK right now, depending on the efforts the devs put into it, can be an good game or another ARPG going to the bin.

reviewText:
Superior Hack'n Slay - game with active combat elements, like dodging, attack timing.

I didn't expect much from this game, hadn't I heard about it at all, before a friend was talking
about it. For nearly 7 bucks I gave it a try and .. love it.

It's different to other Hack'n Slays like D3, because you have alot of variety how to build your

you a bare 'layout' of your hero, in other games that would be close to hero class").

reviewText:
Amazing game. If you've ever played Diablo 3 or torchlight 2, Any rpg and thought I wish there was a higher skill ceiling for normal fights not just bosses. Where dodging is not a passive move. Then play this game its fantastic. it adds jumping rolling and incredibly dynamic fighting to the standard arp play by using wasd to move around.

Intuitive and fun though much harder then most arpgs. I keep being told with newer coop and mmos. Well the games easy but only for the first 200 hours then you'll finally hit the hard part... O.O... Waiting until endgame to actually need to play has killed so many games for me. When 5 percent of your content needs more then 3 buttons then 95 percent of your players are going to fall asleep.

This one fixes it with a hex system ((turn on and off buffs to the monsters at will))

Other then that heres the setup. two weapons switch between them at will each with their own left click attack e and q ((drastically different effects from crowd control to self buffs)) on top of that two powers which require a seperate resource to use no cooldown on them though. Then you have cards which add passive though sometimes dramatic changes to gameplay.

One thing! if you want to use cool looking powers spells what have you then make sure to pick the top hat costume it gives focus ((for casting those moves)) All the time instead of on hit etc. Makes it much easier to manage. But lower armor to compensate.

Thats the one caveat two actually no chracter customization as far as cosmetics other then costumes.


9.5 out of ten. First game to get my pulse up in a while.

reviewText:
Victor Vran sports deceptively enticing gameplay at the outset, but as a whole, the game slowly but surely devolves into tedium over the hours.

Anyone who has played Baldur's Gate: Dark Alliance or its sequel will find familiarity in the setup of Victor Vran. You have a dodge button, a jump button, 3 weapon attacks, and a powerful ability called an Overdrive that gradually charges as you deal or take damage. Movement and abilities are responsive and fluid, there's even a wall jump mechanic. Areas offer secrets to be found, and challenges to be completed. And you will of course level up, gain new abilities, acquire powerful equipment, what's not to like?

As it turns out, quite a bit. Because apart from the relatively polished gameplay, there are cut corners on nearly every other aspect of the game. Victor Vran had such POTENTIAL, which was unfortunately squandered by either a limited budget or a lack of vision.

To begin, when you go to your home base the first time, it's pretty sparse, but still you think: Wow
date: this is probably going to get a whole bunch of other people offering cool items
recommended: crafting and spells over the course of the game!" But then 10 hours later
hoursPlayed: you've nearly beaten the game and none of that ever happened. Transmutation(oooh!) unlocks at Level 16
voteText: and then you discover Transmutation is just a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ crafting system to increase damage or critical chance on your weapons. Or you can forget about it entirely and just wait a few levels and get a better weapon from drops. That works too.\n\nThe combat is great fun at first. It's awesome blasting skeletons with a shotgun for the first hour or so
helpfulPercent: but then you expect the combat to evolve in some way
votesHelpful: but it never does. 7 weapons in the game
votesTotal: each with 3 moves. The same 3 moves you use when you get your first Scythe are the same 3 moves you'll be using at Level 50.\n\nAreas offer secrets to be found
votesFunny: but those secrets are merely gold or a random weapon.\n\nMonster variety is limited. Spiders
commentsCount: skeletons
column16: wraiths
column17: rifle skeletons
column18: hammer skeletons
column19: elementals are the majority of what you fight. Areas consist of gardens
column20: caves
column21: crypts
column22: cemeteries
column23: city streets
column24: and houses. Mix and match area and enemy types as you see fit! Perhaps a garden with spiders
column25: skeletons and wraiths. Or a cave with spiders. Or a house with gargoyles
column26: skeletons and wraiths. Or an open plain with skeletons
column27: spiders and elementals.\n\nThe theme of this game is literally: What you see is what you get. Nothing of substance ever changes in this game to keep you truly interested. You level up at first and can use 2 weapons. Cool. Then you level up and can use 2 potions.  Ok. Then you level up and can use 2 Overdrives. And that's the extent of the leveling system. Every time you level up after that you get more health or Destiny Points so you can equip Destiny Cards
column28: which are just more stat padding. There is no real
column29: meaty customization to be found here.\n\nThe characters are lifeless. The story is forgettable. On a better note
column30: Victor has a voice inside his head who makes wise cracks about things from time to time
column31: and he was funny enough to make me laugh several times.\n\nIf I were to express my biggest issue with this game
column32: it's that we should be playing its sequel right now. Victor Vran has laid down a decent foundation which could be massively improved to great success. Unfortunately
column33: that is not the case. As it is
column34: Victor Vran is not worth more than 2 hours of your time
column35: and no more than $5 of your money."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game has its potentials. Besides those merits mentioned by other reviewers, I just focus on the cons of the game in current version.
1. The mouse control is clunky, but I'm sure the dev will optimize it in future updates.
2. The combat isn't that smooth, but I assume it's OK for an early-access game
3. The challenges are getting boring along the way, they're fairly repetitive and sometimes annoying
4. The leveling system has its validity and creativity, but I still don't find it's very exiting to be given a green weapon after slavery hacking and slashing hundreds of monsters.
5. Some minors, for a ARPG games, the loot system isn't appealing right now mainly due to the limited variety, but I believe loots will be much richer along the development
Anyways, this game is OK right now, depending on the efforts the devs put into it, can be an good game or another ARPG going to the bin.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After much gameplay and completion of the available content, I bring to light my review thus far.

Combat, Weapons, and Abilities:
The combat mechanics are smooth and support both keyboard/mouse and Controller. Being able to dodge and roll adds the feeling of complete control over the encounter situation. Though, it is a hack and slash ARPG, you still have the flexibility to choose how to go about an encounter.

Weapons determine which set of abilities you have. Each weapon comes with a basic attack and 2 specials attacks. Each unique within themselves, pressing you to be more tactful in your decisions. You can equip 2 weapons at one time. For example, you can carry a Shotgun with a Rapier. Allowing you begin the encounter ranged and then dashing in to strike quick and devasting blows. Switching between weapons is situation dependant and personal choice. It is, however, needed in order to progress with harder difficulty settings.

The four weapon choices are: Sword, Hammer, Shotgun, and Rapier.

Demon Power is nothing new to ARPG MMOs, in this game you will eventually (once you increase in level) be able to equip 2 separate demon powers.

Maps and Difficulties:
The maps range in size, just as any other ARPG. Where this game separates itself most from others like it, is the ability to jump. Jumping allows for you to reach heights where secret treasures await you. The current available maps environments range from inside a castle of Skeletons, outside in a spider infested courtyard, to deep into the bowels of an earth encrusted dungeon. Each sharing similar mobs as well as having their own unique sets of encounters.

The difficulty of the game is set by you at anytime. The hex system is quite enjoyable, you control a packs buffs and if you want more champions or less. Maybe you are farming for gold, so turn on the hex for gold drop increased. If you are farming for gear, turn on the appropriate hexes and start hacking away on any map you choose. Too hard, then turn off a hex or two until you find your comfort zone.

Character progression, gear, and cards:
As you level your character to level 10 (current max level) you will unlock more weapon, cards, and demon power slots. This is where the customization comes into play.

Cards boost your stats and more importantly can cripple or complement your build. So, choose wisely as a bad setup could leave you crippled on the battlefield.

Farming is part of any ARPG just as much as this one, this game is not for everyone. In order to progress to be able to stack your Hexes, you will need to farm for better gear, cards, weapons, and demon powers. Its a question of will you enjoy it.

Maps Challenges:
Each map has its own set of challenges. So, when you are 68/70 mobs killed without taking any damage and you get hit, you will have to start that challenge over. The positive side is that there are several challenges per map, so if you lose one, you may gain another. Allowing for you to complete that map and come back at a later time, better equipped and with a vengance.

Overall Opinion:
Victor Van.... Van Helsing.... not sure if its a ripoff or a parody of the other. Probably should have given a different name to the game, something more genarlized and not focused on a characters name. This would allow for the choice of Female or Male character.

Positives:
Gameplay is smooth and combat is enjoyable. The various amount of maps are fun to play and with the challenges and hex system, there are hours of gameplay to be had.

The background of the game is colorful and easy on the eyes. Making for some good scenery along your adventures.

Negatives:
The storyline dialogue and voice over is not yet in game, which puts me in a position where I am unable to play for countless hours on end. Not having the storyline, the only thing to do from start to finish is complete the challenges and the first set of quests. Do not expect to get lost in a story when it is not there yet.

The multiplayer is not yet active, so dont be fooled by the advertisement. It is content yet to come.

Should I buy it?
I would suggest buying the early access, since it is currently on sale. Some will get exactly what they pay for while the others will get more out of it. If you want something else to play that is new and inexpensive, buy it.
voteText: 5 of 10 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I feel like I gave this game a fair enough shot. Bought the 2-pack on sale to try it with a friend of mine since we both thought it looked good. It was. For awhile.

Before I begin, I only put in about 5~6 hours into this game before deciding I probably won't be revisiting it. As such, I'm only going to be able to review what I experienced.

Weapons There's lots of weapon types in Victor Vran. All of them have a basic attack, and two special attacks. Some weapon types, like the Hand Mortar, are a bit more complex in how they work. The Hand Mortar allows you to hold down the button in order to charge/aim" where your bomb will go
date: which lets players rapid fire super close range if they choose to
recommended: or safely arc bombs a long distance to attack monsters. I'm going over Hand Mortars because they're the main weapon that stuck out to me when I was playing. 90% of the fun I had playing Victor Vran was using a Hand Mortar. All other weapons were incredibly simple to use
hoursPlayed: and got boring after maybe 30 minutes of playing them.\n\nCombat  Consider this a sub-section to Weapons. Most enemies
voteText: with the exception of super baby enemies that attack you in groups of 20 and all die in one hit
helpfulPercent: have fairly obvious tells for their attacks
votesHelpful: and the game puts a lot of emphasis on you being able to dodge these attacks. Victor Vran is a game that tries to be an ARPG and a hack 'n' slash at the same time
votesTotal: but it doesn't really work. Combat feels very mundane and basic
votesFunny: because what you can do in terms of attacks is very limited. "Hack 'N' Slash" is a pretty good description
commentsCount: considering that's basically all you can do. A lot of enemies either go down super easily
column16: or last forever and only have maybe two attacks that you have to dodge. Fighting one strong enemy should feel engaging
column17: but in Victor Vran it doesn't. But why doesn't it? The answer lies in the fact that again
column18: Victor Vran is a Hack 'N' Slash built as an ARPG. I'll go a little bit more into that...\n\nMovement and Exploration here. In Victor Vran
column19: you can dodge roll and jump. You can use either of these maneuvers to cancel out of a weapon's basic attack and move away
column20: which means that at the first sight of danger
column21: no matter what weapon you're using
column22: you're able to safely get out (most of the time) and wait for another chance to engage. Let's talk about jumping for a second. The land of Victor Vran is littered with treasure chests that are "hidden." How are they hidden? Well
column23: two ways typically. Jumping somewhere/onto a platform that vaguely looks like you can maybe jump on it
column24: or walljumping in an incredibly specific way. Jumping ultimately is nothing more than a convenience feature at times when traversing areas
column25: and a "puzzle solving mecahnic
column26: if you want to call it that. You can also jump and then jump again to slam down and disperse enemies, but this is rarely useful, and given the AoE-ness of a lot of weapons it's usually a bad thing. A lot of attacks that look like they can be avoided via jumping can't, and the list goes on. SO. Finding treasure. A lot of the treasure chests are pretty well hidden in my opinion, and being able to move the camera around implies that the developers really wanted players to get a grasp of their surroundings and see where they can go. In fact, there's a TON of emphasis on the exploration compared to the combat. Some challenges are just based around killing a certain amount of enemies with a certain weapon under a time limit or some other arbitrary condition. Others are based on finding secrets hidden in the area, which can involve walljumping off of a column and onto higher ground, going through a crack in the wall that you can just barely squeeze through, and many more ways. Victor Vran has the exploration and movement of a hack'n'slash adventure game, but has the combat of an ARPG limited to a hack 'N' slash formula.\n\nChallenges I'm adding this section to the review since I felt it needed it. This might mess up the flow of the review a bit. Anyway, Victor Vran is composed of large open areas that typically lead to smaller, mini areas. Dungeons if you will. Each area, both main and sub, have challenges." These challenge can range from "kill x amount of enemies with x weapon" to "just kill this many enemies" to "kill 300 enemies in 2 minutes without getting hit because #challenge." Each challenge constitutes a star on the map
column28: is basically the only sense of "progression" you'll feel out of Victor Vran. And it doesn't even do a good job of doing that. Rewards for doing challenges are RIDICULOUSLY small
column29: which is a real kick in the gut when the game makes such a big deal about completing challenges. W\hen you complete a challenge
column30: a banner falls and lands where you are and poops out your prize. This can be a small
column31: REALLY small amount of gold broken up into smaller gold piles to make you feel like you're getting a lot of gold
column32: or a white grade weapon for that challenge of becoming Mozart and teaching weasels French. Challenges are supposed to make players feel inclined to complete a game fully
column33: especially when an instant reward is tied to each one
column34: but Victor Vran essentially asks "why did you even bother dude" and throws you something useless.\n\n"Hexes" are something I'll tack on real quick. I didn't mess with these at all
column35:
but they're basically the Skulls from Halo. They make the game """harder"""  but there's no reason to turn these on other than the useless challenges yelling at you to do so.

I have one final gripe with this game.

Sense of Progression Destiny cards
column37: what have you. There are a lot of ways players can give themselves stats in Victor Vran. And that's basically it. As far as progression goes
column38: upping your stats is the only thing there is. Weapons you get via drops are rarely better than what you're currently using
column41: two damage increase that you take because why not. You cannot change your attacks in any way (other than the demon spells or whatever they were called) and there is no skill tree. The only thing you have is this weird level up "system" where you pick a reward and the game yells at you saying you can up your stats by equipping even more destiny cards wowee. Aside from a bunch of stars on the map that said I did some challenge in an area
column42: I did not feel like I made any progress in Victor Vran. Even when I upgraded or found a stronger weapon
column43: it felt exactly the same. A lot of weapon types I would straight up not use because they were too boring to play for an extended period of time.\n\nClosing I feel that if Victor Vran focused on being just a hack'n'slash adventure or an ARPG
column44: it would've been a lot better (leaning towards hack 'n' slash). Victor Vran had the potential to be something incredibly fun
column45: but what I played was a weird mix of ideas that ultimately didn't go well together. It feels like a lot of people flocked to this game because it was new and "unique" and the store page literally says "dude this game is so skill based....holy....just wow dude....." and also says "character build" when the only way you can build a character is through stat boosts. And yes
column46: which outfit you use is ultimately just a stat boost. Hell
column47: a lot of the stat boosts are literally "when you do damage
column48: you might do MORE DAMAGE." Almost every big and scary enemy that I enounctered was defeated using the traditional tactic of running/dodge rolling around until the enemy stopped attacking
column49: going in for a few stabs or whacks or what have you
column50: and moving when he went to do something else.\n\nIf you want a fun hack 'n' slash experience
column51: I do not recommend Victor Vran.\nIf you want a fun ARPG experience
column52: I do not recommend Victor Vran."

reviewText:
If you liked van helsing...well - you'll probably hate this game.
bording, repetitive fights, endless chase for uninteresting loot, no decernable storiline.
The game is about loot - and if you like that sort of thing - you might like this game
However - if you like, you know - gameplay, story etc' - there's none to be found here.
spending time playing this game or leveling gets you nowhere, you don't get any better, stronger - enemies stay the same boring unchallanging mess.
You battle an endless array of the same enemies, there's an elaborate and unintersting system to improve the various weaponry you find. there's a weird card system and you are granted these useless items on leveling up...

bottom line  - poor man's van helsing - just play van helsing instead.

reviewText:
Has a similar mechanic for hotbar that GW2 has. You have 5 weapon skills and 5 other customizable skill slots in GW2. In this game it's only 3 each. I'm pretty sure this was done to make it easier for controllers to be used. You also can have 2 weapon sets and switch between them, thus changing your first 3 skills.

When you level up, starting at level 10, you can pick from a few different cards. These cards can be equipped and modify your stats/abilities. However, You can only have a few equipped (3 or 4).

There are no classes and there are no talents.

You can equip 2 demon powers, which are essentially spells. In order to use them, you have to charge them up first.

Due to all this, I feel the game is too simplistic for a PC ARPG.

I had originally picked up a 4 pack and tried it out before giving it to my friends. After trying it however, I decided it would not actually be as much fun as I had hoped, so I requested a refund.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

VV is an iso arpg that has a pretty awesome jump mechanic and gamepad support. I love iso arpgs but cannot stand to play them with a mouse, so major kudos to the devs for the gamepad support! Now with that out of the way, VV is good fun, not great, not the next Diablo, not even close, but its arcade style fast paced combat and jumping mechanic alone make this game worth trying. Ultimately, VV is a mash up between Bastion and Sacred 3.

Honestly I'm on the fence about recommending the game. I sway to YES obviously but mainly I'm jaded because of the gamepad support that I so desperately want in iso arpgs.. Currently the game is stale and I became bored with the game very quickly. I don't get bored in arpgs...

The main problem is the type of level progression system used and the lack of variety with enemy mobs. I remember hitting level 2 and my only reward was loot (a shotgun I already had). I obtained only loot for leveling up. Really!?  I was given a weapon I already had after fighting non-stop spiders for a hour, the same exact spiders, which they didn't even bother to reskin. I remember a game for XBLA called Crimson Alliance doing something like this and I hated it. What happened to the level progression of old? The one where you level up skill trees and individual stats? ::::sigh::::

I won't go any furthur with this review other than to say, several changes must be made to the final product for me to enjoy it. We'll see, I'm hopeful, the devs seem on it. For now don't believe the hype, the game has promise, but no where near deserving the huge amount of praise it is getting. Maybe its because I have played every game known to man, I dunno, but VV gets a 6/10, for now.

reviewText:
If you're the type of person who likes loot treadmills (think: Diablo or Borderlands), or just want something mindless to chill with, then Victor Vran might be for you. It's a very-competently made Diablo III-esque clone, with full controller support and good multiplayer options.

However, I'm not the type of person this game is made for, as I easily get bored of loot treadmills due to the sheer repetition and lack of interesting decisions to make. So, I can't personally recommend it to people who share my tastes.

And for what it's worth, I used the hardest difficulty-level to avoid the risk of things becoming too easy. But it ended-up becoming a back-and-fourth between:

a) slogging through stuff that takes  *forever* to kill, devoid of any sense of challenge or tension. And
b) finding some high-level item which then makes everything too easy for a while.

Maybe I should've played it on Normal mode and selectively-enabled Hexes, but I doubt that would've fundamentally changed anything for me.

So yeah, good game, but it's not for me.

reviewText:
Most dynamic combat in a ARPG from a really unexpected developer.

Its content may not be close to Grim Dawn(which is in my opinion is the best ARPG released in a long time) but its combat is so refreshing, I dont know how to describe it. It's setting has a nice colorful atmosphere while managing to be grim enough to fit the genre. It feels a bit strange to listen to a monster hunter with the voice of Geralt but acts like a different person.

I think only thing this game needs is a sequel and a bit more marketing. With a fast paced and smooth combat like
this, people who dont even like the genre will like this game.

reviewText:
Lacking much depth or replay value, Victor Vran is a mediocre dungeon crawler with good combat. You play as Victor, a character with demon powers, and must remove a curse from the city of Zagoravia in an overwhelmingly generic adventure. You are joined by a voice in your head that sometimes makes bad jokes but mostly stays quiet. The game emulates prominent titles in the genre, notably Diablo 3, with similar locations, monsters and abilities. The combat is different, with seven main weapon types that each have two skills. Most weapons are fun to use, with special mention going to the awesome lightning gun. Players can dodge during action to avoid damage, and jumping is used to find treasure or take shortcuts.

The city of Zagoravia is separated into handmade districts and each of those contains a number of dungeon-like areas. Each district repopulates with monsters if you fast-travel back to the town hub, and every dungeon resets the instant you leave it. This can be annoying if you explore a dungeon before the story sends you there. The main incentive to replay is to find legendary weapons and complete challenges in each level. Challenges might entice you to use another weapon or avoid taking health potions. Unfortunately many felt like a grind to force extra value and they often required the use of Hexes, which are just difficulty modifiers. Playing through the main campaign took about 11 hours and was largely forgettable. Once complete, there was almost no incentive to keep playing.

Multiplayer fares better. It has great netcode which ensures the action is smooth. You will be going through the same areas as before, with the narrator repeating the same lines and monsters spawning in the same place. Only this time somebody might join and enable hard mode with all hexes to upset your game. So it’s probably best with friends in a private match. Either online or offline, Victor Vran has decent combat but it is not enough to earn a recommendation.

Read my longer review[www.newgamenetwork.com]

reviewText: Decent enough game ot begin with, but as you get into more difficult content some cracks begin to show, esp if you're using ranged weapns a lot. Aiming is highly dodgy at best. It even highlights enemies you put the mouse over, then proceeds to fire way wide of that target sometimes. The overkill mechanic seems to be pretty broken (or just doesn't make any sense). Hitting even a relatively weak enemy with no dicernible HP left with a hard-hitting attack (e.g. hammer smash) sometimes doesn't count as an overkill. This makes one challenge in particular almost impossibe to attain (except by fluke). There are also issues with movement and mouse tracking and other minor glitches. As a beta/early access, I could recommend this, but it clearly still needs to polish and tweaking. Nice try, but not quite there yet.

reviewText: Victor Vran does not promise much and does little well. Essentially, it is a popcorn game that should not be purchased for more than five to ten dollars.\n\nWhat the game promises and does well includes ...hordes of monsters
recommended: and Xbox controller support. The player does indeed face hordes of monsters (which is also a negative discussed later on) and it may even prove overwhelming at times. Seldom does the player feel that he isn't in the midst of chaotic action. The co-op is intuitive and seamless (note, be sure that everyone in a lobby presses his face against all dungeon portals, or the dungeon may not be available from the fast travel map later). On top of these well-delivered promises, the controls themselves feel right (in terms of layout and responsiveness) for this specific game and carry over very well to controllers.\n\nHowever, the list of promises Victor Vran does not fulfill is more comprehensive: a ...story of the dark world...
voteText: extensive character development
helpfulPercent: and huge variety in monster behavior."\n\nThe story aspect of this game is lackluster
votesHelpful: boiling down to several flat cut scenes intertwined with lazy and uninspired boss fights (which have been done many times before and prove to be more of a chore than difficult). The atmosphere is quirky (not positively) and tries to take Handsome Jack's constant berating and taunting and make it its own in its main antagonist - where it fails is in its taking itself too seriously in terms of tone and pretending to have a higher purpose or deeper meaning. The game ends with not even a slap on the back or a sense that your six hours spent on completing the story was worth it - your actions are not impactful on the world at all. It feels as if the developers attempted to take their favorite parts of several games and splice them together (unfortunately
votesTotal: unsuccessfully) [note
votesFunny: gratuitous portal/time-traveling sand world strangely similar to that in Witcher 3].\n\nThe action and enemies are two-faced - yes

reviewText:
This game is absolutely technically ...horrible.   Compared to Van Helsing it is just plain BAD.  I played through level 10 and let me tell you - it was a pure chore.  I'm not sure why it has gotten so many favorable reviews, because it doesn't deserve them.

Game controls (at least for PC) are absolutely horrible.  Three attacks are allowed and two of those are special and on long timers.   Thirty percent of the time,  the game animation over-rides the ability to use the special attacks.

Bait and switch during boss battles (i..e., running around and letting a boss beat on you while some special power sucks the life outta you) is absolutely painful, even on casual.  Its almost as if the game is negatively encouraging you to replay completed levels over and over in order to get the weapons and cards necessary to defeat a boss.

Add in the fact that the weapons are basically uninteresting variations on three items - hammer, sword, shotgun, and it's basically a frustration-fest.  The demonic powers your supposed to obtain with the Overcharge ability are absolutely laughable...you push and push to get the overcharge event going and are rewarded with an unimpressive spurt of power.  To make matters more frustrating, Overcharge trickles away about 5 times faster than it takes to build up, ensuring that you surely wont use it often.

I'll give the designers credit for the ambience and graphics, theyre pretty good, but gameplay totally ruins any kudos they might have gotten for that.

Merchants are also horrible - I have yet to see any affordable weapons for sale that are useful at all (at least through level 10 when I finally said enough, and stopped playing).  Potions, what there are of them through level 10, are on timers, and are a complete waste of the gamer's coinage.  You can easily find potions just as good as you play though a level.

The game looks good, i'll give them that...but the gameplay is absolutely boring and uninspired and didn't draw me in to continue playing it.  Even having Geralt of Rivia's voice as the protagonist didn't persuade me to play a moment longer.

Basically 4/10 - would not purchase again.

reviewText:
I wouldn't compare it to Diablo 2 like the others. This game is more a mix of Van Helsing and Gauntlet. There's less worry about item min/maxing and almost no talents to speak of except in the form of Destiny Cards that give buffs to your gameplay style. It' s a fun game, but can feel a little tedious. After playing for a few hours,  it's become incredibly boring.  Can't recommend this.

reviewText: I bought this game due to my absolutel LOVE of ARPG's, even bad ones like the Van helsing series. I play ARPG's more than any genre, Torchlight series, Diablo series, Van helsing sereies, Grim Dawn, Path of Exile, etc. etc. This game had tons of great reviews, had new interesting game mechanics, so I gave it a shot.\n\nFirst off, there is no real skill progressoin of any sort. Every ARPG i've ever played has a real solid RPG aspect, where you can really create your character how you want to. In Victor Vran, you equip a weapon, and the weapon gives you skills. You can equip demon abilties" which are just charge up skills. Finally you get cards
date: these cards have some base passive stats for your character to give a minor customizable aspect to your character
recommended: but its very bland and doesnt feel like it changes anything. I can get past all of this for the most part
hoursPlayed: this im fine with.\n\nWhat breaks the game is the controls. There three options for controls
voteText: and yet all feel clunky. When it comes to ARPG's
helpfulPercent: tight controls make a game
votesHelpful: and clunky controls break them. This had weird hit boxes where I would be clicking on an enemy
votesTotal: yet I would be walking to them rather then attacking them. Also the fact that multiple of the skills are on keys (W
votesFunny: E
commentsCount: etc.) but don't automatically attack when pressed. So therefor you need to Shift + key to attack. It's minor but it makes no sense. Im well aware shift is used in many ARPG's if not all of them. But when Im surrounded by 30 spiders
column16: and want to using my PBAOE skill
column17: i cant just click it
column18: and have it go off.\n\nSecondly the map will randomly rotate your view and will be south after exiting a point. Im all for map control and camera rotation if its needed. The weird hit detection on things made it so I couldn't walk to area's and needed the camera rotation just to walk to the area i needed to go. So it's needed in this game
column19: but it's needed because of bad mechanics. Map/camera rotation is something ARPG's simply dont need if the camera is implemented well
column20: and can only sometimes confuse the player
column21: there is no benefit to having it.\n\nIt's all these minor things like this that coupled with weird hit box detection that makes the combat feel bad and unsatifying. I really wanted to give this a chance for the simple fact that it was trying new things to broaden the ARPG horizons. It just wasn't implemented well
column22: and thus I must give this a "No" recommendation."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's a game with pretty cool physics with some secret areas that have useless treasure chests. But mostly it's your typical action RPG with nothing special. The character customization is very lacking, 3 abilities per weapon and a severe lack of different type of weapons.

What they have already is pretty cool, but there just needs to be a lot more of it. It just gets boring once you unlock lightning guns and mortars. Every item you find becomes a minor upgrade, levelling up is very minor (most of the time you just get 5 potions...).

And the multiplayer is pretty lazy. Very few things are shared with the party. My friend had an ability that placed the next hit is a crit" buff on targets
date: but that wasn't specific to him so my lightning gun ate up the charge and made his build worthless.\n\nI played this back when it first came on steam as early access
recommended: and it doesn't seem like it has come very far. It needs a lot more content. The character development needs an overhaul. It's incredibly casual."
